P1:
"Observation versus prophylactic Ladd procedure for asymptomatic intestinal rotational abnormalities in heterotaxy syndrome: A systematic review"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2:
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion.
[Yes]

P3:
"Heterotaxy syndrome (HS), a consequence of aberrations in left-toright positional signaling in early embryonic development, manifests as cardiac and visceral anatomic malpositioning. Forty percent to 90% of patients with HS also have intestinal rotational abnormalities (IRA) [1]."
The introduction provides rationale for the review in the context of what is known about heterotaxy syndrome and intestinal rotational abnormalities.
[Yes]

P4:
No relevant quotes found.
The introduction does not provide an explicit statement of the review questions being addressed in terms of PICOS.
[No]

P5:
"This study was performed according to guidelines from the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) [6]."
The methods indicate that the review followed PRISMA guidelines but do not specify if a protocol exists or where it can be accessed.
[No]

P6:
"Exclusion criteria were non-English language articles, case reports, case studies with three patients or less, and studies without outcomes data."
Exclusion criteria for study eligibility are specified.
[Yes]

P7:
"An online database search for all articles published between January 1993 and January 2014 on pediatric patients using the following keywords was performed: "heterotaxy", "rotation", "volvulus", "Ladd procedure", "Ivemark", "asplenia", and "polysplenia". Searches were repeated in PubMed, Medline, CINAHL, and Cochrane library."
Information sources searched are described with dates of coverage.
[Yes]

P8:
"An online database search for all articles published between January 1993 and January 2014 on pediatric patients using the following keywords was performed: "heterotaxy", "rotation", "volvulus", "Ladd procedure", "Ivemark", "asplenia", and "polysplenia"."
The full search strategy with keywords is provided but not the exact electronic search syntax for reproducibility.
[No]

P9:
"Two independent researchers (A.A. and A.W.) confirmed the inclusion of appropriate citations based on study definitions and aims. See Fig. 1 for a flow diagram summary of the literature vetting process."
The study selection process is described.
[Yes]

P10:
No relevant quotes found.
The data collection process is not described in detail.
[No]

P11:
"Characteristics such as mesenteric width and atrial isomerism were examined."
Some data items collected are mentioned but not all PICOS variables.
[No]

P12:
No relevant quotes found.
Methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies are not described.
[No]

P13:
"Primary outcomes were defined as volvulus and 30-day (perioperative) Ladd procedure mortality. Secondary outcomes included overall mortality, 30-day (perioperative) complications and overall complications."
The primary and secondary outcome measures are stated.
[Yes]

P14:
"Because of the absence of randomized controlled trials and the heterogeneous nature of studies, a formal meta-analysis was not performed."
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P15:
No relevant quotes found.
Risk of bias across studies was not assessed in this review without meta-analysis.
[NA]

P16:
No relevant quotes found.
No additional analyses were mentioned.
[NA]

P17:
"Fig. 1 Flow diagram summary of literature vetting process."
A flow diagram provides the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded with reasons.
[Yes]

P18:
"Table 1 Group characteristics of included studies."
A table provides the characteristics of each included study.
[Yes]

P19:
No relevant quotes found.
Data on risk of bias for each included study is not presented.
[No]

P20:
"Table 2 Outcomes by system."
A table presents the summary outcome data for each group.
[Yes]

P21:
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22:
No assessment of risk of bias across studies was reported for this review without meta-analysis.
[NA]

P23:
No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24:
"Heterotaxy syndrome refers to abnormal arrangement of thoracoabdominal organs along the left-right body axis, and is associated with multiple congenital anomalies including complex congenital heart disease [4]. Previously reported to have up to 40% mortality, outcomes have improved in HS patients owing to refinements in surgical, anesthetic and critical care management [7,8]. IRA occurs in approximately 40–90% of HS patients [1]."
The discussion summarizes the main findings and their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25:
"The subtype of right atrial isomerism has the potential to be a predictor of volvulus risk in HS patients with further investigation into this area."
Some limitations are discussed, though not comprehensively at the study, outcome and review levels.
[No]

P26:
"Despite the low risk of volvulus in the data presented here, there are anecdotal cases of patients with HS who presented with volvulus that resulted in death. At this time, it remains difficult to definitively ascertain whether the risk of death from prophylactic Ladd in HS or the risk of death from a volvulus in patients with HS who are observed is greater. A randomized, prospective trial to determine which subsets of patients with HS have the highest risk of volvulus is needed in order to optimize the care of this patient population. Ideally, a Ladd procedure should only be performed on those patients with HS that have the highest risk of volvulus, allowing the benefits of no operation to outweigh the risks."
The conclusion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27:
No relevant quotes found.
Sources of funding and support are not described.
[No]

"Despite the low risk of volvulus in the data presented here, there are anecdotal cases of patients with HS who presented with volvulus that resulted in death. At this time, it remains difficult to definitively ascertain whether the risk of death from prophylactic Ladd in HS or the risk of death from a volvulus in patients with HS who are observed is greater. A randomized, prospective trial to determine which subsets of patients with HS have the highest risk of volvulus is needed in order to optimize the care of this patient population. Ideally, a Ladd procedure should only be performed on those patients with HS that have the highest risk of volvulus, allowing the benefits of no operation to outweigh the risks."

A1

Reasoning: Study selection was done in duplicate by two independent reviewers.
[Yes]

A3
Quote: "We searched Medline, Embase, and Cochrane Trials databases for studies comparing open with endosurgical CDH repair. Non-neonatal series and reports without comparison groups were excluded. References from eligible studies were also hand searched."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases plus reference hand-searching were used.
[Yes]

A4
Quote: "References from eligible studies were also hand searched."
Reasoning: Searching of references implies inclusion of grey literature.
[Yes]

A5
Quote: "Two independent reviewers reviewed all studies in abstract form. Exclusions were only made at this point if it was absolutely clear that the above criteria were met."
Reasoning: Excluded studies were referenced at the abstract stage.
[Yes]

A6
Quote: "Analyzing the demographic data in each study, there were no statistically significant differences in proportion of male sex, mean birth weight, proportion of left-sided CDH, or proportion of cases with significant associated anomalies between open and endosurgical groups."
Reasoning: Relevant characteristics of the included studies were provided in aggregate form.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "No randomized controlled trials were found. The 3 included studies compare endosurgical thoracoscopic and open CDH repairs performed at the same institutions. All are limited by their methodology, primarily due to the control (open surgery) groups being historical; there is therefore significant risk of case selection and performance bias."
Reasoning: The scientific quality of included studies was assessed and documented.
[Yes]

Quote: "We restricted our study to neonatal CDH repair because it is in this newborn population that labile cardiopulmonary physiology predominates and threatens survival; hence it is this group whose choice of surgical approach may have greatest impact on mortality."
Reasoning: The limitations of included studies were considered when formulating the conclusions.
[Yes]

Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed, only a systematic review.

Reasoning: No assessment of publication bias was reported, likely because there were only 3 included studies.
[No]

Reasoning: Sources of support for the systematic review and included studies were not clearly reported.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Neonatal Endosurgical Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Repair A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Reasoning: A structured abstract with labeled sections of background, methods, results, and conclusions is provided.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Historically a surgical emergency, neonatal CDH repair is now deferred pending stabilization of characteristically labile cardiopulmonary physiology. Usually accomplished via laparotomy, surgical repair may acutely worsen lung function; conversely, by reducing the visceral hernia, surgery might improve it."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is known.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "We searched Medline, Embase, and Cochrane Trials databases for studies comparing open with endosurgical CDH repair."
Reasoning: The research question specifies the population (neonatal CDH) and intervention (endosurgical vs open repair).
[Yes]

P5
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6
Quote: "Studies were eligible for inclusion in the review and meta-analysis if they directly compared open and endosurgical CDH repair in the newborn infant and included outcome data regarding survival, CDH recurrence, prosthetic patch use, and operative time."
Reasoning: Study eligibility criteria are specified.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "We searched Medline, Embase, and Cochrane Trials databases for studies comparing open with endosurgical CDH repair."
Reasoning: Electronic databases searched are described but dates of coverage and last search date are not provided.
[No]

Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented for any of the databases.
[No]

Quote: "Two independent reviewers reviewed all studies in abstract form. Exclusions were only made at this point if it was absolutely clear that the above criteria were met. [Yes]

Reasoning: The data collection process is described.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "Analyzing the demographic data in each study, there were no statistically significant differences in proportion of male sex, mean birth weight, proportion of left-sided CDH, or proportion of cases with significant associated anomalies between open and endosurgical groups."
Reasoning: Demographic variables for which data were sought are defined.
[Yes]

P12
Quote: "No randomized controlled trials were found. The 3 included studies compare endosurgical thoracoscopic and open CDH repairs performed at the same institutions. All are limited by their methodology, primarily due to the control (open surgery) groups being historical; there is therefore significant risk of case selection and performance bias."
Reasoning: Risk of bias in individual studies was assessed.
[Yes]

P13
Quotes: "Meta-analysis reveals that recurrence was higher (RR: 3.21 [1.11, 9.29], P = 0.03) and operative time was longer (WMD: 50.38 minutes [31.79, 68.97], P < 0.0001) in the endosurgical group."
Reasoning: Risk ratio and weighted mean difference are stated as the principal summary measures.
[Yes]

Reasoning: No meta-analysis methods are described as this was a systematic review without meta-analysis.
[NA]

Reasoning: Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.
[NA]

Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

Quote: "No randomized controlled trials were found. The 3 included studies compare endosurgical thoracoscopic and open CDH repairs performed at the same institutions. Reasoning: Risk of bias for each included study is presented.

Reasoning: Results for individual studies are not presented, only the pooled meta-analysis results.

Reasoning: Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.
[NA]

P23
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

Quote: "This meta-analysis illustrates that thoracoscopic neonatal CDH repair is currently associated with higher CDH recurrence risk and longer operative times compared with open CDH repair."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "We restricted our study to neonatal CDH repair because it is in this newborn population that labile cardiopulmonary physiology predominates and threatens survival; hence it is this group whose choice of surgical approach may have greatest impact on mortality."
Reasoning: Limitations of the included studies are discussed.

llm_message:
Here is the assessment of the systematic review using AMSTAR and PRISMA:

A1
Quote: "The aim of the study was to review evidence-based data regarding the use of antibiotics for the treatment of appendicitis in children."
Reasoning: The research question was established a priori.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "We conducted a literature search using "appendicitis" combined with "antibiotics" with children as the target patient population. Studies were selected based on relevance for the following questions:"
Reasoning: Study selection was described but data extraction process and consensus procedure were not mentioned.
[No]

A3
Quotes: "PubMed and other databases of the English literature (up to August 2009) were analyzed. The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects, and the HTA Database were used as well. Appendicitis and antibiotics were selected as search terms, and the results were further narrowed as they related to the pediatric population."
Reasoning: At least two databases were searched and key terms were provided, but years of coverage, full search strategy, and supplemental strategies were not described comprehensively.
[No]

A4
Reasoning: Inclusion of grey literature was not mentioned.
[No]

A5
Reasoning: A list of included and excluded studies was not provided.
[No]

A6
Quotes: "126 studies were selected and reviewed. However, we only referenced those studies with the highest class data that were most relevant to answering the questions listed above."
Reasoning: Some characteristics of included studies were mentioned but not provided in an aggregated form like a table.
[No]

A7
Quotes: "Once guidelines were established, grades were assigned based on the strength of the studies supporting the recommendation [3]. Overall, 126 studies were selected and reviewed. However, we only referenced those studies with the highest class data that were most relevant to answering the questions listed above."

"2 RCTs and 4 OCSs reported the patients' mean age [10,14,19-22], and 5 studies presented the age range [10,14,19,20,22]. However, none of these studies reported the patients' age as mean±SD, resulting in no eligibility for further meta-analysis."

A critical review checklist of the Dutch Cochrane Center was used to appraise the RCTs [dcc.cochrane.org, last updated Jul 2010]. This checklist was also considered valid for the assessment of the quality of non-RCTs."
Reasoning: The methodological quality of included studies was independently assessed using a standardized checklist.
[Yes]

A8

Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2
Quote: "Objective: The aim of this study was to explore the efficacy and potential advantages of lymphatic sparing laparoscopic varicocelectomy (LSV) over lymphatic non-sparing laparoscopic varicocelectomy (LNSV) in children and adolescents. Methods: A search was made for studies published up until 31 August 2010 using the terms "lymphatic sparing varicocelectomy", "laparoscopy", "adolescent" and "children" in the Medline, Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases. Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and observational clinical studies (OCSs) comparing LSV and LNSV were included. A systematic review and meta-analysis was performed using odds ratios (ORs) for dichotomous variables."

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to review the currently available data comparing laparoscopic portoenterostomy (LPE) versus open portoenterostomy (OPE) for the treatment of biliary atresia (BA)."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Two investigators independently assessed selected studies and extracted data for meta-analysis." "All studies were single-center cohort studies and both cohorts, open versus laparoscopic, in all studies were performed by the same institution and same surgical teams."
Reasoning: At least two independent investigators selected studies and extracted data.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "We conducted a systematic search of the online databases, including Medline, Ovid, Elsevier, Google Scholar Embase, Cohrane library, for studies published between 1990 and 2014 with no limits for publication language, place of study origin and sample size of the studies." "The following Medical Subject Headings were used: ''comparative study,'' ''laparoscopy,'' ''biliary atresia,'' ''surgery,'' and ''treatment outcome''."
Reasoning: Multiple databases were searched using relevant keywords.
[Yes]

A4
Quote: "No limits for publication language, place of study origin and sample size of the studies."
Reasoning: The authors searched for reports regardless of publication type.
[Yes]

A5
Quote: "The process of study screening is showed in Fig. 1, through which, eleven studies assessing LPE versus OPE were considered suitable for meta-analysis, including two prospective [21, 22] and nine retrospective [13, 23–30] studies."
Reasoning: A list of included studies was provided.
[No] - No list of excluded studies was provided.

A6
Quote: "The characteristics of these 11 studies are listed in Table 1."
Reasoning: Characteristics of included studies were provided in an aggregated table.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "The Newcastle–Ottawa scale (NOS) for assessing the quality of included studies and is demonstrated in Table 3."
Reasoning: The quality of included studies was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa scale.
[Yes]

A8
Quote: "Without doubt, the number of the articles in this meta-analysis is small, which may cause the low survival rate in LPE patients. Possibly, caution should be applied and more cohort studies are needed before we reached a definite decision about long-term result between laparoscopic Kasai and open Kasai."
Reasoning: The authors considered the low quality of evidence in their conclusions.
[Yes]

A9
Quotes: "Statistical analysis was performed using the odds ratio (OR) as the statistic summary. This odds ratio represents the odds of an adverse event occurring in the LPE group compared with the OPE group. Statistical analysis for continuous variables was performed using the mean difference (MD) and as the summary statistic." "The heterogeneity for summary effects was explored using the χ2 test, with significance set at P < 0.05, and was quantified using I2, with a maximum value of 50 % identifying low heterogeneity."
Reasoning: Appropriate statistical methods were used to combine findings and assess heterogeneity.
[Yes]

A10
[NA] - Publication bias was not assessed, likely because there were fewer than 10 studies.

A11
Quote: "None declared."
Reasoning: Conflicts of interest were stated for the systematic review but not for the included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Laparoscopic portoenterostomy versus open portoenterostomy for the treatment of biliary atresia: a systematic review and meta-analysis of comparative studies"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See the structured abstract on the first page.
Reasoning: A structured abstract with background, methods, results and conclusions is provided.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Open portoenterostomy (OPE) remains the mainstay in treatment of biliary atresia, while during the past several years, the laparoscopic portoenterostomy (LPE) has been widely introduced. However, safety of LPE remains a major concern. Thus, we conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to review the currently available data comparing LPE and OPE."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is known.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to review the currently available data comparing laparoscopic portoenterostomy (LPE) versus open portoenterostomy (OPE) for the treatment of biliary atresia (BA)."
Reasoning: The review question specifies the population, interventions and outcomes of interest.
[Yes]

P5
[No] - No mention of a review protocol or registration.

P6
Quote: "Exclusion criteria from the study were determined as follows: (1) review articles or meeting abstract; (2) no necessary outcomes (specified later) were reported or extrapolate the interesting data or impossible to calculate by the published results; (3) study focusing on pure robotic-assisted procedures."
Reasoning: Eligibility criteria are specified.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "We conducted a systematic search of the online databases, including Medline, Ovid, Elsevier, Google Scholar Embase, Cohrane library, for studies published between 1990 and 2014 with no limits for publication language, place of study origin and sample size of the studies."
Reasoning: Information sources and date ranges are described.
[Yes]

P8
Quote: "The following Medical Subject Headings were used: ''comparative study,'' ''laparoscopy,'' ''biliary atresia,'' ''surgery,'' and ''treatment outcome''."
Reasoning: The search terms are provided but the full search strategy for each database is not presented.
[No]

P9
Quote: "The process of study screening is showed in Fig. 1, through which, eleven studies assessing LPE versus OPE were considered suitable for meta-analysis, including two prospective [21, 22] and nine retrospective [13, 23–30] studies."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Two investigators independently assessed selected studies and extracted data for meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The data extraction process is described.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "The risk of bias was assessed using the Newcastle–Ottawa scale (NOS) for assessing the quality of included studies and is demonstrated in Table 3."
Reasoning: The data items (quality assessment using NOS) are described.
[Yes]

P12
Quote: "The Newcastle–Ottawa scale (NOS) for assessing the quality of included studies and is demonstrated in Table 3."
Reasoning: The Newcastle-Ottawa scale was used to assess risk of bias in individual studies.
[Yes]

P13
Quote: "Statistical analysis was performed using the odds ratio (OR) as the statistic summary. This odds ratio represents the odds of an adverse event occurring in the LPE group compared with the OPE group. Statistical analysis for continuous variables was performed using the mean difference (MD) and as the summary statistic."
Reasoning: The summary measures of odds ratio and mean difference are specified.
[Yes]

P14
Quote: "The heterogeneity for summary effects was explored using the χ2 test, with significance set at P < 0.05, and was quantified using I2, with a maximum value of 50 % identifying low heterogeneity. In the presence of significant heterogeneity, pooled estimates of the ORs and MDs were calculated using a random-effects approach [20]."
Reasoning: Methods for assessing heterogeneity and combining results are described.
[Yes]

P15
[NA] - No assessment of risk of bias across studies was mentioned, likely because there were too few studies.

P16
[NA] - No additional analyses were mentioned.

P17
Quote: "The process of study screening is showed in Fig. 1, through which, eleven studies assessing LPE versus OPE were considered suitable for meta-analysis, including two prospective [21, 22] and nine retrospective [13, 23–30] studies."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened and included is provided, with reasons, in a flow diagram (Fig. 1).
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "The characteristics of these 11 studies are listed in Table 1."
Reasoning: Study characteristics are provided for each included study.
[Yes]

P19
Quote: "The Newcastle–Ottawa scale (NOS) for assessing the quality of included studies and is demonstrated in Table 3."
Reasoning: Risk of bias assessments for each study are presented.
[Yes]

P20
Quotes: See Tables 1 and 2 and Figures 2-8.
Reasoning: For each study and outcome, summary data for each group and effect estimates with confidence intervals are provided, including forest plots.
[Yes]

P21
[NA] - No meta-analysis results are presented, as the analyses appear to be subgroup comparisons rather than overall meta-analyses.

P22
[NA] - No assessment of risk of bias across studies was mentioned.

P23
[NA] - No additional analyses were mentioned.

P24
Quote: "The clinical impression is that BA patients who underwent LPE might have better early outcomes than patients in the OPE group. But in this meta-analysis, we found the difference was not statistically significant so LPE group was not better than OPE group in short-term outcomes like intraoperative blood loss, early clearance of jaundice and cholangitis."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "There are limitations to this review which must be considered. First, there have only been a small number of studies comparing LPE with OPE in the treatment of biliary atresia, with a lack of randomized trials. Second, the sample size of some selected studies is small so that the statistical power to detect the difference in the outcomes is limited."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Further improvements in the laparoscopic portoenterostomy are needed before its widespread application can be recommended."
Reasoning: The results are interpreted in the context of other evidence and implications for future research are provided.
[Yes]

P27
[No] - Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.

Quote: "Laparoscopic portoenterostomy versus open portoenterostomy for the treatment of biliary atresia: a systematic review and meta-analysis of comparative studies"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See the structured abstract on the first page.
Reasoning: A structured abstract with background, methods, results and conclusions is provided.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Open portoenterostomy (OPE) remains the mainstay in treatment of biliary atresia, while during the past several years, the laparoscopic portoenterostomy (LPE) has been widely introduced. However, safety of LPE remains a major concern. Thus, we conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to review the currently available data comparing LPE and OPE."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is known.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to review the currently available data comparing laparoscopic portoenterostomy (LPE) versus open portoenterostomy (OPE) for the treatment of biliary atresia (BA)."
Reasoning: The review question specifies the population, interventions and outcomes of interest.
[Yes]

P5
[No] - No mention of a review protocol or registration.

P6
Quote: "Exclusion criteria from the study were determined as follows: (1) review articles or meeting abstract; (2) no necessary outcomes (specified later) were reported or extrapolate the interesting data or impossible to calculate by the published results; (3) study focusing on pure robotic-assisted procedures."
Reasoning: Eligibility criteria are specified.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "We conducted a systematic search of the online databases, including Medline, Ovid, Elsevier, Google Scholar Embase, Cohrane library, for studies published between 1990 and 2014 with no limits for publication language, place of study origin and sample size of the studies."
Reasoning: Information sources and date ranges are described.
[Yes]

P8
Quote: "The following Medical Subject Headings were used: ''comparative study,'' ''laparoscopy,'' ''biliary atresia,'' ''surgery,'' and ''treatment outcome''."
Reasoning: The search terms are provided but the full search strategy for each database is not presented.
[No]

P9
Quote: "The process of study screening is showed in Fig. 1, through which, eleven studies assessing LPE versus OPE were considered suitable for meta-analysis, including two prospective [21, 22] and nine retrospective [13, 23–30] studies."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Two investigators independently assessed selected studies and extracted data for meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The data extraction process is described.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "The risk of bias was assessed using the Newcastle–Ottawa scale (NOS) for assessing the quality of included studies and is demonstrated in Table 3."
Reasoning: The data items (quality assessment using NOS) are described.
[Yes]

P12
Quote: "The Newcastle–Ottawa scale (NOS) for assessing the quality of included studies and is demonstrated in Table 3."
Reasoning: The Newcastle-Ottawa scale was used to assess risk of bias in individual studies.
[Yes]

P13
Quote: "Statistical analysis was performed using the odds ratio (OR) as the statistic summary. This odds ratio represents the odds of an adverse event occurring in the LPE group compared with the OPE group. Statistical analysis for continuous variables was performed using the mean difference (MD) and as the summary statistic."
Reasoning: The summary measures of odds ratio and mean difference are specified.
[Yes]

P14
Quote: "The heterogeneity for summary effects was explored using the χ2 test, with significance set at P < 0.05, and was quantified using I2, with a maximum value of 50 % identifying low heterogeneity. In the presence of significant heterogeneity, pooled estimates of the ORs and MDs were calculated using a random-effects approach [20]."
Reasoning: Methods for assessing heterogeneity and combining results are described.
[Yes]

P15
[NA] - No assessment of risk of bias across studies was mentioned, likely because there were too few studies.

P16
[NA] - No additional analyses were mentioned.

P17
Quote: "The process of study screening is showed in Fig. 1, through which, eleven studies assessing LPE versus OPE were considered suitable for meta-analysis, including two prospective [21, 22] and nine retrospective [13, 23–30] studies."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened and included is provided, with reasons, in a flow diagram (Fig. 1).
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "The characteristics of these 11 studies are listed in Table 1."
Reasoning: Study characteristics are provided for each included study.
[Yes]

P19
Quote: "The Newcastle–Ottawa scale (NOS) for assessing the quality of included studies and is demonstrated in Table 3."
Reasoning: Risk of bias assessments for each study are presented.
[Yes]

P20
Quotes: See Tables 1 and 2 and Figures 2-8.
Reasoning: For each study and outcome, summary data for each group and effect estimates with confidence intervals are provided, including forest plots.
[Yes]

P21
[NA] - No meta-analysis results are presented, as the analyses appear to be subgroup comparisons rather than overall meta-analyses.

P22
[NA] - No assessment of risk of bias across studies was mentioned.

P23
[NA] - No additional analyses were mentioned.

P24
Quote: "The clinical impression is that BA patients who underwent LPE might have better early outcomes than patients in the OPE group. But in this meta-analysis, we found the difference was not statistically significant so LPE group was not better than OPE group in short-term outcomes like intraoperative blood loss, early clearance of jaundice and cholangitis."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "There are limitations to this review which must be considered. First, there have only been a small number of studies comparing LPE with OPE in the treatment of biliary atresia, with a lack of randomized trials. Second, the sample size of some selected studies is small so that the statistical power to detect the difference in the outcomes is limited."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Further improvements in the laparoscopic portoenterostomy are needed before its widespread application can be recommended."
Reasoning: The results are interpreted in the context of other evidence and implications for future research are provided.
[Yes]

P27
[No] - Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "We conducted a structured search of Medline, Embase, trial registries, and the gray literature. We included studies that compared outcomes for FG and GJ in children with neurologic impairment."
The authors conducted a structured search based on pre-defined inclusion criteria.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Title and abstract screening was completed independently and in duplicate by two of the authors (MHL, ACS). Disagreements resulted in automatic inclusion. Studies were included if participants were less than 18 years of age, had neurologic impairments, and a clinical history or investigation suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux."
Study selection was done in duplicate by two authors.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "We conducted a systematic search of Medline, Embase, and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials for studies of participants with gastroesophageal reflux treated with FG or GJ. A medical librarian helped us develop queries for each database to identify studies that mentioned fundoplication and gastrojejunostomy."
"We also performed manual searches of relevant journals, conference proceedings [13], theses and dissertations [14–16], and other trial registries [17–20]."
The authors searched multiple databases, trial registries, and other sources.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: "We included studies that compared outcomes for FG and GJ in children with neurologic impairment."
"We also performed manual searches of relevant journals, conference proceedings [13], theses and dissertations [14–16], and other trial registries [17–20]."
The authors searched for and included grey literature like theses and conference proceedings.
[Yes]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "The first article that was excluded following full text review was a qualitative study that explored quality-of-life issues among 8 children with neurologic impairment who underwent fundoplication and 8 who underwent gastrostomy without fundoplication. This was a trend obtained from all 16 participants, but no attempt was made to compare outcomes between these two groups."
The authors provided the reason for excluding one study, but did not provide a full list of included and excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "The three included studies reported on children and adolescents with gastroesophageal reflux and various forms of neurologic impairment. Some had progressive conditions but the majority had nonprogressive impairments (predominantly cerebral palsy and/or seizure disorders)."
The authors provided aggregate characteristics of the included studies.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "None of the studies reached the gold standard cut-off on MINORS of 19.8 out of 24 (Table 2). All three used retrospective data and reported important baseline differences between treatment groups."
The authors used a validated tool (MINORS) to assess study quality and reported the scores.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quote: "Researchers should consider establishing large, comparative registries using observational data rather than dedicating significant resources to randomized controlled trials. Children with neurologic impairments and gastroesophageal reflux are medically complex, and many parents and clinicians are hesitant to proceed with randomization [35]."
The authors considered the low quality of evidence in their conclusions and suggested observational registries rather than trials.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
The authors did not perform a meta-analysis or quantitatively combine study findings.
[NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
The authors did not assess publication bias, which is appropriate since they did not perform a meta-analysis.
[NA]  

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quote: "© 2015 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved."
The source of funding for the systematic review was reported, but sources of support for the individual studies were not reported.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Fundoplication and gastrostomy versus percutaneous gastrojejunostomy for gastroesophageal reflux in children with neurologic impairment: A systematic review and meta-analysis"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
The abstract has labeled sections covering background, methods, results, conclusions and other PRISMA-recommended elements.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Children with neurologic impairment often fail medical management of gastroesophageal reflux [1–4]. Even with maximal therapy, many patients continue to experience symptoms and complications."
The introduction explains the rationale for the review in the context of limitations of current therapies.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The radiologic option is a percutaneous gastrojejunostomy (GJ) [8]. This option is less invasive, requires less recovery time, and can be removed if symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux improve."
The introduction outlines the objective of comparing GJ to fundoplication.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
A review protocol or registration number was not mentioned.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "We included studies that compared outcomes for FG and GJ in children with neurologic impairment. We included the results from observational studies, graded the best available evidence, and focused on patient-important outcomes, including mortality, pneumonia, complications, and quality of life."
The eligibility criteria in terms of population, interventions, comparators, and outcomes are specified.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "We conducted a systematic search of Medline, Embase, and Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials for studies of participants with gastroesophageal reflux treated with FG or GJ. A medical librarian helped us develop queries for each database to identify studies that mentioned fundoplication and gastrojejunostomy. These concepts were expanded to include synonyms and related terms. The search syntax and nomenclature were missed due to variation in database tax and nomenclature. We also performed manual searches of relevant journals, conference proceedings [13], theses and dissertations [14–16], and other trial registries [17–20]."
The databases searched and date last searched (February 2014) are reported.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
The full search strategies are not provided.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Title and abstract screening was completed independently and in duplicate by two of the authors (MHL, ACS). Disagreements resulted in automatic inclusion. Studies were included if participants were less than 18 years of age, had neurologic impairments, and a clinical history or investigation suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux."
The study selection process is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
The data collection process is not described in detail.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quote: "We included all patient-important outcomes in our analysis. Outcomes deemed critical a priori were quality of life, all-cause mortality, and pneumonia. During the course of our review, we decided to add major complications as a critical outcome. These were defined as adverse events other than pneumonia that resulted in surgery or prolonged hospitalization."
The outcomes for which data were sought are defined.
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "Risk of bias for individual studies was assessed in duplicate using the methodological index for nonrandomized studies (MINORS). Differences between reviewers were resolved through consensus."
The use of the MINORS tool to assess risk of bias is described.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Summary measures are not mentioned, as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "An overview of the search strategy and results is depicted in Fig. 1. We identified a total of 556 participants from three retrospective observational studies that compared outcomes for FG (n = 431) and GJ (n = 125) [30–32]."
A flow diagram of study selection is provided in Figure 1.
[Yes]  

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "The three included studies reported on children and adolescents with gastroesophageal reflux and various forms of neurologic impairment. Some had progressive conditions but the majority had nonprogressive impairments (predominantly cerebral palsy and/or seizure disorders)."
Characteristics of the included studies are reported in aggregate.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quote: "None of the studies reached the gold standard cut-off on MINORS of 19.8 out of 24 (Table 2). All three used retrospective data and reported important baseline differences between treatment groups."
Results of the risk of bias assessment using MINORS are reported.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Simple summary data and effect estimates for individual studies are not provided, only pooled results.
[No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
No meta-analysis was performed. 
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "The evidence supporting the use of FG versus GJ for refractory gastroesophageal reflux in children with neurologic impairment is very low. Studies reported to date have been complicated by baseline differences between treatment groups and imprecision due to small numbers."
"We found that the rates of mortality and pneumonia following either procedure were similar, and that most causes of death do not appear to be related to complications of treatment or ongoing gastroesophageal reflux."
The main findings and their strength are summarized.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "The risk of major complications appears to be higher with FG, whereas the risk of minor complications appears to be higher with GJ. Neither of these trends was statistically significant and should be interpreted with caution. Heterogeneity between publications has only been assessed in studies that compared open FG with GJ."
Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "The evidence supporting the use of FG versus GJ for refractory gastroesophageal reflux in children with neurologic impairment is very low. Studies reported to date have been complicated by baseline differences between treatment groups and imprecision due to small numbers."
The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quote: "© 2015 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved."
The source of funding for the systematic review is reported, but sources of support for the individual studies are not mentioned.
[No]

llm_message:
A1 - Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "This systematic review was conducted according to the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses) statement."
Reasoning: The review mentions following the PRISMA statement, suggesting an a priori design.
[Yes]

A2 - Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Titles and abstracts of all retrieved records, and subsequently full-text articles (that were possibly relevant or where relevance appeared potentially relevant), were examined independently by two authors (F.M. and B.B.) according to the PRISMA statement."
Reasoning: Study selection and data extraction was done independently by two authors.
[Yes]

A3 - Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "PubMed, Embase and The Cochrane Library (issue 3, 2011) were systematically searched according to the search strategy. The following data were extracted separately by the same two authors for all studies meeting the inclusion criteria: study population characteristics, study design, surgical method, duration of follow-up, number of participating subjects and events for each of the study outcomes of interest."
Reasoning: At least 3 databases were searched and study characteristics were extracted.
[Yes]

A4 - Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Reasoning: No mention of including or excluding studies based on publication status or grey literature.
[No]

A5 - Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "In total, 939 potentially relevant publications were identified. After title/abstract and full-text screening we selected eight original studies that met the inclusion and exclusion criteria"
Reasoning: The number of included studies is provided but no list of excluded studies is given.
[No]

A6 - Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations."
Reasoning: The review states that study characteristics were extracted for included studies.
[Yes]

A7 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: "Using predefined criteria, two authors (F.M. and B.B) included studies and assessed their methodological quality and risk of bias according to the PRISMA statement and the Cochrane Collaboration's tool for risk of bias assessment."
Reasoning: The methodological quality and risk of bias of included studies was assessed using predefined criteria.
[Yes]

A8 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Reasoning: The review does not appear to consider the quality assessment in the conclusions.
[No]

A9 - Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quote: "The random-effects model was chosen to take into account suspected heterogeneity caused by differences in study design and patient population, as it generates a more conservative estimate than an analysis using the fixed-effects model."
Reasoning: A random-effects meta-analysis model was appropriately used to account for heterogeneity.
[Yes]

A10 - Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quote: "To identify possible selection bias funnel plots were constructed. The funnel plot on dysphagia indicated a lack of larger studies in favor of a partial fundoplication, but it is unclear whether this is due to publication bias or other mechanisms."
Reasoning: Funnel plots were used to assess publication bias.
[Yes]

A11 - Was the conflict of interest included?
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review and included studies are not reported.
[No]

P1 - Title
Quote: "Complete Versus Partial Fundoplication in Children with Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease: Results of a Systematic Review and Meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2 - Abstract/Structured summary
Quotes: "Abstract Complete fundoplication (Nissen) has long been accepted as the gold standard surgical procedure in children with therapy-resistant gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD); however, increasingly more evidence has become available for partial fundoplication as an alternative. The aim of this study was to perform a systematic review and meta-analysis comparing complete versus partial fundoplication in children with therapy-resistant GERD."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, methods, results and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3 - Introduction/Rationale
Quote: "Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in children is defined as pathologic reflux causing symptoms. Antireflux surgery, by means of (laparoscopic) fundoplication is reserved for pediatric patients with severe GERD resistant to medical treatment."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of GERD in children.
[Yes]

P4 - Introduction/Objectives
Quote: "The aim of this study was to perform a systematic review and meta-analysis comparing complete versus partial fundoplication in children with therapy-resistant GERD."
Reasoning: An explicit aim is provided referencing the PICO elements.
[Yes]

P5 - Methods/Protocol and registration
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6 - Methods/Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Each article was independently assessed for eligibility using the following predefined criteria: Study population: neurologically normal (NN) and impaired (NI) infants and children (0–18 years) undergoing primary antireflux surgery for GERD, irrespective of prior or concomitant gastrostomy placement."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria are specified in terms of population, intervention and study design.
[Yes]

P7 - Methods/Information sources
Quote: "This systematic review was conducted according to the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses) statement. Using predefined search terms PubMed (1960 to 2011), EMBASE (from 1980 to 2011), and the Cochrane Library (issue 3, 2011) were systematically searched until March 16, 2011 to identify all articles comparing complete to partial fundoplication in children with GERD."
Reasoning: PubMed, Embase and Cochrane Library were searched up to March 2011.
[Yes]

P8 - Methods/Search
Quote: "Using predefined search terms PubMed (1960 to 2011), EMBASE (from 1980 to 2011), and the Cochrane Library (issue 3, 2011) were systematically searched until March 16, 2011 to identify all articles comparing complete to partial fundoplication in children with GERD. For PubMed, the following search terms were used: (child*[Title/Abstract] OR infant*[Title/Abstract] OR adolescent*[Title/Abstract] OR pediatric*[Title/Abstract] AND (nissen[Title/Abstract] OR toupet[Title/Abstract] OR thal[Title/Abstract] OR antireflux*[Title/Abstract] OR fundoplication[Title/Abstract] OR fundoplication[MeSH Terms]) AND gastroesophageal reflux[MeSH Terms]. The same search strategy was used in EMBASE (replacing "[Title/Abstract]" by; "ti,ab" and "[MeSH Terms]" by/exp)."
Reasoning: The full search strategy is provided for PubMed and adapted for other databases.
[Yes]

P9 - Methods/Study selection
Quote: "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described in the flow diagram (Fig. 1).
[Yes]

P10 - Methods/Data collection process
Quote: "Titles and abstracts of all retrieved records, and subsequently full-text articles (that were possibly relevant or where relevance appeared potentially relevant), were examined independently by two authors (F.M. and B.B.) according to the PRISMA statement."
Reasoning: Data extraction was done independently by two authors.
[Yes]

P11 - Methods/Data items
Reasoning: The specific data items sought are not defined, although some study characteristics that were extracted are mentioned.
[No]

P12 - Methods/Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "Using predefined criteria, two authors (F.M. and B.B) included studies and assessed their methodological quality and risk of bias according to the PRISMA statement and the Cochrane Collaboration's tool for risk of bias assessment."
Reasoning: The risk of bias was assessed using the Cochrane tool.
[Yes]

P13 - Methods/Summary measures
Quote: "Results were presented as risk ratios (RRs) with 95 % confidence intervals (CI)."
Reasoning: Risk ratios were used as the summary measure.
[Yes]

P14 - Methods/Synthesis of results
Quote: "Data were pooled using the Mantel–Haenszel random-effects meta-analysis model. The random-effects model was chosen to take into account suspected heterogeneity caused by differences in study design and patient population, as it generates a more conservative estimate than an analysis using the fixed-effects model."
Reasoning: A random-effects meta-analysis was performed.
[Yes]

P15 - Methods/Risk of bias across studies
Quote: "To identify possible selection bias funnel plots were constructed."
Reasoning: Funnel plots were used to assess risk of bias across studies.
[Yes]

P16 - Methods/Additional analyses
Quote: "Subgroup analysis was performed to compare specific types of surgical techniques. Surgical techniques of interest were complete posterior (Nissen), partial posterior (Toupet), and partial anterior (Thal) fundoplication."
Reasoning: Subgroup analyses were performed by surgical technique.
[Yes]

P17 - Results/Study selection
Quote: "In total, 939 potentially relevant publications were identified. After title/abstract and full-text screening we selected eight original studies that met the inclusion and exclusion criteria"
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included are reported in the flow diagram (Fig. 1).
[Yes]

P18 - Results/Study characteristics
Quote: "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations."
Reasoning: Study characteristics are provided in Table 1.
[Yes]

P19 - Results/Risk of bias within studies
Reasoning: The results of the risk of bias assessment for individual studies are not presented.
[No]

P20 - Results/Results of individual studies
Reasoning: Forest plots showing the results of individual studies for each outcome are not provided.
[No]

P21 - Results/Synthesis of results
Reasoning: This systematic review included a meta-analysis, but the results of each meta-analysis with confidence intervals and measures of consistency are not presented.
[No]

P22 - Results/Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: The results of the funnel plot assessment for publication bias are not shown, although it is mentioned in the discussion.
[No]

P23 - Results/Additional analysis
Reasoning: The results of the subgroup analyses by surgical technique are reported in the text and figures, but no p-values for subgroup differences are provided.
[No]

P24 - Discussion/Summary of evidence
Quote: "Meta-analysis could be performed on all primary outcomes, except for 24-h pH monitoring. None of the studies used standardized reflux questionnaires. Only the absence or presence of reflux symptoms was reported. Short-term (RR 0.64; p=0.28; Fig. 2a) and long-term (RR 0.85; p=0.42; Fig. 2b) subjective reflux control was similar for complete and partial fundoplication."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized for each primary outcome.
[Yes]

P25 - Discussion/Limitations
Quote: "Several different types of fundoplication are performed in pediatric GERD patients. Complete posterior (Nissen) fundoplication (360°) is performed in up to two thirds of children undergoing antireflux surgery. However, it may be associated with a higher risk of postoperative dysphagia compared to a partial fundoplication (<360°)."
Reasoning: Limitations at the review level are discussed, including the variety of fundoplication techniques performed.
[Yes]

P26 - Discussion/Conclusions
Quote: "For many years, Nissen fundoplication was considered the gold standard for treatment of severe GERD in pediatric patients. Recent meta-analyses of several randomized controlled trials (RCTs) on antireflux surgery have suggested, however, that partial fundoplication should be the therapy of first choice in refractory adult GERD patients. Unfortunately, data in the pediatric literature is scarce: several individual retrospective studies and only one RCT have been published comparing complete Nissen to partial Thal fundoplication. Our systematic review and meta-analysis of these studies found similar short- and long-term reflux controls after both complete and partial fundoplication, whereas none of the studies reported differences in experience or learning curves between the two techniques."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide an interpretation of the results in the context of treating pediatric GERD patients.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
A1 - Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "This article aims to systematically review the efficacy of pediatric ARS and its effects on gastroesophageal function tests."
Reasoning: The research objective was stated, but no mention of a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined inclusion criteria.
[No]

A2 - Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Each article was independently assessed for eligibility using the following criteria: study population—infants and children (0–18 years), who underwent ARS; type of intervention—open or laparoscopic Nissen, Thal, or Toupet fundoplication; study design—only prospective study format; study results—operative results reported using symptom questionnaires, or clearly defined reflux symptoms, or GE function tests, both before and after ARS."
Reasoning: Independent eligibility assessment was performed, but no mention of duplicate study selection or data extraction.
[No]

A3 - Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quote: "Three electronic databases (Medline, Embase, and the Cochrane Library) were searched for prospective studies reporting on ARS in children with GERD."
Reasoning: At least 2 databases plus reference checking were searched.
[Yes]

A4 - Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Reasoning: No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5 - Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "In total, 17 eligible studies were identified, reporting on a total of 1,280 children."
Reasoning: The number of included studies was stated, but no list of excluded studies was provided.
[No]

A6 - Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Table 1 Details on included prospective clinical trials on ARS in children"
Reasoning: Characteristics of the included studies were provided in an aggregated table.
[Yes]

A7 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "The overall methodological quality was generally poor. All potential threats to validity are summarized in Table 2."
Reasoning: The methodological quality of included studies was assessed and summarized.
[Yes]

A8 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quote: "Our systematic review further shows that the quality of life has been highly underexposed in the evaluation of pediatric ARS, even though validated QoL questionnaires are available for different age groups and development levels."
Reasoning: The conclusions considered the poor quality of the included studies.
[Yes]

A9 - Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Reasoning: This was a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so no combining of study findings was performed.
[NA]

A10 - Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed, likely because there were fewer than 10 included studies.
[NA]

A11 - Was the conflict of interest included?
Reasoning: The article disclosed funding sources for the systematic review, but not for each included study.
[No]

P1 - Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quote: "The Effects and Efficacy of Antireflux Surgery in Children with Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease: A Systematic Review"
Reasoning: The title identified the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2 - Abstract: Structured summary of the systematic review
Quote: The abstract contains labeled sections for Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion.
Reasoning: The abstract was structured with the required sections.
[Yes]

P3 - Introduction: Rationale for the review
Quote: "This study aims to systematically review the efficacy of pediatric ARS and its effects on gastroesophageal function tests. This is the first systematic review comprising only prospective, longitudinal studies, minimizing the risk of bias."
Reasoning: The rationale for conducting the systematic review was described in the context of what is known.
[Yes]

P4 - Introduction: Objectives
Quote: "This article aims to systematically review the efficacy of pediatric ARS and its effects on gastroesophageal function tests."
Reasoning: The research objectives were explicitly stated.
[Yes]

P5 - Methods: Protocol and registration
Reasoning: No review protocol or registration number was mentioned.
[No]

P6 - Methods: Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Each article was independently assessed for eligibility using the following criteria: study population—infants and children (0–18 years), who underwent ARS; type of intervention—open or laparoscopic Nissen, Thal, or Toupet fundoplication; study design—only prospective study format; study results—operative results reported using symptom questionnaires, or clearly defined reflux symptoms, or GE function tests, both before and after ARS."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria were specified.
[Yes]

P7 - Methods: Information sources
Quote: "Three electronic databases (Medline, Embase, and the Cochrane Library) were searched for prospective studies reporting on ARS in children with GERD."
Reasoning: The information sources searched were described.
[Yes]

P8 - Methods: Search
Quote: "The same search strategy was used in EMBASE (replacing "[TIAB]" by ":ti,ab"). In addition, the Cochrane library was manually searched."
Reasoning: The full search strategy for one database was not presented, only key terms were mentioned.
[No]

P9 - Methods: Study selection
Quote: "Each article was independently assessed for eligibility using the following criteria: study population—infants and children (0–18 years), who underwent ARS; type of intervention—open or laparoscopic Nissen, Thal, or Toupet fundoplication; study design—only prospective study format; study results—operative results reported using symptom questionnaires, or clearly defined reflux symptoms, or GE function tests, both before and after ARS."
Reasoning: The study selection process was described.
[Yes]

P10 - Methods: Data collection process
Quote: "The titles and abstracts of all identified studies were reviewed by two independent authors (WS, MH) according to the MOOSE criteria. Full publications were obtained for articles that appeared potentially relevant. References in these selected articles were also screened for cross-reference."
Reasoning: The data collection process was described, involving review by two independent authors.
[Yes]

P11 - Methods: Data items
Reasoning: The data items extracted were not explicitly defined.
[No]

P12 - Methods: Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "The overall methodological quality was generally poor. All potential threats to validity are summarized in Table 2."
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias were described and summarized.
[Yes]

P13 - Methods: Summary measures
Reasoning: No principal summary measures were specified, as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P14 - Methods: Synthesis of results
Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed, so methods for combining results are not applicable.
[NA]

P15 - Methods: Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence was not assessed.
[NA]

P16 - Methods: Additional analyses
Reasoning: No additional analyses such as sensitivity analysis or meta-regression were mentioned.
[NA]

P17 - Results: Study selection
Quote: "In total, 1,260 articles were identified and screened. Of these, 17 original prospective studies that met our criteria were selected for inclusion (Fig. 1)."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included was reported, with reasons for exclusions in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18 - Results: Study characteristics
Quote: "Table 1 Details on included prospective clinical trials on ARS in children"
Reasoning: The characteristics of each included study were presented in a table.
[Yes]

P19 - Results: Risk of bias within studies
Quote: "The overall methodological quality was generally poor. All potential threats to validity are summarized in Table 2."
Reasoning: The results of the risk of bias assessment were presented.
[Yes]

P20 - Results: Results of individual studies
Quote: "Table 3 Success rate (complete resolution of gastroesophageal reflux symptoms) of ARS in children"
Reasoning: For the main outcome of reflux symptom resolution, results for each individual study were reported in a table.
[Yes]

P21 - Results: Synthesis of results
Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22 - Results: Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.
[NA]

P23 - Results: Additional analysis
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24 - Discussion: Summary of evidence
Quote: "Our systematic review identified more than 1,000 publications after searching the available databases for pediatric ARS. Most of these articles were found to be retrospective studies or case reports. Only 17 prospective, longitudinal studies, using reflux symptom scores and/or GE tests could be identified that described the outcome of ARS in pediatric GERD patients."
Reasoning: The main findings were summarized.
[Yes]

P25 - Discussion: Limitations
Quote: "This indicates that the vast majority of studies on pediatric ARS are of poor quality."
Reasoning: Limitations of the included studies were discussed, but review-level limitations were not mentioned.
[No]

P26 - Discussion: Conclusions
Quote: "In conclusion, ARS in children shows a good overall success rate (median 86%) in terms of complete relief of symptoms. The success rate in NI patients may not be worse compared to NN patients. The outcome of ARS does not seem to be influenced by different surgical techniques, although postoperative dysphagia may occur less after partial fundoplication. The strength of these conclusions is, however, bound by the lack of high-quality prospective studies on pediatric ARS."
Reasoning: The conclusions provided a general interpretation of the results in the context of the evidence.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were not described.
[No]

Quote: "This study aims to systematically review the efficacy of pediatric ARS and its effects on gastroesophageal function tests. This is the first systematic review comprising only prospective, longitudinal studies, minimizing the risk of bias."
Reasoning: The rationale for conducting the systematic review was described in the context of what is known.
[Yes]

P4 - Introduction: Objectives
Quote: "This article aims to systematically review the efficacy of pediatric ARS and its effects on gastroesophageal function tests."
Reasoning: The research objectives were explicitly stated.
[Yes]

P5 - Methods: Protocol and registration
Reasoning: No review protocol or registration number was mentioned.
[No]

P6 - Methods: Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Each article was independently assessed for eligibility using the following criteria: study population—infants and children (0–18 years), who underwent ARS; type of intervention—open or laparoscopic Nissen, Thal, or Toupet fundoplication; study design—only prospective study format; study results—operative results reported using symptom questionnaires, or clearly defined reflux symptoms, or GE function tests, both before and after ARS."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria were specified.
[Yes]

P7 - Methods: Information sources
Quote: "Three electronic databases (Medline, Embase, and the Cochrane Library) were searched for prospective studies reporting on ARS in children with GERD."
Reasoning: The information sources searched were described.
[Yes]

P8 - Methods: Search
Quote: "The same search strategy was used in EMBASE (replacing "[TIAB]" by ":ti,ab"). In addition, the Cochrane library was manually searched."
Reasoning: The full search strategy for one database was not presented, only key terms were mentioned.
[No]

P9 - Methods: Study selection
Quote: "Each article was independently assessed for eligibility using the following criteria: study population—infants and children (0–18 years), who underwent ARS; type of intervention—open or laparoscopic Nissen, Thal, or Toupet fundoplication; study design—only prospective study format; study results—operative results reported using symptom questionnaires, or clearly defined reflux symptoms, or GE function tests, both before and after ARS."
Reasoning: The study selection process was described.
[Yes]

P10 - Methods: Data collection process
Quote: "The titles and abstracts of all identified studies were reviewed by two independent authors (WS, MH) according to the MOOSE criteria. Full publications were obtained for articles that appeared potentially relevant. References in these selected articles were also screened for cross-reference."
Reasoning: The data collection process was described, involving review by two independent authors.
[Yes]

P11 - Methods: Data items
Reasoning: The data items extracted were not explicitly defined.
[No]

P12 - Methods: Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "The overall methodological quality was generally poor. All potential threats to validity are summarized in Table 2."
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias were described and summarized.
[Yes]

P13 - Methods: Summary measures
Reasoning: No principal summary measures were specified, as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P14 - Methods: Synthesis of results
Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed, so methods for combining results are not applicable.
[NA]

P15 - Methods: Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence was not assessed.
[NA]

P16 - Methods: Additional analyses
Reasoning: No additional analyses such as sensitivity analysis or meta-regression were mentioned.
[NA]

P17 - Results: Study selection
Quote: "In total, 1,260 articles were identified and screened. Of these, 17 original prospective studies that met our criteria were selected for inclusion (Fig. 1)."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included was reported, with reasons for exclusions in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18 - Results: Study characteristics
Quote: "Table 1 Details on included prospective clinical trials on ARS in children"
Reasoning: The characteristics of each included study were presented in a table.
[Yes]

P19 - Results: Risk of bias within studies
Quote: "The overall methodological quality was generally poor. All potential threats to validity are summarized in Table 2."
Reasoning: The results of the risk of bias assessment were presented.
[Yes]

P20 - Results: Results of individual studies
Quote: "Table 3 Success rate (complete resolution of gastroesophageal reflux symptoms) of ARS in children"
Reasoning: For the main outcome of reflux symptom resolution, results for each individual study were reported in a table.
[Yes]

P21 - Results: Synthesis of results
Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22 - Results: Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.
[NA]

P23 - Results: Additional analysis
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24 - Discussion: Summary of evidence
Quote: "Our systematic review identified more than 1,000 publications after searching the available databases for pediatric ARS. Most of these articles were found to be retrospective studies or case reports. Only 17 prospective, longitudinal studies, using reflux symptom scores and/or GE tests could be identified that described the outcome of ARS in pediatric GERD patients."
Reasoning: The main findings were summarized.
[Yes]

P25 - Discussion: Limitations
Quote: "This indicates that the vast majority of studies on pediatric ARS are of poor quality."
Reasoning: Limitations of the included studies were discussed, but review-level limitations were not mentioned.
[No]

P26 - Discussion: Conclusions
Quote: "In conclusion, ARS in children shows a good overall success rate (median 86%) in terms of complete relief of symptoms. The success rate in NI patients may not be worse compared to NN patients. The outcome of ARS does not seem to be influenced by different surgical techniques, although postoperative dysphagia may occur less after partial fundoplication. The strength of these conclusions is, however, bound by the lack of high-quality prospective studies on pediatric ARS."
Reasoning: The conclusions provided a general interpretation of the results in the context of the evidence.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were not described.
[No]

A1
Quote: "Purpose: To comprehensively review the available evidences in the literature on the use of laparoscopic pyeloplasty (LP) vs open pyeloplasty (OP) for the repair of ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction in children."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria are clearly stated in the purpose section.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Two reviewers (MH and TQS) independently assessed selected studies, and tabulated data in a predefined data extraction form." and "Data regarding the following factors were considered: Study methodology, participant features, intervention characteristics, definition of complications, and outcome measures."
Reasoning: The authors mention that two reviewers independently assessed studies and extracted data.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "We searched online databases, including Medline (using PubMed as the search engine), Embase, Web of Science, Ovid, and Cochrane, to identify suitable studies until the end of October 2010, without lower date limit." and "After identifying relevant titles, the abstracts of those articles were read to decide if the study was eligible."
Reasoning: The authors searched multiple databases and supplemented the search by reading abstracts to determine eligibility.
[Yes]

A4
Quote: "The "pyeloplasty," "laparoscopy," "ureteropelvic junction obstruction" were used as search terms."
Reasoning: The authors do not explicitly mention searching for reports regardless of publication type or language.
[No]

A5
Reasoning: The authors provide a flowchart (Fig. 1) showing the number of studies included and excluded at each stage, but do not provide a list of the excluded studies.
[No]

A6
Quote: "One RCT, two prospective comparative studies, and six retrospective observational studies were eligible for inclusion criteria and selected for this analysis, comprising 694 cases of LP and 7334 cases of OP. The OP has significantly reduced operative time (weighted mean difference [WMD]=59.00; 95% confidence interval [CI]=41.15 to 76.85; P<0.00001) and higher stent placement rate (OR=3.17 to 11.26; P<0.00001) compared with LP, whereas the duration of hospital stay was shorter in the LP group (WMD=−0.40; 95% CI=−0.77 to −0.03; P=0.03)."
Reasoning: The authors provide aggregate data on the participants, interventions, and outcomes of the included studies.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "Each included article was appraised by two reviewers (MH and TQS), who assessed the methodologic quality of selected studies independently. A critical review checklist of the Dutch Cochrane Centre was used to appraise the RCTs (de.co chrane.org, last updated Jul 2010). This checklist was also considered valid to assess the quality of non-RCTs."
Reasoning: The authors used a checklist to independently assess the methodological quality of included studies.
[Yes]

A8
Reasoning: The authors do not appear to have used the scientific quality of the included studies in formulating their conclusions and recommendations.
[No]

A9
Reasoning: The authors used weighted mean differences and odds ratios to combine findings across studies, which are appropriate methods. However, they do not report assessing heterogeneity of the included studies.
[No]

A10
Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing the likelihood of publication bias.
[No]

Reasoning: The authors describe the funding source for their systematic review in the Acknowledgment section, but do not report the funding sources of the individual included studies.
[No]

Quote: "Purpose: To comprehensively review the available evidences in the literature on the use of laparoscopic pyeloplasty (LP) vs open pyeloplasty (OP) for the repair of ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction in children."
