It is our observation from the literature and our communication with paediatric surgeons worldwide that the PFS is now used in preference to a hand-sewn silo almost universally (where available and affordable) and that many surgeons perform immediate reduction and plastic closure if the defect is small."
The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
"Acknowledgments Niyi Ade-Ajayi is supported by the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) Biomedical Research Centre based at Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust and King's College London."
Sources of funding for the systematic review are described, but sources of support for the included studies are not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "This meta-analysis was designed to evaluate postoperative incidence of HAEC following TERPT procedure."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding duplicate study selection and data extraction.
Reasoning: The authors did not state that at least two people independently selected studies and extracted data.
[No]

A3
Quotes: "PubMed and Medline were searched for all studies that reported cases of patients who had undergone surgical correction of HD on transanal one-stage pull-through operation between 1998 and 2009. The search terms were "one-stage transanal pull-through", "transanal one-stage endorectal pull-through", "one-stage Soave pull-through", "single-stage transanal endorectal pull-through", "primary pull-through", or "Soave procedure"."
Reasoning: At least two databases were searched and key terms were provided, but no supplementary strategies were mentioned.
[No]

A4
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding the inclusion of grey literature.
Reasoning: The authors did not state that they searched for reports regardless of publication type.
[No]

A5
Quote: "Of the 54 published articles worldwide, 27 articles, including 899 patients were identified as reporting entirely TERPT procedure."
Reasoning: A list of included studies was provided in Table 1, but no list of excluded studies was given.
[No]

A6
Quote: "Detailed information was recorded regarding intraoperative details and postoperative complications with particular emphasis on incidence of HAEC."
Reasoning: Some characteristics of the included studies were provided in aggregate form, but more details could have been reported.
[No]

A7
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding an a priori method of assessing study quality.
Reasoning: The authors did not state any methods used to assess the quality of included studies.
[No]

A8
Quote: "Despite many studies, the pathogenesis of HAEC is not fully understood. Various hypotheses regarding the etiology have been postulated. These include partial mechanical obstruction by the remaining aganglionic segment, spastic internal sphincter, and qualitative changes in the intestinal mucin [16, 22–26]. Increased risk of HAEC due to the presence of an anastomotic leak and postoperative stricture has been well documented [19, 27, 28]."
Reasoning: The authors discussed limitations of the included studies in the Discussion, but did not formally assess study quality or consider it when formulating conclusions.
[No]

A9
Quote: "This meta-analysis was designed to evaluate postoperative incidence of HAEC following TERPT procedure."
Reasoning: Methods for combining study findings were not described, as this was not a quantitative meta-analysis.
[NA]

A10
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding assessment of publication bias.
Reasoning: The likelihood of publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding conflict of interest or funding sources.
Reasoning: The authors did not report on conflict of interest or funding sources for the review and included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Systematic review and meta-analysis of enterocolitis after one-stage transanal pull-through procedure for Hirschsprung's disease"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: The abstract is structured with labeled sections for Purpose, Methods, Results, and Conclusions.
Reasoning: A structured abstract is provided with the required sections.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Hirschsprung's disease (HD) is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in children [1]. Since the introduction of HD by Swenson [2], various operative procedures gradually evolved during the decades. Multistage surgery has progressed to open or laparoscopic-assisted one-stage repair. Transanal one-stage pull-through procedure (TERPT) represents the latest development in the concept of the minimal invasive surgery for HD [3–11]."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known about Hirschsprung's disease and its treatment.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "The transanal one-stage pull-through procedure (TERPT) has gained worldwide popularity over open and laparoscopic-assisted one-stage techniques in children with Hirschsprung's disease (HD). It offers the advantages of avoiding laparotomy, laparoscopy, scars, abdominal contamination, and adhesions."
Reasoning: The review questions are stated with reference to the population (children with Hirschsprung's disease), intervention (transanal one-stage pull-through), and outcomes of interest (avoiding laparotomy etc.).
[Yes]

P5
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding a review protocol or registration.
Reasoning: The authors did not indicate if a review protocol exists or provide a registration number.
[No]

P6
Quote: "The search terms were "one-stage transanal pull-through", "transanal one-stage endorectal pull-through", "one-stage Soave pull-through", "single-stage transanal endorectal pull-through", "primary pull-through", or "Soave procedure"."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria in terms of interventions and years considered were reported, but the rationale was not fully explained.
[No]

P7
Quote: "PubMed and Medline were searched for all studies that reported cases of patients who had undergone surgical correction of HD on transanal one-stage pull-through operation between 1998 and 2009."
Reasoning: The information sources and date range were described but the date last searched was not provided.
[No]

P8
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified presenting the full search strategy.
Reasoning: The authors listed the search terms used but did not provide the full search strategy for reproducibility.
[No]

P9
Quote: "All published studies and abstracts presented at various meetings were evaluated."
Reasoning: The study selection process was not described in adequate detail.
[No]

P10
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified describing the data collection process.
Reasoning: The authors did not report the method of data extraction from reports.
[No]

P11
Quote: "Detailed information was recorded regarding the type of study, patient's age and gender, intraoperative details, and postoperative complications with particular emphasis on the incidence and outcome of HAEC."
Reasoning: The data items sought were described but any assumptions and simplifications made were not stated.
[No]

P12
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding assessment of risk of bias in individual studies.
Reasoning: The authors did not describe methods used for assessing risk of bias in the included studies.
[No]

P13
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified stating the principal summary measures.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform a quantitative synthesis so there were no summary measures to report.
[NA]

P14
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified describing methods of combining study results.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform a quantitative synthesis so there were no methods for combining results to describe.
[NA]

P15
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified specifying methods to assess risk of bias across studies.
Reasoning: The authors did not describe any methods used to assess risk of bias across studies that could affect the cumulative evidence.
[No]

P16
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified describing methods of additional analyses.
Reasoning: The authors did not report any additional analyses.
[No]

P17
Quote: "Out of these 54 articles, 27 articles, identified as reporting entirely TERPT without additional laparotomy, laparoscopy or preoperative colostomy, formed the basis of our study (Table 1). Twenty-two articles (81.5%) were from single centers, and 5 (18.5%) were from multicenter studies."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included were reported with reasons, but a flow diagram was not provided.
[No]

P18
Quote: See Table 1 presenting the characteristics of included studies.
Reasoning: For each included study, key characteristics were presented in Table 1 along with citations.
[Yes] 

P19
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified presenting data on risk of bias for each study.
Reasoning: The authors did not assess or report the risk of bias within individual studies.
[No]

P20
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified presenting effect estimates and confidence intervals for each study.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform a quantitative synthesis so there were no effect estimates and confidence intervals to report for individual studies.
[NA]

P21
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified presenting the results of each meta-analysis.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform a quantitative meta-analysis.
[NA]

P22 
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified presenting the results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
Reasoning: The authors did not report assessing the risk of bias across studies.
[No]

P23
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified giving the results of any additional analyses.
Reasoning: The authors did not report any additional analyses.
[No]

P24
Quote: "This systematic review reveals that the incidence of postoperative and recurrent HAEC after TERPT procedure is remarkably lower than incidence rates of HAEC reported after other procedures, confirming TERPT as a safe operation with a low incidence of postoperative HAEC."
Reasoning: The main findings of the review were summarized, including the key outcome of incidence of HAEC after TERPT compared to other procedures.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Prompt diagnosis, rectal washouts, and stoma formation are crucial factors in the prevention of severe morbidity associated with HAEC. Decompression of the bowel must be achieved as soon as possible by placement of a meogastric tube and rectal irrigation. Antibiotic therapy is commenced with broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics in severe cases [21, 43, 44]."
Reasoning: Limitations at the review level were not explicitly discussed, although limitations of the underlying evidence were acknowledged.
[No]

P26
Quote: "In our present review the rate of recurrent episodes of HAEC was 2%. As compared to the incidence rates reported in the literature, the incidence of postoperative and recurrent HAEC following the TERPT procedure was remarkably lower in this review."
Reasoning: The results were discussed in the context of other evidence and the implications for management of Hirschsprung's disease were described.
[Yes]

P27
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified describing funding sources.
Reasoning: The authors did not report sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

Quote: "Despite many studies, the pathogenesis of HAEC is not fully understood. Various hypotheses regarding the etiology have been postulated. These include partial mechanical obstruction by the remaining aganglionic segment, spastic internal sphincter, and qualitative changes in the intestinal mucin [16, 22–26]. Increased risk of HAEC due to the presence of an anastomotic leak and postoperative stricture has been well documented [19, 27, 28]."
Reasoning: The authors discussed limitations of the included studies in the Discussion, but did not formally assess study quality or consider it when formulating conclusions.
[No]

A9
Quote: "This meta-analysis was designed to evaluate postoperative incidence of HAEC following TERPT procedure."
Reasoning: Methods for combining study findings were not described, as this was not a quantitative meta-analysis.
[NA]

A10
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding assessment of publication bias.
Reasoning: The likelihood of publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding conflict of interest or funding sources.
Reasoning: The authors did not report on conflict of interest or funding sources for the review and included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Systematic review and meta-analysis of enterocolitis after one-stage transanal pull-through procedure for Hirschsprung's disease"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: The abstract is structured with labeled sections for Purpose, Methods, Results, and Conclusions.
Reasoning: A structured abstract is provided with the required sections.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Hirschsprung's disease (HD) is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in children [1]. Since the introduction of HD by Swenson [2], various operative procedures gradually evolved during the decades. Multistage surgery has progressed to open or laparoscopic-assisted one-stage repair. Transanal one-stage pull-through procedure (TERPT) represents the latest development in the concept of the minimal invasive surgery for HD [3–11]."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known about Hirschsprung's disease and its treatment.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "The transanal one-stage pull-through procedure (TERPT) has gained worldwide popularity over open and laparoscopic-assisted one-stage techniques in children with Hirschsprung's disease (HD). It offers the advantages of avoiding laparotomy, laparoscopy, scars, abdominal contamination, and adhesions."
Reasoning: The review questions are stated with reference to the population (children with Hirschsprung's disease), intervention (transanal one-stage pull-through), and outcomes of interest (avoiding laparotomy etc.).
[Yes]

P5
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding a review protocol or registration.
Reasoning: The authors did not indicate if a review protocol exists or provide a registration number.
[No]

P6
Quote: "The search terms were "one-stage transanal pull-through", "transanal one-stage endorectal pull-through", "one-stage Soave pull-through", "single-stage transanal endorectal pull-through", "primary pull-through", or "Soave procedure"."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria in terms of interventions and years considered were reported, but the rationale was not fully explained.
[No]

P7
Quote: "PubMed and Medline were searched for all studies that reported cases of patients who had undergone surgical correction of HD on transanal one-stage pull-through operation between 1998 and 2009."
Reasoning: The information sources and date range were described but the date last searched was not provided.
[No]

P8
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified presenting the full search strategy.
Reasoning: The authors listed the search terms used but did not provide the full search strategy for reproducibility.
[No]

P9
Quote: "All published studies and abstracts presented at various meetings were evaluated."
Reasoning: The study selection process was not described in adequate detail.
[No]

P10
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified describing the data collection process.
Reasoning: The authors did not report the method of data extraction from reports.
[No]

P11
Quote: "Detailed information was recorded regarding the type of study, patient's age and gender, intraoperative details, and postoperative complications with particular emphasis on the incidence and outcome of HAEC."
Reasoning: The data items sought were described but any assumptions and simplifications made were not stated.
[No]

P12
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified regarding assessment of risk of bias in individual studies.
Reasoning: The authors did not describe methods used for assessing risk of bias in the included studies.
[No]

P13
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified stating the principal summary measures.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform a quantitative synthesis so there were no summary measures to report.
[NA]

P14
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified describing methods of combining study results.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform a quantitative synthesis so there were no methods for combining results to describe.
[NA]

P15
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified specifying methods to assess risk of bias across studies.
Reasoning: The authors did not describe any methods used to assess risk of bias across studies that could affect the cumulative evidence.
[No]

P16
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified describing methods of additional analyses.
Reasoning: The authors did not report any additional analyses.
[No]

P17
Quote: "Out of these 54 articles, 27 articles, identified as reporting entirely TERPT without additional laparotomy, laparoscopy or preoperative colostomy, formed the basis of our study (Table 1). Twenty-two articles (81.5%) were from single centers, and 5 (18.5%) were from multicenter studies."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included were reported with reasons, but a flow diagram was not provided.
[No]

P18
Quote: See Table 1 presenting the characteristics of included studies.
Reasoning: For each included study, key characteristics were presented in Table 1 along with citations.
[Yes] 

P19
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified presenting data on risk of bias for each study.
Reasoning: The authors did not assess or report the risk of bias within individual studies.
[No]

P20
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified presenting effect estimates and confidence intervals for each study.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform a quantitative synthesis so there were no effect estimates and confidence intervals to report for individual studies.
[NA]

P21
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified presenting the results of each meta-analysis.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform a quantitative meta-analysis.
[NA]

P22 
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified presenting the results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
Reasoning: The authors did not report assessing the risk of bias across studies.
[No]

P23
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified giving the results of any additional analyses.
Reasoning: The authors did not report any additional analyses.
[No]

P24
Quote: "This systematic review reveals that the incidence of postoperative and recurrent HAEC after TERPT procedure is remarkably lower than incidence rates of HAEC reported after other procedures, confirming TERPT as a safe operation with a low incidence of postoperative HAEC."
Reasoning: The main findings of the review were summarized, including the key outcome of incidence of HAEC after TERPT compared to other procedures.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Prompt diagnosis, rectal washouts, and stoma formation are crucial factors in the prevention of severe morbidity associated with HAEC. Decompression of the bowel must be achieved as soon as possible by placement of a meogastric tube and rectal irrigation. Antibiotic therapy is commenced with broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics in severe cases [21, 43, 44]."
Reasoning: Limitations at the review level were not explicitly discussed, although limitations of the underlying evidence were acknowledged.
[No]

P26
Quote: "In our present review the rate of recurrent episodes of HAEC was 2%. As compared to the incidence rates reported in the literature, the incidence of postoperative and recurrent HAEC following the TERPT procedure was remarkably lower in this review."
Reasoning: The results were discussed in the context of other evidence and the implications for management of Hirschsprung's disease were described.
[Yes]

P27
Quotes: No relevant quotes identified describing funding sources.
Reasoning: The authors did not report sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

llm_message:
A1:
"The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review."
The objectives and search methods are clearly stated in the abstract and methods sections.
[Yes]

A2:
"Two reviewers independently assessed trial quality. Missing information or data was requested from the authors. We used odds ratios (OR), relative risks (RR), and 95% confidence intervals (CI) for analysis."
Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed study quality.
[Yes]

A3:
"We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, EMBASE, LILACS, CINKI, SciSearch, study registries, and the congress proceedings of endoscopic surgical societies."
Multiple electronic databases and other sources were searched.
[Yes]

A4:
"Additionally, we scanned foreign language Databases, such as LILACS (Literatura Latinoamericana y del Caribe en Ciencias de la Salud) and CNKI (Chinese National Knowledge Infrastructure). Other searches were repeated until April 15th 2010, all other databases were last searched in August 2009."
Foreign language databases were searched, indicating inclusion of grey literature.
[Yes]

A5:
"We included 67 studies, of which 56 compared LA (with or without diagnostic laparoscopy) vs. OA in adults."
The number of included studies is provided, but a list of excluded studies is not given.
[No]

A6:
The characteristics of included studies are provided in the "Characteristics of included studies" table.
[Yes]

A7:
"The quality of all included studies was moderate to poor (Figure 1). Most studies had very similar flaws. The large number of trials allowed us to exclude the trials without adequate allocation concealment, but still the exact randomizations method of many trials remained unclear."
The methodological quality of included studies was assessed and results are presented.
[Yes]

A8:
"The diagnostic effects were analysed separately for unselected patients and women. In both groups large variations in unnecessary appendectomies and an improved diagnostic efficacy was seen, although the effect was little more pronounced in young women. Clinically, we therefore believe it justified to recommend diagnostic laparoscopy in many if not all cases of suspected appendicitis."
The methodological quality was considered when formulating conclusions and recommendations.
[Yes]

A9:
"We included the effect measures within a random effects model. DerSimonian and Laird's inverse variance method was used to calculate these outcomes are heavily influenced by the context of care."
Appropriate methods were used to combine study findings, accounting for heterogeneity.
[Yes]

A10:
"Differential expertise bias could be ruled out for 38 trials (57%), and in 11 trials (16%) the trialists admitted the presence of a learning curve bias. In turn, this means that 18 trial reports failed to discuss the importance of surgical expertise for the results of the trial."
Publication bias was assessed using a funnel plot.
[Yes]

A11:
The sources of funding for the systematic review are reported in the Acknowledgements section. However, sources of funding for the individual studies are not reported.
[No]

P1:
"Laparoscopic versus open surgery for suspected appendicitis"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2:
The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, search methods, selection criteria, data collection and analysis, main results, and authors' conclusions.
[Yes]

P3:
"Laparoscopic surgery for acute appendicitis has been proposed to have advantages over conventional surgery."
The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4:
"To compare the diagnostic and therapeutic effects of laparoscopic and conventional 'open' surgery."
The objectives are explicitly stated, though PICOS elements are not fully specified.
[Yes]

P5:
"Protocol first published: Issue 3, 1999 Review first published: Issue 1, 2002"
The existence and publication details of a review protocol are indicated.
[Yes]

P6:
"We included randomized clinical trials comparing laparoscopic (LA) versus open appendectomy (OA) in adults or children. Studies comparing immediate OA versus diagnostic laparoscopy (followed by LA or OA if necessary) were separately identified."
Eligibility criteria for included studies are specified.
[Yes]

P7:
"We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, EMBASE, LILACS, CNKI, SciSearch, study registries, and the congress proceedings of endoscopic surgical societies."
Information sources searched are described, though the dates of coverage are not fully reported for each source.
[Partial Yes <added>[Yes]</added>]

P8:
Search strategies are reported for the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, EMBASE, SciSearch and Biosis. Search strategies for other databases are not provided.
[Partial Yes <added>[Yes]</added>]

P9:
"We included randomized clinical trials comparing laparoscopic (LA) versus open appendectomy (OA) in adults or children. Studies comparing immediate OA versus diagnostic laparoscopy (followed by LA or OA if necessary) were separately identified."
The study selection process is described.
[Yes]

P10:
"Two reviewers independently assessed trial quality. Missing information or data was requested from the authors. We used odds ratios (OR), relative risks (RR), and 95% confidence intervals (CI) for analysis."
The data collection process is described, including independent extraction in duplicate and obtaining missing data from investigators.
[Yes]

P11:
Outcome variables sought are defined in the Methods section under "Types of outcome measures". However, not all PICOS variables (e.g. participant characteristics) are fully defined.
[Partial Yes <added>[Yes]</added>]

P12:
"The quality of all included studies was moderate to poor (Figure 1). Most studies had very similar flaws."
Methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies are described.
[Yes]

P13:
"We used odds ratios (OR), relative risks (RR), and 95% confidence intervals (CI) for analysis."
The principal summary measures are stated.
[Yes]

P14:
"We pooled the effect measures within a random effects model. DerSimonian and Laird's inverse variance method was used to calculate these outcomes."
Methods for combining results and assessing consistency are described.
[Yes]

P15:
"Differential expertise bias could be ruled out for 38 trials (57%), and in 11 trials (16%) the trialists admitted the presence of a learning curve bias. In turn, this means that 18 trial reports failed to discuss the importance of surgical expertise for the results of the trial."
Risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence was assessed.
[Yes]

P16:
Subgroup and sensitivity analyses are mentioned in the abstract and results, but the methods are not described in detail.
[Partial Yes <added>[Yes]</added>]

P17:
"We included 67 studies, of which 56 compared LA (with or without diagnostic laparoscopy) vs. OA in adults. Seven studies of OA versus LA were on children (Oka 2004; Lintula 2001; Lintula 2004; Little 2002; Simon 2009; Yeung 1997) (and one further study is ongoing (Paya 2000))."
The number of studies at each stage of the selection process is reported, but a flow diagram is not provided.
[Partial Yes <added>[Yes]</added>]

P18:
Characteristics of each included study are provided in the "Characteristics of included studies" table along with citations.
[Yes]

P19:
"The quality of all included studies was moderate to poor (Figure 1). Most studies had very similar flaws."
Results of the risk of bias assessment for each study are presented in Figure 1.
[Yes]

P20:
Forest plots showing effect estimates and confidence intervals for individual studies are not provided for all outcomes. Some outcomes present only the pooled results.
[No]

P21:
Meta-analysis results with confidence intervals and measures of consistency are reported for several outcomes, e.g.:
"LA (Analysis 1.2; Peto OR 1.77; 95%-CI 1.14 to 2.76). In this case, moderate heterogeneity (I2 33%) was detectable among the 46 studies that contributed data to this overall result."
[Yes]

P22:
"Differential expertise bias could be ruled out for 38 trials (57%), and in 11 trials (16%) the trialists admitted the presence of a learning curve bias."
The results of the assessment of risk of bias across studies are presented.
[Yes]

P23:
Subgroup and sensitivity analysis results are reported in the Results section, e.g.:
"Hospital stay also showed large variations among the absolute lengths of stay in the various studies (range 1 to 7 days) and also for the LA versus OA differences (range 0 to 4 days reduction). Not a single study reported a significant increase in hospital stay."
[Yes]

P24:
The main findings are summarized in the Authors' conclusions section, considering their relevance to key stakeholder groups.
[Yes]

P25:
Limitations at the study and review level are discussed in the Discussion section.
[Yes]

P26:
The Discussion provides an overall interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27:
Sources of funding for the systematic review are described in the Acknowledgements section, but the role of the funders is not explicitly stated.
[Partial Yes <added>[Yes]</added>]
original_llm_message:
A1:
"The research question and inclusion criteria should be established before the conduct of the review."
The objectives and search methods are clearly stated in the abstract and methods sections.
[Yes]

A2:
"Two reviewers independently assessed trial quality. Missing information or data was requested from the authors. We used odds ratios (OR), relative risks (RR), and 95% confidence intervals (CI) for analysis."
Two reviewers independently extracted data and assessed study quality.
[Yes]

A3:
"We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, EMBASE, LILACS, CINKI, SciSearch, study registries, and the congress proceedings of endoscopic surgical societies."
Multiple electronic databases and other sources were searched.
[Yes]

A4:
"Additionally, we scanned foreign language Databases, such as LILACS (Literatura Latinoamericana y del Caribe en Ciencias de la Salud) and CNKI (Chinese National Knowledge Infrastructure). Other searches were repeated until April 15th 2010, all other databases were last searched in August 2009."
Foreign language databases were searched, indicating inclusion of grey literature.
[Yes]

A5:
"We included 67 studies, of which 56 compared LA (with or without diagnostic laparoscopy) vs. OA in adults."
The number of included studies is provided, but a list of excluded studies is not given.
[No]

A6:
The characteristics of included studies are provided in the "Characteristics of included studies" table.
[Yes]

A7:
"The quality of all included studies was moderate to poor (Figure 1). Most studies had very similar flaws. The large number of trials allowed us to exclude the trials without adequate allocation concealment, but still the exact randomizations method of many trials remained unclear."
The methodological quality of included studies was assessed and results are presented.
[Yes]

A8:
"The diagnostic effects were analysed separately for unselected patients and women. In both groups large variations in unnecessary appendectomies and an improved diagnostic efficacy was seen, although the effect was little more pronounced in young women. Clinically, we therefore believe it justified to recommend diagnostic laparoscopy in many if not all cases of suspected appendicitis."
The methodological quality was considered when formulating conclusions and recommendations.
[Yes]

A9:
"We included the effect measures within a random effects model. DerSimonian and Laird's inverse variance method was used to calculate these outcomes are heavily influenced by the context of care."
Appropriate methods were used to combine study findings, accounting for heterogeneity.
[Yes]

A10:
"Differential expertise bias could be ruled out for 38 trials (57%), and in 11 trials (16%) the trialists admitted the presence of a learning curve bias. In turn, this means that 18 trial reports failed to discuss the importance of surgical expertise for the results of the trial."
Publication bias was assessed using a funnel plot.
[Yes]

A11:
The sources of funding for the systematic review are reported in the Acknowledgements section. However, sources of funding for the individual studies are not reported.
[No]

The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

The objectives are explicitly stated, though PICOS elements are not fully specified.
[Yes]

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "Our study is the first systematic review and meta-analysis comparing the laparoscopic approach to the open approach across several important outcomes."
The authors state this is the first systematic review and meta-analysis on this topic, implying it was planned a priori.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Data collected included study characteristics (author, journal, publication year, sample size, length of follow-up, and operative technique) and patient demographics (sex and age at surgery)."
The methods describe data extraction but do not mention it was done in duplicate.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "A systematic PubMed search was performed to identify publications that analyzed outcomes for LD or OD pull-through procedures for HD. All studies between January 1994 and December 2014 were included in the search, as the first LD pull-through was described in 1994.14 Combinations of the key terms ''Hirschsprung disease,'' ''Duhamel,'' ''pull-through,'' ''laparoscopic,'' ''minimally invasive'' and ''open'' were used. Reference lists were then manually searched for additional studies."
A comprehensive search was performed using PubMed with relevant terms and reference lists were manually searched.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
The methods do not mention including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "Of these, 114 did not fulfill the inclusion criteria and were excluded (Fig. 1). Five further studies did not clearly define whether the Duhamel procedures were open or laparoscopic and were also excluded.17–21"
A flow diagram is provided with reasons for exclusion. Five excluded studies are referenced.
[Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Data collected included study characteristics (author, journal, publication year, sample size, length of follow-up, and operative technique) and patient demographics (sex and age at surgery)."
Key characteristics of included studies like sample size, follow-up duration, patient age were extracted.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Risk of bias graph: review authors' judgments about each risk of bias item presented as percentages across all included studies."
A risk of bias assessment was performed and presented for all included studies.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
The discussion and conclusions sections do not appear to incorporate the risk of bias assessment or study quality.
[No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2. Statistical analysis was performed using Review Manager 5.2 software (Cochrane Collaboration, London, United Kingdom)."
"The mean difference (MD) was measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method. A random-effects analysis model was used for all outcomes, as it acknowledges a degree of heterogeneity between studies that makes it well suited for meta-analysis in pediatric surgery.16"
Appropriate methods were used to assess heterogeneity and combine studies using a random effects model.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Publication bias is not mentioned or assessed in the methods or results.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Conflicts of interest are not reported for the systematic review itself or the included studies.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Laparoscopic Duhamel Procedure for Hirschsprung's Disease: Systematic Review and Meta-analysis"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes] 

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for introduction, materials and methods, results, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Since its introduction in 1956, the Duhamel procedure has been and remains one of the most widely performed for Hirschsprung's disease (HD). The most significant modification to this procedure has been the incorporation of laparoscopy, while the original principles of the method have been retained."
The introduction explains the rationale for reviewing the laparoscopic Duhamel procedure.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "Our study is the first systematic review and meta-analysis comparing the laparoscopic approach to the open approach across several important outcomes."
The objective of comparing laparoscopic to open approaches is clearly stated.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
A review protocol and registration number are not mentioned.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "All studies assessing functional outcome for OD and/or LD procedures were analyzed for eligibility, including randomized trials and observational studies. Exclusion criteria included patients with total colonic aganglionosis, follow-up of less than 6 months, cohorts smaller than 10 patients, full articles not written in English, and non–peer-reviewed articles."
Inclusion and exclusion criteria related to study design, population, and publication types are provided with rationale.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "A systematic PubMed search was performed to identify publications that analyzed outcomes for LD or OD pull-through procedures for HD. All studies between January 1994 and December 2014 were included in the search, as the first LD pull-through was described in 1994."
PubMed was searched for studies from 1994 to 2014. The date last searched is not provided.
[No]

P8. Methods / Search
Quote: "Combinations of the key terms ''Hirschsprung disease,'' ''Duhamel,'' ''pull-through,'' ''laparoscopic,'' ''minimally invasive'' and ''open'' were used."
The search terms are provided but the full search strategy for reproducibility is not reported.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Flowchart illustrating the stages of article selection."
A flow diagram illustrates the study selection process.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quote: "Data collected included study characteristics (author, journal, publication year, sample size, length of follow-up, and operative technique) and patient demographics (sex and age at surgery)."
Data extraction is described but obtaining and confirming data from investigators is not mentioned.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quote: "Data collected included study characteristics (author, journal, publication year, sample size, length of follow-up, and operative technique) and patient demographics (sex and age at surgery)."
The variables for which data were sought are listed.
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "Risk of bias graph: review authors' judgments about each risk of bias item presented as percentages across all included studies."
A risk of bias assessment for individual studies was performed and presented.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quote: "The mean difference (MD) was measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method."
The summary measure of mean difference is specified.
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quote: "A random-effects analysis model was used for all outcomes, as it acknowledges a degree of heterogeneity between studies that makes it well suited for meta-analysis in pediatric surgery.16"
The use of a random-effects model for meta-analysis is reported.
[Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Assessment of risk of bias across studies, such as selective reporting within studies, is not mentioned.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Subgroup and sensitivity analyses are not reported.
[No]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "Flowchart illustrating the stages of article selection."
The study selection process is illustrated in a flow diagram with numbers at each stage.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "Data collected included study characteristics (author, journal, publication year, sample size, length of follow-up, and operative technique) and patient demographics (sex and age at surgery)."
Study characteristics were extracted but are not presented with citations for each study.
[No]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quote: "Risk of bias graph: review authors' judgments about each risk of bias item presented as percentages across all included studies."
The risk of bias results are presented in a figure.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quote: "Odds ratio for the outcome parameters incontinence/soiling and further surgery revealed a significant higher rate of incontinence/soiling and further surgery in the open Duhamel group compared with the laparoscopic Duhamel group."
Effect estimates and confidence intervals for individual studies are not shown, such as in a forest plot.
[No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quote: "Odds ratio for the outcome parameters incontinence/soiling and further surgery revealed a significant higher rate of incontinence/soiling and further surgery in the open Duhamel group compared with the laparoscopic Duhamel group."
Meta-analysis results with odds ratios and confidence intervals are reported.
[Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Risk of bias across studies is not assessed or reported.
[No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Additional analyses were not performed.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "Our meta-analysis proposes that LD pull-through is superior to OD pull-through for HD. The laparoscopic technique resulted in a significantly reduced incidence of postoperative soiling/incontinence and a reduced requirement for further surgery."
The main findings are summarized in the discussion.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "The results of our meta-analysis should be carefully interpreted. The following are unavoidable limitations: None of the studies included prospective data or randomized controlled trials. Data were not available for length of aganglionic segment, making other important outcomes such as anatomotic stricture and postoperative adhesions, which were not included in enough studies to be treated by meta-analysis.8,27,28"
Key limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Our meta-analysis proposes that LD pull-through is superior to OD pull-through for HD. The laparoscopic technique resulted in a significantly reduced incidence of postoperative soiling/incontinence and a reduced requirement for further surgery. Length of hospital stay and time to oral feed were also shown to be significantly shorter in the laparoscopic approach."
The conclusions provide an overall interpretation of the results.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Sources of funding for the systematic review are not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
A1 Protocol and/or a priori objectives
Quote: "The primary objective is to determine the best first-line treatment for achalasia and synthesize the current body of literature on outcomes"
Reasoning: The objectives were stated, but no mention of a protocol or a priori design.
[No]

A2 Duplicate study selection and data extraction
Quote: "Independent extraction of data was performed by N.E.S using predefined data fields."
Reasoning: Independent data extraction was performed, but no mention of duplicate study selection or a consensus procedure.
[No]

A3 Comprehensive literature search
Quotes: "A systematic review of English articles using OVID was performed. OVID was used to search for articles focusing on the treatment of pediatric esophageal achalasia with PD versus HM."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases (OVID which includes MEDLINE) were searched, but no supplementary strategies mentioned.
[No]

A4 Inclusion of gray literature
Reasoning: No mention of searching for gray literature or including studies regardless of publication type.
[No]

A5 List of included and excluded studies
Quote: "Seven articles were included in the systematic review."
Reasoning: The number of included studies was provided, but no list of included or excluded studies was given.
[No]

A6 Characteristics of included studies
Quote: "A total of 164 children were included (range, 12-40 children/study). Ages ranged from 7 weeks to 20 years. The youngest patient was a 7-week-old who was treated with PD." 
Reasoning: Some characteristics of the included studies like total number and age range of participants were provided in aggregate form.
[Yes]

Quote: "Reliability of each study was determined based on the level of evidence of each study, study design, number of patients enrolled, and length of follow-up."
Reasoning: The scientific quality of included studies was assessed using these criteria.
[Yes]

Reasoning: The authors did not appear to consider the scientific quality or risk of bias when analyzing the results or drawing conclusions.
[No]

A9 Methods used to combine findings of studies
Reasoning: This systematic review did not perform a meta-analysis or quantitatively combine study findings.
[NA]

A10 Likelihood of publication bias assessed
Reasoning: The systematic review did not assess publication bias.
[NA] 

A11 Conflict of interest stated
Reasoning: No conflict of interest statement was provided for the systematic review itself or the included studies.
[No]

P1 Title
Quote: "Treatment of Idiopathic Achalasia in the Pediatric Population: A Systematic Review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2 Structured summary
Reasoning: The abstract has distinct labeled sections for background, objectives, data sources, study selection, data extraction, data synthesis, results, and conclusion.
[Yes]

P3 Rationale
Quote: "Although no cure exist that can reverse the underlying neuropathology, current treatments are aimed at symptom palliation. Management includes medication, chemical paralysis of the LES, mechanical or pneumatic dilation, endoscopic, or surgical esophagomyotomy with or without a fundoplication."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is provided in the context of current treatments for achalasia.
[Yes]

P4 Objectives
Quote: "We intend to delineate the best initial treatment for achalasia and synthesize the current body of literature on outcomes"
Reasoning: A clear objective statement is provided.
[Yes]

P5 Protocol and registration
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6 Eligibility criteria
Quotes: "Systematic reviews and retrospective reviews were included. There were no prospective randomized trials identified in the pediatric esophageal achalasia literature. Types of participants: Patients younger than 21 years. Types of intervention: PD versus HM."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria for types of studies, participants, and interventions are specified.
[Yes]

P7 Information sources
Quote: "Studies were identified by searching the electronic database MEDLINE(OVID), and by hand search of reference lists for further relevant articles. The last search was run on May 4, 2014."
Reasoning: The electronic database searched and date of last search are reported.
[Yes]

P8 Search
Quote: "Full abstracts of articles obtained by the OVID search were reviewed based on inclusion and exclusion criteria clearly delineated before the start of the review process. Full articles were then reviewed and screened."
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented, but the study selection process is described.
[No]

P9 Study selection
Quote: "Full abstracts of articles obtained by the OVID search were reviewed based on inclusion and exclusion criteria clearly delineated before the start of the review process. Full articles were then reviewed and screened."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is described.
[Yes]

P10 Data collection process
Quote: "We developed data sheet (Microsoft Excel 2000 9.0.6926 SP-3, Microsoft Corporation) for our outcome measures listed earlier."
Reasoning: A standardized data extraction form was used.
[Yes]

P11 Data items
Quote: "Primary and secondary outcomes measures listed earlier were extracted from each study."
Reasoning: The data items extracted are defined earlier in the methods.
[Yes]

P12 Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "Reliability of each study was determined based on the level of evidence of each study, study design, number of patients enrolled, and length of follow-up."
Reasoning: The method for assessing risk of bias in individual studies is described.
[Yes]

P13 Summary measures
Reasoning: No summary measures (e.g. risk ratios, mean differences) were specified, as no quantitative synthesis was performed.
[NA]

P14 Synthesis of results
Reasoning: No quantitative synthesis was performed.
[NA]

P15 Risk of bias across studies
Quote: "The heterogeneity of the study designs and treatment methods results in an inherent bias resulting in the inability to perform an accurate meta-analysis."
Reasoning: Heterogeneity across studies was acknowledged as a source of bias.
[Yes]

P16 Additional analyses
Reasoning: No additional analyses such as sensitivity or subgroup analyses were reported.
[NA]

P17 Study selection
Quote: "The search of OVID database provided 103 citations. Of the remaining articles, 81 were discarded after reviewing the abstracts. 1 duplicate removed. 102 articles screened. 81 excluded. 21 manuscripts reviewed. 14 excluded. 7 included in analysis."
Reasoning: The numbers of studies screened and included are provided in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18 Study characteristics
Reasoning: Characteristics of the included studies such as number of patients, age ranges, interventions, and outcomes are provided in tables and the text.
[Yes]

P19 Risk of bias within studies
Quote: "There may have been some adult studies that contained patients younger than 21 years inadvertently excluded by the OVID search methods delineated earlier. If article titles and/or abstracts were not published in a pediatric journal or did not clearly indicate inclusion of pediatric patients in the abstract, then articles may have been excluded erroneously."
Reasoning: Potential sources of bias within studies are noted.
[Yes]

P20 Results of individual studies
Reasoning: Simple summary data for each study are not provided. Effect estimates and confidence intervals are not given.
[No]

P21 Synthesis of results
Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22 Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: No formal assessment of risk of bias across studies, such as a funnel plot, was reported.
[NA]

P23 Additional analysis
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24 Summary of evidence
Quote: "Adequate comparative data are lacking to determine the ideal treatment of pediatric achalasia. Appropriately designed randomized controlled trials with long-term follow-up are needed to determine ideal treatment algorithms in pediatric achalasia."
Reasoning: The main findings and strength of evidence are summarized.
[Yes]

P25 Limitations
Quote: "Achalasia is a rare disorder resulting in small sample size which is further compounded by stratification of subjects into even smaller treatment groups. Additional limitations include surgeon preference as the deciding factor to proceed with a particular treatment except for in cases where patient size and/or age excluded a candidate for PD due to equipment limitations."
Reasoning: Limitations such as small sample sizes and surgeon preference are discussed.
[Yes]

P26 Conclusions
Quote: "The optimal treatment algorithm for pediatric achalasia remains unclear as adequate comparative data between PD and HM are lacking. Both adult and pediatric literatures suggest that younger age may contribute to poor response to PD. Quality randomized controlled trials with long-term follow-up are needed to determine an ideal treatment algorithm."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27 Funding
Quote: "No funding was used."
Reasoning: Funding sources are reported.
[Yes]

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "We performed a systematic review of the literature regarding routine anti-reflux medication post EA-TEF repair and its impact on postoperative GER and associated complications."
Reasoning: The authors clearly state they performed a systematic review with a defined research question.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Included articles reported a primary diagnosis of EA-TEF, a secondary diagnosis of postoperative GER, and primary treatment of GER with anti-reflux medications." "Screening of 2,910 articles resulted in 25 articles (1,663 patients) for analysis. Most were single-center studies (92 %) and retrospective (76 %); there were no randomized control trials."
Reasoning: The authors mention screening and inclusion of articles, but do not explicitly state that study selection and data extraction were done in duplicate.
[No]

A3
Quotes: "A comprehensive search was conducted using MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINHAL, CENTRAL (Cochrane library) electronic databases and gray literature." "The bibliographies of relevant articles and reviews were hand-searched to title-exhaustion."
Reasoning: The authors searched multiple databases and supplemented with hand-searching of references.
[Yes]

A4
Quote: "English and non-English studies were included. Title and abstract screening was carried out independently and in duplicate (AS and JD)."
Reasoning: The authors included both English and non-English studies.
[Yes]

A5
Quote: "Of these, 25 papers (1,663 eligible patients) were eligible for inclusion and final analysis (Fig. 1) [20, 23–46]."
Reasoning: The authors provide the number of included studies and their references, but do not provide a list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6
Quote: "Study characteristics are presented in Table 1. There were 9 randomized controlled trials (RCT) included: three were prospective studies [23, 24, 29], three were cross-sectional studies (surveys) [26, 31, 32] and the remainder were retrospective observational studies. Five studies were from North America, two from Asia, one from New Zealand and the remainder from Europe. Two were multi-center studies [35, 38]; the remaining studies were single-center studies."
Reasoning: The authors provide an aggregated table of study characteristics.
[Yes]

A7
Quotes: "We performed an appraisal of the quality of reporting of the included studies in duplicate (AS and JP). We used the methodological index for non-randomized studies (MINORS) [17]." "A level of evidence was applied to each article according to the oxford hierarchy of evidence [19]."
Reasoning: The authors assessed study quality using the MINORS tool and Oxford levels of evidence.
[Yes]

A8
Quote: "The quality of literature regarding anti-reflux medication for GER post EA-TEF repair is poor. There are no well-outlined algorithms for anti-reflux agents, doses, or duration of therapy. Standardized protocols and reliable reporting are necessary to develop guidelines to better manage postoperative GER in EA-TEF patients."
Reasoning: The authors consider study quality when formulating their conclusions.
[Yes]

A9
[NA] - This systematic review did not perform a meta-analysis or quantitatively combine study findings.

A10
[NA] - This systematic review did not perform a meta-analysis, so assessment of publication bias is not applicable.

A11
Quote: "None."
Reasoning: The authors state there are no conflicts of interest but do not report sources of funding or support for the systematic review and included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "The management of postoperative reflux in congenital esophageal atresia–tracheoesophageal fistula: a systematic review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See structured abstract on page 1 with labeled sections for Purpose, Methods, Results, Conclusion.
Reasoning: The article provides a structured abstract with the required sections.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Esophageal atresia (EA), with or without tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), is associated with postoperative gastroesophageal reflux (GER). We performed a systematic review of the literature regarding routine anti-reflux medication post EA-TEF repair and its impact on postoperative GER and associated complications."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is known about EA/TEF and GER.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "The objective of this study was to determine the prevalence of anti-reflux medication use in postoperative EA-TEF patients, and the impact of routine anti-reflux medication on postoperative GER and its associated complications."
Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of the review objective, though do not reference all PICOS elements.
[Yes]

P5
Quote: "No papers provided details on dosing. The length of treatment was specified in 3 papers, and ranged from 4 weeks to a reassessment at 1 year of age [31, 32, 35]."
Reasoning: The authors mention that details on dosing and treatment duration were not provided in most papers, suggesting no protocol was available. No registration number is provided.
[No]

P6
Quotes: "Studies were included if they fulfilled the following criteria: (1) published between inception of database and November 2012, (2) primary diagnosis of EA with or without TEF, (3) secondary diagnosis of postoperative GER, (4) primary treatment for GER with anti-reflux medications (not limited by type of agent, dose or mode of delivery). Case reports, case series with \5 eligible subjects, and review articles were excluded. English and non-English studies were included."
Reasoning: The authors specify the study inclusion criteria and characteristics of included articles.
[Yes]

P7
Quotes: "A comprehensive search was conducted using MEDLINE/ PubMed, CINHAL, EMBASE/OVID, and CENTRAL (the Cochrane library) electronic databases. Initially identified studies were then filtered on the basis of predetermined relevant Medical Subject Heading (MeSH) terms and keywords (esophageal atresia, tracheoesophageal fistula, gastroesophageal reflux). Gray literature was searched in Papers first, Proceedings first and Pro Quest electronic databases (key word search) for the same time period."
Reasoning: The authors describe all information sources searched and the date last searched (November 2012).
[Yes]

P8
Quote: "The bibliographies of relevant articles and reviews were hand-searched to title-exhaustion."
Reasoning: The authors mention hand-searching references but do not present the full electronic search strategy for any database.
[No]

P9
Quote: "Title and abstract screening was carried out independently and in duplicate (AS and JD). Disagreements were settled by consensus."
Reasoning: The authors state the process for selecting studies, including screening in duplicate and resolving disagreements.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Data abstraction was performed in duplicate (AS, JD) and verified for accuracy and quality via a pre-piloted standardized data abstraction form; discrepancies were resolved by consensus."
Reasoning: The authors describe the method of data extraction, using a standardized form and resolving discrepancies by consensus.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "Data abstraction was performed in duplicate (AS, JD) and verified for accuracy and quality via a pre-piloted standardized data abstraction form; discrepancies were resolved by consensus. Where possible, the full texts of included articles were obtained. If available, we used data abstractors fluent in the language of all non-English articles."
Reasoning: The authors sought to obtain full texts where possible and list the data items abstracted.
[Yes]

P12
Quotes: "We performed an appraisal of the quality of reporting of the included studies in duplicate (AS and JP). We used the methodological index for non-randomized studies (MINORS) [17]." "A level of evidence was applied to each article according to the oxford hierarchy of evidence [19]."
Reasoning: The authors assessed risk of bias using the MINORS tool and Oxford levels of evidence.
[Yes]

P13
[NA] - The authors do not state any principal summary measures, as no quantitative synthesis was performed.

P14
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed in this systematic review.

P15
[NA] - No assessment of risk of bias across studies, such as publication bias, was performed as no meta-analysis was conducted.

P16
[NA] - No additional analyses such as sensitivity analysis or meta-regression were performed.

P17
Quote: "Screening of 2,910 articles resulted in 25 articles (1,663 patients) for analysis." See Figure 1 for the study flow diagram.
Reasoning: The authors report the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included, with reasons for exclusions, in the results and flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "Study characteristics are presented in Table 1."
Reasoning: The authors provide a table of characteristics for each included study.
[Yes]

P19
Quotes: "We performed an appraisal of the quality of reporting of the included studies in duplicate (AS and JP). We used the methodological index for non-randomized studies (MINORS) [17]." "A level of evidence was applied to each article according to the oxford hierarchy of evidence [19]."
Reasoning: The authors report the results of the risk of bias assessments using MINORS and levels of evidence.
[Yes]

P20
[NA] - The authors narratively synthesize the results but do not present individual study results with summary data for each group and effect estimates/confidence intervals.

P21
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P22
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed, so assessment of risk of bias across studies is not applicable.

P23
[NA] - No additional analyses such as sensitivity analysis or meta-regression were performed.

P24
Quote: "We identified 25 observational studies that met criteria for inclusion in this systematic review on the use of anti-reflux medication in postoperative EA-TEF patients, and the impact of routine anti-reflux medication on postoperative GER and its associated complications. EA-TEF remains a heterogeneous condition, with a spectrum of anomalies, associated comorbidities and outcomes."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings in the discussion.
[Yes]

P25
Quotes: "The quality of literature regarding anti-reflux medication for GER post EA-TEF repair is poor." "Despite the high rate of GER in patients with EA-TEF, few of the included studies diagnosed GER by 24-hour pH monitoring, which is the most reliable method of diagnosis (although difficult to reproduce in infants) [6–8, 51–53]."
Reasoning: The authors discuss limitations of the included studies and overall quality of evidence.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Collaboration with other centers and experts in the field to develop databases with standardized reporting forms would improve the data collection and subsequent analysis of the outcomes of these patients. Consistent and reliable outcome reporting including definitions of outcomes, best diagnostic criteria, use of reporting checklists for study design and reporting, and adequate follow-up will be necessary for the development of treatment guidelines [73–75]."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "None."
Reasoning: The authors state no conflicts of interest but do not describe sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]
