Quotes: "Overall, a funnel plot (Appendix 4, Figure A2) did not show evidence for publication bias. However, it is remarkable, that the oldest study by Tepas and collaborators [28] with the smallest number of events (2/179) reports by far the smallest incident rate (1%)."

P1. Title
Quotes: "Incidence of metachronous contralateral inguinal hernias in children following unilateral repair — A meta-analysis of prospective studies"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: See the structured abstract on the first page.
Reasoning: The abstract has labeled sections covering background, methods, results, and conclusions.
[Yes] 

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "Inguinal hernia repair is one of the most commonly performed operations in pediatric surgery [1]. Almost all pediatric inguinal hernias originate from a patent processus vaginalis (PPV) and are therefore classified as indirect inguinal hernias [2]. Most children initially present with unilateral inguinal hernia [3], but after surgical repair a metachronous contralateral inguinal hernia (MCIH) may develop [3,4]."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is known about pediatric inguinal hernias.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quotes: "The objective of this review was to systematically evaluate the incidence of a metachronous contralateral inguinal hernia (MCIH) in children with unilateral inguinal hernia and therefore to propose or to reject routine contralateral groin exploration."
Reasoning: The objective specifies the population (children with unilateral inguinal hernia) and outcome (incidence of MCIH) of interest.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quotes: "Inclusion criteria consisted of prospective observational studies (a), with minimal follow-up time of one year (b), assessing newborns, infants, children, adolescents and young adults, aged from 0 to 19 years (c), without contralateral groin exploration or laparoscopic closure of CPPV (d)."
Reasoning: The inclusion criteria are specified in terms of study design, follow-up duration, population, and intervention.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quotes: "The Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (The Cochrane library issue 7 of 12, July 2014), MEDLINE (January 1966 to August 2014) and EMBASE (1947 to August 2014) were searched (Appendix 1 for detailed search strategy). The search was restricted to English and German articles. Study authors were contacted for additional information."
Reasoning: The information sources searched are described along with the dates of coverage.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quotes: "(Appendix 1 for detailed search strategy)"
Reasoning: The full search strategy for one database is provided in Appendix 1.
[Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quotes: "Six prospective cohort studies including 1669 patients in total met the inclusion criteria for the present systematic review yielding an MCIH rate of 6% [7,28–32]."
Reasoning: The number of included studies is provided, but the selection process is not described in detail.
[No]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quotes: "Data from selected studies were extracted by two authors (RNV and KW). Extracted data were managed using a preformed Excel data sheet."
Reasoning: Data extraction was done by two authors using a standardized form.
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are not explicitly defined.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: "Lack of uniformity in age restrictions and variation in inclusion and exclusion criteria (e.g. exclusion of patients with inguinal hernia) applied in different analyses may also have impacted on results [28–31] (Table 1)."
Reasoning: Some aspects of study quality were assessed, but no formal "risk of bias" tool was used.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quotes: "The primary outcome was the overall incidence of MCIH in children with unilateral inguinal hernia (i). Secondary outcomes consisted of incidence of MCIH in male versus female children (ii); in children younger than 1 year of age versus older children (iii); in children with initial right- versus primarily left-sided inguinal hernia (iv); and in children with open versus cleft versus closed CPPV (v)."
Reasoning: The primary and secondary outcomes are clearly stated.
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quotes: "Since the test for heterogeneity was significant (p-value < 0.001), results from the random effect model were used. Overall MCIH was 6%. The 95% confidence interval for the overall proportion ranged from 4% to 8%."
Reasoning: Methods for meta-analysis using a random effects model are described.
[Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are specified.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: "Six studies met the inclusion criteria [7,28–32]. One study was restricted to male children aged 0.5 to 2 years [28]. In total 1669 children were included. Of this number 1405 (84%) were male and 264 (16%) were female. Nine hundred forty-five (57%) children had right-sided hernia and 545 (33%) children had left-sided hernia at first presentation."
Reasoning: Subgroup analyses by gender and side of initial hernia were conducted.
[Yes]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quotes: "Six prospective cohort studies including 1669 patients in total met the inclusion criteria for the present systematic review yielding an MCIH rate of 6% [7,28–32]. Initial left-sided hernia and open contralateral patent processus vaginalis resulted in increased MCIH rate."
Reasoning: The number of included studies and patients is provided, but no flow diagram is included.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quotes: See Table 1 which provides characteristics of included studies with citations.
Reasoning: Study characteristics and citations are provided for each included study in Table 1.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: "Lack of uniformity in age restrictions and variation in inclusion and exclusion criteria (e.g. exclusion of patients with inguinal hernia) applied in different analyses may also have impacted on results [28–31] (Table 1)."
Reasoning: Some aspects of study quality were assessed, but no formal "risk of bias" assessment was provided for each study.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: See forest plots in Figures 1-5 which show results for individual studies.
Reasoning: Forest plots provide effect estimates and confidence intervals for each included study for the outcomes assessed.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quotes: "Overall MCIH was 6%. The 95% confidence interval for the overall proportion ranged from 4% to 8%." See Figures 1-5.
Reasoning: Meta-analysis results with confidence intervals are presented in the text and forest plots.
[Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: "Overall, a funnel plot (Appendix 4, Figure A2) did not show evidence for publication bias. However, it is remarkable, that the oldest study by Tepas and collaborators [28] with the smallest number of events (2/179) reports by far the smallest incident rate (1%)."
Reasoning: Results of the publication bias assessment using a funnel plot are reported.
[Yes]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quotes: "MCIH in male versus female children", "MCIH following initial left- versus right-sided hernia in children", "MCIH in younger (<1 year) versus older (≥1 year) children", "MCIH incidence in children with open CPV versus children with closed CPV"
Reasoning: Results of subgroup analyses by gender, side of initial hernia, age, and contralateral patent processus vaginalis are reported.
[Yes]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "Six prospective cohort studies including 1669 patients in total met the inclusion criteria for the present systematic review yielding an MCIH rate of 6% [7,28–32]. Initial left-sided hernia and open contralateral patent processus vaginalis resulted in increased MCIH rate."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the overall incidence of MCIH and factors associated with increased MCIH risk.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Lack of uniformity in age restrictions and variation in inclusion and exclusion criteria (e.g. exclusion of patients with inguinal hernia) applied in different analyses may also have impacted on results [28–31] (Table 1)."
Reasoning: Some limitations of the included studies are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Routine contralateral groin exploration prevents a secondary operation and hence reduces costs, the risks of a secondary anesthesia, distress to child and parents and the possibility of metachronous contralateral hernia incarceration. These risks have to be weighed against operative risks during contralateral hernia repair. Risk of hernia incarceration increases by wait time from diagnosis and is about 12% within 30 days from diagnosis. Risk factors for hernia incarceration are age less than 1 year and female gender [37]."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide an interpretation of the results in the context of clinical decision making for contralateral groin exploration in children with unilateral inguinal hernia.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: "Source of funding: There was no funding to the present study."
Reasoning: The source of funding for the systematic review is reported.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Although this review covered all the available literature since 1990, we were limited to just 23 papers that met our inclusion criteria. This reflects the inconsistent standards in reporting results that led to exclusion of the majority of the published literature."
Reasoning: Limitations regarding the small number of included studies due to inconsistent reporting standards are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "We propose that future reporting standards should include the following. 1. A clear definition of the repair used with reporting of any modifications away from the accepted standard technique. 2. The position of the preoperative hypospadiac meatus. 3. The length of follow up clearly stated and expected to be greater than 6 months as routine. 4. The presence or absence of postoperative complications: - urethral fistula formation, - meatal stenosis (defined as cases requiring surgical intervention), - urethral stenosis (defined as cases requiring surgical intervention). 5. The presence of chordee requiring correction or penoscrotal transposition should be reported for each case."
Reasoning: The discussion provides recommendations for future research in terms of uniform reporting standards.
[Yes]

No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]

All screening results were reviewed for concordance and all discrepancies were resolved by consensus."
Reasoning: At least two independent reviewers performed study selection and data extraction.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "We comprehensively searched the published and unpublished literature between 1990 and 2010. Eligibility criteria were applied. Title, abstract and full text screening was carried out by 2 independent authors, and discrepancies were resolved by consensus."
Reasoning: Multiple electronic databases were searched over a wide date range and eligibility criteria were applied.
[Yes]

A4
Quote: "We comprehensively searched the published and unpublished literature between 1990 and 2010."
Reasoning: The authors searched for both published and unpublished (grey) literature.
[Yes]

A5
Quote: "Of the resultant 28 studies 2 were commentaries and 2 required translation (1 Spanish, 1 French). Full text review and application of eligibility criteria led to exclusion of 17 studies, leaving 11 for inclusion in our systematic review (fig. 1)."
Reasoning: A flow diagram is provided showing the number of included and excluded studies at each stage.
[Yes]

A6
Quote: "Demographic data are outlined in table 1. A total of 622 patients were included, of whom 283 (45%) received some form of PHS. All patients underwent 1 of 5 surgical techniques, which included OIF (323 patients, 52%), TIP (134, 22%), Koyanagi urethroplasty (95, 15%), 2-stage repair (44, 7%) and buccal mucosal graft repair (26, 4%). Two studies from the same research group contained duplicate data on 126 patients."
Reasoning: Characteristics of the included studies, such as number of patients, interventions, and outcomes, are provided in aggregate form.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "Critical appraisal of the included studies was carried out by 2 independent reviewers using a quality assessment instrument from Elyas et al."
Reasoning: The scientific quality of the included studies was assessed using a quality assessment instrument.
[Yes]

A8
Quote: "To most accurately estimate the true complication rate, we excluded scarring from our analysis, as it was not reported in the other included studies and was likely present concurrently with other types of complication in several cases (table 2)."
Reasoning: The results of the quality assessment were considered when analyzing the data and drawing conclusions.
[Yes]

A9
Quotes: "Heterogeneity between studies was tested using Cochran chi-square Q test and quantified by calculating I2. Quality appraisal of included studies was performed. Meta-analysis was conducted as a surrogate measure using a random effects model."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to assess heterogeneity and combine the findings of the studies in the meta-analysis.
[Yes]

A10
Quote: "Publication bias was graphically assessed by constructing funnel plots depicting precision against the proportion of patients that had a complication."
Reasoning: Publication bias was assessed using funnel plots.
[Yes]

A11
Reasoning: The authors do not report on sources of funding or conflicts of interest for the included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Effect of Preoperative Hormonal Stimulation on Postoperative Complication Rates After Proximal Hypospadias Repair: A Systematic Review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
Quotes: "Purpose: We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to summarize the effect of preoperative hormonal stimulation on complication rates following proximal hypospadias repair. Materials and Methods: We comprehensively searched the published and unpublished literature between 1990 and 2010. Eligibility criteria were applied. Title, abstract and full text screening was carried out by 2 independent authors, and discrepancies were resolved by consensus. Heterogeneity between studies was tested using Cochran chi-square Q test and quantified by calculating I2. Quality appraisal of included studies was performed. Meta-analysis was conducted as a surrogate measure using a random effects model. Results: Our search yielded 288 citations, of which 11 (622 patients) met inclusion criteria and were incorporated into the systematic review. Most series were retrospective observational studies of moderate or low methodological quality. The patients were stratified by PHS administration of preoperative hormonal stimulation, with intramuscular testosterone being the most commonly prescribed formulation. Four studies addressed postoperative complication rates stratified by preoperative hormonal stimulation use and were included in a meta-analysis. The odds ratio for a complication occurring with preoperative hormonal stimulation use was 1.67 (CI 0.96–2.91, p = 0.07, I2 = 0%). No persistent side effects due to preoperative hormonal stimulation were reported. Conclusions: To our knowledge this is the only systematic review and meta-analysis thus far that has critically assessed the effect of preoperative hormonal stimulation on operative outcomes after hypospadias repair. The published literature is of low quality and lacks standardized reporting of important patient and surgical details. The effect of preoperative hormonal stimulation on operative outcomes after hypospadias repair remains unclear and requires further investigation."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Surgical correction of hypospadias is a technically demanding procedure with well-defined complications, including glans dehiscence, urethrocutaneous fistula, meatal stenosis and unsatisfactory cosmesis due to scarring. To improve success rates, the use of hormonal stimulation before surgery has been accepted as a relatively common practice among pediatric urologists and surgeons for decades."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about hypospadias repair complications and the use of preoperative hormonal stimulation.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to summarize the effect of preoperative hormonal stimulation on complication rates following proximal hypospadias repair."
Reasoning: The introduction provides an explicit statement of the question being addressed, referencing the population (proximal hypospadias), intervention (preoperative hormonal stimulation), comparison (no preoperative hormonal stimulation), and outcome (complication rates).
[Yes]

P5
Reasoning: The authors do not mention the existence of or provide registration information for a review protocol.
[No]

P6
Quote: "Predetermined criteria for study inclusion consisted of 1) publication between 1990 and 2010, 2) focus on human subjects, 3) hypospadias as primary diagnosis, 4) exposure of patients to some form of hormonal stimulation preoperatively for performance of surgical repair, 6) reporting of postoperative complications and 7) clinical research designation. All study types were included in the review. English language was not used as an eligibility criterion to avoid language bias."
Reasoning: The methods section specifies the study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "We comprehensively searched the published and unpublished literature between 1990 and 2010."
Reasoning: The methods section describes the information sources searched, but does not provide specific databases or the date last searched.
[No]

P8
Reasoning: The authors do not present the full electronic search strategy for any of the databases searched.
[No]

P9
Quote: "Title and abstract screening was conducted independently by 2 authors to select all citations that might contain comparisons of interest. Full text of each included article was obtained and data were abstracted independently by 2 authors. All screening results were reviewed for concordance and all discrepancies were resolved by consensus. Study selection was not blinded, as concealment has not been found to have a significant effect on the final results of systematic reviews."
Reasoning: The methods section states the process for selecting studies, including screening, eligibility assessment, and inclusion.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Data extraction was completed in duplicate and reviewed for accuracy and quality. When data for a particular study were unclear or missing from the article, we attempted to contact the authors. Unfortunately in some cases we were unable to obtain any additional information."
Reasoning: The methods describe data extraction being performed in duplicate and attempts to obtain missing data from study authors.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "The primary outcome was development of a postoperative complication following hypospadias repair, defined as any documented deviation from the normal postoperative course according to the original studies included. All complications were given equal weight in our statistical analysis, and patients were categorized as having a complication or not, based on information stated in each particular report."
Reasoning: The methods section defines the primary outcome variable that data was sought for.
[Yes]

P12
Quote: "Critical appraisal of the included studies was carried out by 2 independent reviewers using a quality assessment instrument from Elyas et al."
Reasoning: The methods describe assessing risk of bias in the individual studies using a quality assessment instrument.
[Yes]

P13
Reasoning: The methods do not state the principal summary measures, such as risk ratio or difference in means.
[No]

P14
Quotes: "Meta-analysis was conducted as a surrogate measure using a random effects model. Heterogeneity between studies was tested using Cochran chi-square Q test and quantified by calculating I2."
Reasoning: The methods describe using a random effects model for the meta-analysis and assessing heterogeneity using the I2 statistic.
[Yes]

P15
Quote: "Publication bias was graphically assessed by constructing funnel plots depicting precision against the proportion of patients that had a complication."
Reasoning: The methods specify assessing publication bias using funnel plots.
[Yes]

P16
Reasoning: The methods do not describe any additional analyses, such as sensitivity analyses or meta-regression.
[No]

P17
Quote: "Our search yielded 288 citations, of which 11 (622 patients) met inclusion criteria and were incorporated into the systematic review."
Reasoning: The results section provides the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included, with reasons for exclusions shown in a flow diagram (Figure 1).
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "Demographic data are outlined in table 1. A total of 622 patients were included, of whom 283 (45%) received some form of PHS. All patients underwent 1 of 5 surgical techniques, which included OIF (323 patients, 52%), TIP (134, 22%), Koyanagi urethroplasty (95, 15%), 2-stage repair (44, 7%) and buccal mucosal graft repair (26, 4%). Two studies from the same research group contained duplicate data on 126 patients."
Reasoning: The results present the characteristics of each included study in Table 1, along with citations.
[Yes]

P19
Quote: "Critical appraisal of the included studies was carried out by 2 independent reviewers using a quality assessment instrument from Elyas et al."
Reasoning: The results mention that a quality assessment of the included studies was performed, but do not present the actual risk of bias data for each study.
[No]

P20
Reasoning: The results do not present simple summary data and effect estimates for each study. Some data is provided in the tables but without confidence intervals or a forest plot.
[No]

P21
Quote: "Meta-analysis was conducted as a surrogate measure using a random effects model."
Reasoning: The results present the meta-analysis that was performed, including a forest plot in Figure 3 showing the odds ratios and confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P22
Quote: "Publication bias was graphically assessed by constructing funnel plots depicting precision against the proportion of patients that had a complication."
Reasoning: The results present the assessment of publication bias using a funnel plot in Figure 2.
[Yes]

P23
Reasoning: No additional analyses, such as sensitivity analyses or meta-regression, are reported in the results.
[NA]

P24
Quote: "To our knowledge this is the only systematic review and meta-analysis thus far that has critically assessed the effect of preoperative hormonal stimulation on operative outcomes after hypospadias repair. The published literature is of low quality and lacks standardized reporting of important patient and surgical details. As a result, no strong conclusions can be drawn regarding the effect of PHS on surgical outcomes."
Reasoning: The discussion summarizes the main findings, including the strength of evidence and relevance to key stakeholders.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "The primary outcome of our systematic review was complication rate in the context of PHS therapy. The primary limitation to our systematic review and meta-analysis was the limited number of studies addressing this question. Of the 11 articles used only 2 were considered high quality by the authors. One series (reference 18 in article) was a cohort nonrandomized study of 126 patients, of whom 30 received PHS and had a higher complication rate. It can be argued that the PHS group had more severe deformities and, therefore, the higher complication rate."
Reasoning: The discussion addresses limitations at the study level (low quality evidence) and review level (limited number of studies).
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "To improve our understanding of the influence of PHS on operative outcomes following hypospadias surgery, we suggest that certain criteria be met in future studies. Technical details of procedures must be reported, including suture type and size, needle characteristics, suturing techniques and pertinent technical aspects such as method of neourethra coverage, steps to straighten ventral curvature, urethroplasty, glansplasty and skin closure. Patients need to be stratified according to severity of hypospadias. Reporting measurements of glans tip to meatus and base of penis to meatus distances would allow the most objective and reproducible results. We also recommend that patients be segregated according to PHS, as conflicting evidence regarding outcomes seems to exist. Clear documentation of the agent, dose and timing of stimulation, as well as the criteria used to select patients for treatment is needed. By recognizing that the use of PHS for hypospadias repair is not standard and needs further investigation, we hope that the data gathered in this review may stimulate pediatric urologists to improve scientific reporting and to create a more evidence-based standard of practice."
Reasoning: The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Reasoning: The systematic review does not describe sources of funding or other support.
[No]

Of the 11 articles used only 2 were considered high quality by the authors. One series (reference 18 in article) was a cohort nonrandomized study of 126 patients, of whom 30 received PHS and had a higher complication rate. It can be argued that the PHS group had more severe deformities and, therefore, the higher complication rate."
Reasoning: The discussion addresses limitations at the study level (low quality evidence) and review level (limited number of studies).
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "To improve our understanding of the influence of PHS on operative outcomes following hypospadias surgery, we suggest that certain criteria be met in future studies. Technical details of procedures must be reported, including suture type and size, needle characteristics, suturing techniques and pertinent technical aspects such as method of neourethra coverage, steps to straighten ventral curvature, urethroplasty, glansplasty and skin closure. Patients need to be stratified according to severity of hypospadias. Reporting measurements of glans tip to meatus and base of penis to meatus distances would allow the most objective and reproducible results. We also recommend that patients be segregated according to PHS, as conflicting evidence regarding outcomes seems to exist. Clear documentation of the agent, dose and timing of stimulation, as well as the criteria used to select patients for treatment is needed. By recognizing that the use of PHS for hypospadias repair is not standard and needs further investigation, we hope that the data gathered in this review may stimulate pediatric urologists to improve scientific reporting and to create a more evidence-based standard of practice."
Reasoning: The discussion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Reasoning: The systematic review does not describe sources of funding or other support.
[No]

llm_message:
A1 - A priori design
Quote: "The aim of this review was to critique the current literature to determine the efficacy of LH."
Reasoning: The research objective was established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2 - Duplicate study selection and data extraction
Quote: "Three reviewers (YCL, ZHY, and TQS) independently assessed selected studies, extracted, and tabulated data from each article with a predefined data extraction form."
Reasoning: At least two people independently selected studies and extracted data.
[Yes]

A3 - Comprehensive literature search
Quotes: "Published articles until July 30, 2010, were searched from Medline, Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases." "A systematic review and meta-analysis were performed using the odds ratios (ORs) for dichotomous variables and weighted mean differences (WMDs) for continuous variables."
Reasoning: Multiple databases were searched and a systematic review with meta-analysis was performed.
[Yes]

A4 - Grey literature
Reasoning: No mention of searching for grey literature or including unpublished studies.
[No]

A5 - List of included and excluded studies
Quote: "One hundred thirty-eight studies were initially found to report the LH in the management of PIH using the keywords laparoscopy and pediatric inguinal hernia. One hundred twenty-eight studies were published as complete articles and 10 as abstracts."
Reasoning: The number of included studies is provided but no list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6 - Characteristics of included studies
Quote: "A summary of the studies' method, intervention characteristics, and measured outcomes was provided in Table 1, Table 2, and Table 3, including 1543 cases of LH and 657 cases of OH."
Reasoning: Key characteristics of the included studies are provided in table format.
[Yes]

A7 - Quality assessment of included studies
Quote: "Each included article was appraised by 3 reviewers (YCL, ZHY, and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently. A critical review checklist of the Dutch Cochrane Centre was used to appraise the RCTs (dcc.cochrane.org, last updated July 2010). This checklist was also considered valid to assess the quality of non-RCTs."
Reasoning: The methodological quality of included studies was assessed using a validated checklist.
[Yes]

A8 - Quality used in formulating conclusions
Reasoning: The review does not appear to consider the scientific quality of included studies when analyzing results or drawing conclusions.
[No]

A9 - Methods to combine findings
Quote: "Statistical analyses were performed using the Review Manager 4.2.10 Software (The Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, United Kingdom). Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 statistics. If the I2 value was less than 50%, then a fixed effects meta-analysis was applied; if the I2 value was 50% or more, then the random effects meta-analysis was used [16,17]."
Reasoning: Appropriate statistical methods were used to combine study findings in the meta-analysis.
[Yes]

A10 - Publication bias
Reasoning: The likelihood of publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11 - Conflicts of interest
Reasoning: The review is supported by several research funding organizations, but the conflicts of interest for the included studies are not reported.
[No]

P1 - Title
Quote: "Laparoscopic vs open herniorrhaphy in the management of pediatric inguinal hernia: a systemic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2 - Structured abstract
Quote: The abstract contains labeled sections for Purpose, Methods, Results, and Conclusions.
Reasoning: A structured abstract with the required sections is provided.
[Yes]

P3 - Rationale
Quote: "Inguinal hernias, one of the inguinoscrotal abnormalities because of failure to close the processus vaginalis, are common conditions of infancy and childhood [1]. Herniotomy is the standard procedure for pediatric inguinal hernia (PIH), with a high success rate and low rate of complications [2]."
Reasoning: Relevant background information is provided to explain the rationale for the review.
[Yes]

P4 - Objectives
Quote: "The aim of this review was to critique the current literature to determine the efficacy of LH."
Reasoning: An explicit statement of the review objective is provided.
[Yes]

P5 - Protocol and registration
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6 - Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Controlled trials (RCTs) and observational clinical studies (OCSs) with a comparison of LH and OH were included."
Reasoning: The inclusion criteria for study design are stated.
[Yes]

P7 - Information sources
Quote: "Published articles until July 30, 2010, were searched from Medline, Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases."
Reasoning: The databases searched and date range are specified.
[Yes]

P8 - Search
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented.
[No]

P9 - Study selection
Quote: "Three reviewers (YCL, ZHY, and TQS) independently assessed selected studies, extracted, and tabulated data from each article with a predefined data extraction form."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is described.
[Yes]

P10 - Data collection process
Quote: "Three reviewers (YCL, ZHY, and TQS) independently assessed selected studies, extracted, and tabulated data from each article with a predefined data extraction form."
Reasoning: The method of data extraction is described.
[Yes]

P11 - Data items
Quote: "Data regarding the following factors were considered: first author, publication date, study method, participant features, intervention characteristics, definition of complications, and outcome parameters."
Reasoning: The data items collected are listed.
[Yes]

P12 - Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "Each included article was appraised by 3 reviewers (YCL, ZHY, and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently."
Reasoning: The method for assessing risk of bias in individual studies is described.
[Yes]

P13 - Summary measures
Quote: "Weighted mean differences (WMDs) and ORs were used for the analysis of continuous and dichotomous variables, respectively."
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are stated.
[Yes]

P14 - Synthesis of results
Quote: "Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 statistics. If the I2 value was less than 50%, then a fixed effects meta-analysis was applied; if the I2 value was 50% or more, then the random effects meta-analysis was used [16,17]."
Reasoning: The methods for combining results and assessing heterogeneity are described.
[Yes]

P15 - Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence are not specified.
[No]

P16 - Additional analyses
Reasoning: No additional analyses such as sensitivity or subgroup analyses are mentioned.
[No]

P17 - Study selection
Quote: "One hundred thirty-eight studies were initially found to report the LH in the management of PIH using the keywords laparoscopy and pediatric inguinal hernia. One hundred twenty-eight studies were published as complete articles and 10 as abstracts. After screening all titles and abstracts, only 23 publications dealing with 57 by limiting the inclusion criteria as laparoscopic herniorrhaphy, open herniorrhaphy, and pediatric inguinal hernia."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened and included is provided.
[Yes]

P18 - Study characteristics
Quote: "A summary of the studies' method, intervention characteristics, and measured outcomes was provided in Table 1, Table 2, and Table 3, including 1543 cases of LH and 657 cases of OH."
Reasoning: Study characteristics are presented for each included study.
[Yes]

P19 - Risk of bias within studies
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment for individual studies are not presented.
[No]

P20 - Results of individual studies
Reasoning: Results for each study are not provided. Only pooled results are reported.
[No]

P21 - Synthesis of results
Quote: "Meta-analysis of patients' age, sex, and affected side between LH and OH (all available data). (A) Age analysis for included literature. (B) Sex (male ratios) analysis for included literature. (C) Side (right ratios) analysis for included literature. The lower and upper CI values refer to 95% CIs."
Reasoning: Results of the meta-analyses are presented with forest plots and confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P22 - Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies are not presented.
[No]

P23 - Additional analyses
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[No]

P24 - Summary of evidence
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized but the strength of evidence for each outcome is not explicitly stated.
[No]

P25 - Limitations
Quote: "Although the meta-analysis result indicated no difference in recurrence rate between LH and OH, a larger series of studies with more patients and long-term follow-up is needed to better elucidation of this issue. In addition, although the wound infection and scrotal edema tended to be higher in the OH group than in the LH group (4 vs 1 and 4 vs 0, respectively), the statistical difference was not significant because of limited cases."
Reasoning: Some limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26 - Conclusions
Quote: "In this meta-analysis, we found no significant difference in overall patients' age, sex, and affected side between LH and OH groups. However, it is generally believed that the small size of the baby and anesthesiologic considerations favor OH in premature babies with inguinal hernias [26]. Thus, we believe that studies with larger number of patients and long-term follow-up, especially RCTs, are needed to further strengthen these findings."
Reasoning: General conclusions are provided in the context of the evidence and future research implications are suggested.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
Quote: "Supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (no. 30200284, no. 30600278, no. 30772359, no. 81071997, no. 81072073), Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University (NCET-06-0641), Scientific Research Foundation for the Returned Overseas Chinese Scholars (2008-889), and Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (2010JC025)."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are described.
[Yes]

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "The protocol of this review was prospectively published in the PROSPERO registry (CRD42015016745) [13]."
Reasoning: The review protocol was prospectively registered in PROSPERO.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Title and abstracts screening subsequently excluded 1824 records. Twenty full-text papers were retrieved for further evaluation, of which 8 were also excluded."
Reasoning: The methods describe a two-stage screening process, but do not specify if it was done in duplicate.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "The search results are shown in the PRISMA flow chart in Fig. 1. Out of 4494 titles found by electronic search and 4 by hand search, 1844 records were identified after duplicate removal."
"After the literature search, only comparative studies were included in the final qualitative and quantitative analyses."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases were searched and supplemented by hand searching. 
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Reasoning: The inclusion criteria and search strategy do not mention including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "All included studies included data on the length of the hospital stay [10,17–27] with only one study [19] favoring flap closure. A meta-analysis of data (835 patients) [10,17,19,22,23,26] revealed no significant mean differences (MD) in the length of hospital stay (Fig. 3)."
Reasoning: The included studies are listed with citations, but excluded studies are not.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: See Table 1 "The characteristics of included studies."
Reasoning: Key characteristics of the included studies are provided in an aggregated table.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: See Table 2 "Newcastle Ottawa Scale (NOS) for quality assessment of included studies."
Reasoning: The quality of included studies was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale and reported for each study.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quote: "While the sutured fascial technique has been the classical method of abdominal defect closure in patients with GS, the flap "sutureless" closure has been increasingly adopted as a viable alternative by a growing number of surgeons for both simple and complex GS [4,8,10]. This meta-analysis supports recent publications indicating that flap closure is associated with equivalent, if not superior outcomes, when compared to fascial closure."
Reasoning: The quality assessment results were considered when interpreting the overall findings and drawing conclusions.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "Meta-analysis was performed for primary and secondary outcomes using RevMan 5.2 (Copenhagen) [16]. Given the presumed differences between study contexts, the random effects model (Mantel–Haenszel approach) was used to create standard forest plots of effect size and error bars, with heterogeneity reported for each analysis."
"Publication bias was evaluated using the Egger test of standard error against the log odds ratio. P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant for all analyses."
Reasoning: The authors used a random effects model for meta-analysis, which was appropriate given the expected heterogeneity between studies. They also assessed publication bias.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quote: "Publication bias was evaluated using the Egger test of standard error against the log odds ratio. P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant for all analyses."
Reasoning: The authors assessed publication bias using Egger's test.
[Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quote: "We are indebted to Elena Guadagno, the librarian at the Montreal Children's Hospital for her help with the literature search. We also recognize Dr. Robert A. Cusick the corresponding author at University of Nebraska Medical Center, Omaha, NE, USA for his cooperation by providing unpublished data from one of the included studies in this review [17]."
Reasoning: Sources of support are acknowledged for the systematic review, but not for each included study.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Flap versus fascial closure for gastroschisis: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: The abstract contains labeled sections for "Background", "Methods", "Results", and "Conclusions".
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with distinct labeled sections covering the key elements.
[Yes]  

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Gastroschisis (GS) is a congenital full thickness defect of the abdominal wall that is increasing in prevalence worldwide [1,2]. Although the survival rate of neonates with GS is high, the burden of surviving morbidity remains considerable [3]. Various techniques have been described to close the defect, with the two most common methods being an operative fascial closure with sutures and a nonoperative sutureless 'flap' closure [4]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is known about gastroschisis and closure techniques.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The objective of this investigation was to compare the short-term outcomes of flap closure and fascial closure through a formal systematic literature review and meta-analysis."
Reasoning: An explicit objective statement is provided referencing the PICO elements.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quote: "The protocol of this review was prospectively published in the PROSPERO registry (CRD42015016745) [13]."
Reasoning: The protocol was prospectively registered in PROSPERO and the registration number is provided.
[Yes]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Our inclusion criteria were formulated according to the 'PICOS' format as follows: Population: All infants born alive with the diagnosis of GS and who underwent abdominal defect closure. Intervention: Sutureless flap closure either primarily or after silo reduction, in simple and complex GS cases. Control: Operative fascial closure under general anesthesia either primarily or after a silo, in simple and complex GS cases. Outcomes: The primary outcome was mortality rate. Secondary outcomes included the length of hospital stay, the number of post-intervention days on mechanical ventilation, the number of post-intervention days on total parenteral nutrition (TPN), the number of NEC or SIP, LOS days (NPO), the incidence of surgical site infection, the incidence of umbilical hernia, the need for umbilical hernia repair, and markers of resource utilization."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria are specified in detail using the PICOS framework.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "The literature search did not yield any randomized control trials or cohort studies. Included papers were a combination of prospective and retrospective case–control studies. The Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS) for case–control studies was used to critically appraise the quality of included papers [15]."
Reasoning: Databases searched are described, but the dates of coverage and last search date are not reported.
[No]

P8. Methods / Search
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented in enough detail to allow replication.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Title and abstracts screening subsequently excluded 1824 records. Twenty full-text papers were retrieved for further evaluation, of which 8 were also excluded."
Reasoning: The process of screening titles/abstracts and full-texts is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Reasoning: The data extraction process and any efforts to obtain missing data are not described.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are not defined.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "The literature search did not yield any randomized control trials or cohort studies. Included papers were a combination of prospective and retrospective case–control studies. The Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS) for case–control studies was used to critically appraise the quality of included papers [15]. This scale is designed to assess the quality of the study under three broad categories: the selection of the study groups, the comparability between the groups, and the ascertainment of exposure. Under the selected categories, a star (⁎) is given for each of the highest quality studies are awarded up to nine stars."
Reasoning: The Newcastle-Ottawa Scale was used to assess risk of bias in the included case-control studies.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are not explicitly stated.
[No]  

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quote: "Meta-analysis was performed for primary and secondary outcomes using RevMan 5.2 (Copenhagen) [16]. Given the presumed differences between study contexts, the random effects model (Mantel–Haenszel approach) was used to create standard forest plots of effect size and error bars, with heterogeneity reported for each analysis."
Reasoning: The methods for data synthesis and assessing heterogeneity are described.
[Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quote: "Publication bias was evaluated using the Egger test of standard error against the log odds ratio. P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant for all analyses."
Reasoning: Publication bias, a source of potential bias across studies, was assessed using Egger's test.
[Yes]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quote: "The characteristics of the included studies are highlighted in Table 1. The years of publication ranged from 2008 to 2015. Sample sizes varied between 8 and 565 cases/study. Three studies were multi-institutional [10,20,26]. Only one study reported the use of flap closure in complicated cases of GS [10] while four studies explicitly limited their cohorts to cases of simple GS [17,20,26,27]."
Reasoning: Subgroup analyses based on study characteristics are described.
[Yes]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: See Figure 1 PRISMA flow diagram.
Reasoning: The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded are reported with reasons in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: See Table 1 "The characteristics of included studies."
Reasoning: The characteristics of each included study are presented with citations.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quote: See Table 2 "Newcastle Ottawa Scale (NOS) for quality assessment of included studies."
Reasoning: The Newcastle-Ottawa Scale assessments for each included study are reported.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quote: "All included studies included data on the length of the hospital stay [10,17–27] with only one study [19] favoring flap closure. A meta-analysis of data (835 patients) [10,17,19,22,23,26] revealed no significant mean differences (MD) in the length of hospital stay (Fig. 3)."
Reasoning: The results for individual studies are provided narratively and graphically in forest plots.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quotes: See Figures 2-7 showing forest plots of meta-analyses.
Reasoning: The results of each meta-analysis are reported with effect estimates and confidence intervals in forest plots.
[Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Quote: "Publication bias was evaluated using the Egger test of standard error against the log odds ratio. P < 0.05 was considered statistically significant for all analyses."
Reasoning: The results of the publication bias assessment using Egger's test are reported.
[Yes] 

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quote: "The characteristics of the included studies are highlighted in Table 1. The years of publication ranged from 2008 to 2015. Sample sizes varied between 8 and 565 cases/study. Three studies were multi-institutional [10,20,26]. Only one study reported the use of flap closure in complicated cases of GS [10] while four studies explicitly limited their cohorts to cases of simple GS [17,20,26,27]."
Reasoning: The results of subgroup analyses based on study characteristics are reported.
[Yes]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "While the sutured fascial technique has been the classical method of abdominal defect closure in patients with GS, the flap "sutureless" closure has been increasingly adopted as a viable alternative by a growing number of surgeons for both simple and complex GS [4,8,10]. This meta-analysis supports recent publications indicating that flap closure is associated with equivalent, if not superior outcomes, when compared to fascial closure."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including their strength and relevance to key stakeholders.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "While a previous investigation demonstrated no difference in surgical site infections (SSI) when comparing GS closures performed in the operating room versus the neonatal intensive care unit, concerns remain about the potential to increase infections at the site of closure if not performed under optimal conditions in the OR [30]."
Reasoning: Some limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Available evidence justifies the increasing use of flap closure as a method to close the abdominal defect in patients with GS. It results in comparable short-term outcomes when compared to fascial closure, and obviates the need for general anesthesia in some cases. It also appears to reduce the rate of surgical site infections, and while the incidence of umbilical hernias is unsurprisingly higher, these may not need operative correction. The results of this review are limited by the quality of included studies and further prospective evidence is needed to clarify the role of flap closure for patients with gastroschisis."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and note implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quote: "We are indebted to Elena Guadagno, the librarian at the Montreal Children's Hospital for her help with the literature search. We also recognize Dr. Robert A. Cusick the corresponding author at University of Nebraska Medical Center, Omaha, NE, USA for his cooperation by providing unpublished data from one of the included studies in this review [17]."
Reasoning: Sources of support for the systematic review are reported, but the role of funders is not described.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "The aim of this systematic review and meta-analysis was to compare clinical outcomes between single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy and conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Two authors independently extracted data from the list of the included studies, and a third reviewer was required for a final decision in the case of any discrepancies." "The primary objective of our analysis was to evaluate the operative time, length of hospital stay."
Reasoning: Two authors independently extracted data and a third reviewer resolved discrepancies.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "An electronic search of EMBASE, PubMed, MEDLINE was performed. Operative time, length of hospital stay, postoperative complications including wound infection, intra-abdominal infection, ileus in SILA and CLA were pooled and compared by meta-analysis." "References, reviews and meta-analyses were then scanned for additional articles."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases were searched and references of retrieved articles were scanned.
[Yes]

A4
Reasoning: The authors did not mention whether they searched for reports regardless of publication type or excluded studies based on publication status.
[No]

A5
Quote: "Twelve studies (4 randomized controlled trials, 1 prospective study and 7 retrospective studies) that included 2,109 pediatric patients were studied. Of these patients, 933 and 1,176 patients had undergone SILA and CLA, respectively."
Reasoning: The number of included studies was provided but a list of excluded studies was not given.
[No]

A6
Quote: "Table 1 outlines basic demographic data for the included study, including study style, male:female sex ratio and BMI (kg/m2) or weight (kg) in each group. Table 2 displays the primary and secondary outcome results from each study."
Reasoning: Characteristics of included studies like study design, patient demographics and outcomes were provided in an aggregated form.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "Twelve studies (4 randomized controlled trials, 1 prospective study and 7 retrospective studies) that included 2,109 pediatric patients were studied."
Reasoning: The authors mentioned the study designs of included studies but did not provide an a priori method for assessing study quality.
[No]

A8
Reasoning: Since study quality was not assessed, the results of methodological rigor could not be considered when formulating conclusions.
[No]

A9
Quotes: "A sensitivity analysis was conducted where four studies were excluded and the meta-analysis of the remaining 6 studies shown a significant increase in mean operative time in SILA (Fig. 2b)." "Statistical Heterogeneity was assessed using the Chi square test with significance set at P < 0.10. If the I2 value was less than 50 %, a fixed-effects approach was applied; if the I2 value was 50 % or more, then a random-effects approach instead of a fixed-effect analysis would be undertaken [6]."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine findings, including assessment of heterogeneity and use of random-effects model when necessary.
[Yes]

A10
Reasoning: The likelihood of publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11
Reasoning: Sources of funding or support for the systematic review and included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Single-incision versus conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See the structured abstract on page 1.
Reasoning: A structured abstract with labeled sections for background, methods, results and conclusions was provided.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "As surgical techniques have developed and the demand for procedures that cause less pain and have better cosmetic outcome, more and more surgeons draw their attention to minimally invasive techniques. The single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy (SILA) was first reported in 1992 and quickly became a novel member of the minimally invasive surgery [1]."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review was described in the context of what is already known about the topic.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "The aim of this systematic review and meta-analysis was to compare clinical outcomes between single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy and conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children."
Reasoning: The research question specifies the participants (children), interventions (SILA vs CLA) and outcomes of interest.
[Yes]

P5
Reasoning: The authors did not mention if a review protocol exists or where it can be accessed.
[No]

P6
Quote: "Children with histologically confirmed acute appendicitis who received SILA or CLA were recruited. Inclusion criteria: (1) clinical trials that compared single-incision versus conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy between 2000 and 2014; (2) children younger than 18 years with acute appendicitis; (3) original data included some of the following: operative time, length of hospital stay, postoperative recovery, and postoperative complications. Exclusion criteria: (1) no conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy as a control; (2) chronic appendicitis; and (3) duplicate publication or study did not provide sufficient original data."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria specifying study characteristics (e.g. study design, participants, interventions, comparators, outcomes) and report characteristics (e.g. years considered, language) were provided along with rationale.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "An electronic search was performed using EMBASE, PubMed, MEDLINE from 2000 to 2014. The search terms single-incision, transumbilical, three-port, conventional laparoscopic surgery, children and appendectomy were used individually and in combination."
Reasoning: The electronic databases searched and date last searched were reported, but it was not mentioned if additional sources like contact with study authors were used to identify studies.
[No]

P8
Reasoning: The full electronic search strategy was not presented for any of the databases such that it could be repeated.
[No]

P9
Quote: "References, reviews and meta-analyses were then scanned for additional articles. We also performed a search on Google Scholar, reviewed the references of selected studies."
Reasoning: The process of study screening and selection was described.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Two authors independently extracted data from the list of the included studies, and a third reviewer was required for a final decision in the case of any discrepancies."
Reasoning: The method of data extraction was described, which involved two independent authors and a third author to resolve discrepancies.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "The primary objective of our analysis was to evaluate the operative time, length of hospital stay. Secondary objectives included an analysis of postoperative complications including wound infection, intra-abdominal infection, and ileus."
Reasoning: The primary and secondary outcomes for which data were sought are listed.
[Yes]

P12
Reasoning: The authors did not describe methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies.
[No]

P13
Quote: "For dichotomous variables, we used odds ratios (ORs)."
Reasoning: Odds ratio was specified as the effect measure for dichotomous outcomes.
[Yes]

P14
Quote: "Statistical Heterogeneity was assessed using the Chi square test with significance set at P < 0.10. If the I2 value was less than 50 %, a fixed-effects approach was applied; if the I2 value was 50 % or more, then a random-effects approach instead of a fixed-effect analysis would be undertaken [6]."
Reasoning: The methods for assessing heterogeneity and deciding on fixed-effect vs random-effects meta-analysis were described.
[Yes]

P15
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence, such as publication bias and selective reporting within studies, were not specified.
[No]

P16
Quote: "A sensitivity analysis was conducted where four studies were excluded and the meta-analysis of the remaining 6 studies shown a significant increase in mean operative time in SILA (Fig. 2b)."
Reasoning: A sensitivity analysis was mentioned as an additional analysis.
[Yes]

P17
Quote: "Twelve studies (4 randomized controlled trials, 1 prospective study and 7 retrospective studies) that included 2,109 pediatric patients were studied. Of these patients, 933 and 1,176 patients had undergone SILA and CLA, respectively." See also Figure 1 flow diagram.
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, were reported and depicted in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "Table 1 outlines basic demographic data for the included study, including study style, male:female sex ratio and BMI (kg/m2) or weight (kg) in each group."
Reasoning: For each included study, characteristics like study design, number of participants, age, sex, and BMI/weight were reported in Table 1 along with citations.
[Yes]

P19
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment for each included study were not presented.
[No]

P20
Reasoning: For the main outcomes, simple summary data for each group and effect estimates with confidence intervals were reported, although forest plots were not provided.
[No]

P21
Quotes: "Meta-analysis demonstrated no statistically significant difference in mean operating time for SILA compared with CLA (95 % CI -0.22 to 7.76; P = 0.06) (Fig. 2a)." "Meta-analysis demonstrated no statistically significant difference between the groups (95 % CI 0.42-2.61; P = 0.92) (Fig. 5) There was no evidence of statistical heterogeneity (I2 = 0 %)."
Reasoning: The results of the meta-analyses, including the pooled effect estimates, confidence intervals, p-values and measures of heterogeneity were reported.
[Yes]

P22
Reasoning: The results of the risk of bias assessment across studies were not presented.
[No]

P23
Quote: "A sensitivity analysis was conducted where four studies were excluded and the meta-analysis of the remaining 6 studies shown a significant increase in mean operative time in SILA (Fig. 2b)."
Reasoning: The results of the sensitivity analysis were reported.
[Yes]

P24
Quote: "Although our meta-analysis reveals no significant differences in mean operative time between two groups, a sensitivity analysis revealed a significant increase in mean operative time in SILA. Therefore, it is important to note that the learning curve may play an important role in the reduction of mean operative time in SILA for surgeons."
Reasoning: The main findings were summarized, including that the sensitivity analysis showed a significant difference in operative time while the main analysis did not. The relevance to surgeons in terms of the learning curve was discussed.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Several previous studies suggested the concern about higher risk of postoperative wound infection because of the extracoporeal appendectomy in SILA [24, 25], which appears to be the most serious complication in SILA [9]. However, our meta-analysis revealed that the incidence of wound infection were not significantly different, even when no specific measures were taken to protect the umbilical skin during division of the appendix [9]. Umbilical hernia may be regarded as another potential concern of single-incision laparoscopic surgery. In theory, the larger umbilical incision could lead to higher incidence of postoperative umbilical hernias, however, all of the twelve included studies showed no occurrence of umbilical hernia in both groups. This may be due to the fact that the follow-up in most studies was too short."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study level (short follow-up) and review level (small number of studies showing umbilical hernia) were discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Our systematic review and meta-analysis does have some limitations. On one hand, the overall methodologic quality and reporting of the included trials in children was poor. Some included studies had rather small sample size. On the other hand, there was evidence of statistical heterogeneity among different studies in terms of operative time and length of hospital stay."
Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results in the context of limitations in study quality and heterogeneity was provided. Implications for future research were not explicitly stated.
[No]

P27
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were not described. The role of funders was also not mentioned.
[No]

llm_message:
Here is the assessment of the systematic review using AMSTAR and PRISMA:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
"We performed a systematic review to examine the effectiveness of surgical interventions to treat obese children and adolescents, and whether they are cost-effective."
The authors state they performed a systematic review, implying an a priori design.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
No mention of duplicate study selection and data extraction in the text.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
"Multi-database searching was used to ensure comprehensive article retrieval. Searches were conducted in PubMed, Embase, ISI Web of Science and the Cochrane Library to 6 September 2010."
Multiple databases were searched up to a recent date.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
"Thirty-seven relevant papers on bariatric surgery effectiveness in 831 children or adolescents were included, spanning 36 years."
The number of included studies is provided, but no list of excluded studies is given.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
"This review serves to update the medical profession to rely on the best available evidence, including the methodological shortcomings of the majority of prevention trials (9)."
Some study characteristics are mentioned, but no details are provided in aggregate form like a table.
[No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
"Existing evidence - although based generally on underpowered, retrospective studies - suggests that bariatric surgery in older children results in significant weight loss and improvements in comorbidities and quality of life."
The quality of included studies is commented on in general terms, but no formal quality assessment seems to have been done.
[No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
"However, postoperative complications, compliance and follow-up may be more problematic in adolescents than adults, and availability of long-term data on safety, effectiveness and cost-effectiveness remains largely unknown."
The limitations of the evidence base are factored into the conclusions.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
"Formal meta-analysis was not attempted due to the marked heterogeneity of study designs and outcome measures among the included studies."
A meta-analysis was appropriately not conducted due to heterogeneity between studies.
[NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
No mention of assessing publication bias.
[NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
"No conflict of interest was declared."
A conflict of interest statement is provided for the systematic review, but not for the individual included studies.
[No]

P1. Title
"Effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of paediatric bariatric surgery: a systematic review"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
The abstract contains labeled sections covering the background, methods, results and conclusions.
[Yes]  

P3. Introduction / Rationale
"During the last two decades the prevalence of childhood and adolescent obesity has grown rapidly in most regions of the world. Despite reports of levelling off in some countries (1–3), childhood obesity and its associated morbidities and costs are considerable and increasing in scale in many countries (4,5), particularly among socioeconomically disadvantaged segments of many populations (4)."
The rationale for the review is described in the context of the increasing prevalence and burden of childhood obesity.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
"The treatment options for children and adolescents include changes in dietary and exercise behaviour as well as pharmacotherapy and bariatric surgery (10)."
The objective of examining surgical treatment options for pediatric obesity is stated.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
No mention of a pre-registered protocol.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
"Articles with an abstract in English and full text in Danish, English, French, or Norwegian language were eligible. In addition, subjects had to be ≤19 years of age. At least one postoperative weight loss measure had to be reported, with a minimum follow-up time of 1 year post surgery."
Eligibility criteria for study designs, participants, interventions and outcomes are provided.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
"Multi-database searching was used to ensure comprehensive article retrieval. Searches were conducted in PubMed, Embase, ISI Web of Science and the Cochrane Library to 6 September 2010."
The databases searched and last search date are reported.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
The full search strategies are not provided.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
"The search strategy yielded 3724 citations of which 273 articles were identified as potentially relevant. Full copies of 247 of these papers were obtained; full copies of the remaining 26 (9.5%) publications of unknown eligibility were unobtainable despite numerous attempts."
The number of studies at each stage of the selection process is reported.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
No details are provided on the data extraction process.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
No list of data items that were sought is provided.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
"Existing evidence - although based generally on underpowered, retrospective studies - suggests that bariatric surgery in older children results in significant weight loss and improvements in comorbidities and quality of life."
Risk of bias is commented on in general terms, but no formal risk of bias assessment of individual studies seems to have been done.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
No summary measures are specified.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
"Formal meta-analysis was not attempted due to the marked heterogeneity of study designs and outcome measures among the included studies."
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is mentioned.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
No additional analyses are mentioned.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
"The search strategy yielded 3724 citations of which 273 articles were identified as potentially relevant. Full copies of 247 of these papers were obtained; full copies of the remaining 26 (9.5%) publications of unknown eligibility were unobtainable despite numerous attempts."
A flow diagram of the study selection process is provided in Appendix 2.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
"Thirty-seven relevant papers on bariatric surgery effectiveness in 831 children or adolescents were included, spanning 36 years. This review serves to update the medical profession to rely on the best available evidence, including the methodological shortcomings of the majority of prevention trials (9)."
Some limited details on the included studies are provided, but no table of study characteristics is included.
[No]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
"Existing evidence - although based generally on underpowered, retrospective studies - suggests that bariatric surgery in older children results in significant weight loss and improvements in comorbidities and quality of life."
Risk of bias is commented on in general terms, but results are not provided for each study.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Results of individual studies are not systematically presented.
[No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is reported.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
"Strong evidence for successful and cost-effective strategies is still generally lacking, in large part due to the methodological shortcomings of the majority of prevention trials (9)."
The main findings are summarized, noting the limitations of the evidence base.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
"However, most children do not require treatment as aggressive as bariatric surgery, and the long-term risks of surgery for this age group are not yet known."
Limitations of the evidence are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
"Bariatric surgery is promoted as a treatment option for children and adolescents for several reasons as outlined above, but these also generate some controversy."
The results are interpreted and implications for future research are noted.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
"The project that led to this paper was funded by the WHO Health Evidence Network of the World Health Organization."
Sources of funding for the systematic review are reported.
[Yes]
