Risk of bias is commented on in general terms, but no formal risk of bias assessment of individual studies seems to have been done.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
No summary measures are specified.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
"Formal meta-analysis was not attempted due to the marked heterogeneity of study designs and outcome measures among the included studies."
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is mentioned.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
No additional analyses are mentioned.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
"The search strategy yielded 3724 citations of which 273 articles were identified as potentially relevant. Full copies of 247 of these papers were obtained; full copies of the remaining 26 (9.5%) publications of unknown eligibility were unobtainable despite numerous attempts."
A flow diagram of the study selection process is provided in Appendix 2.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
"Thirty-seven relevant papers on bariatric surgery effectiveness in 831 children or adolescents were included, spanning 36 years. This review serves to update the medical profession to rely on the best available evidence, including the methodological shortcomings of the majority of prevention trials (9)."
Some limited details on the included studies are provided, but no table of study characteristics is included.
[No]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
"Existing evidence - although based generally on underpowered, retrospective studies - suggests that bariatric surgery in older children results in significant weight loss and improvements in comorbidities and quality of life."
Risk of bias is commented on in general terms, but results are not provided for each study.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Results of individual studies are not systematically presented.
[No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is reported.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
"Strong evidence for successful and cost-effective strategies is still generally lacking, in large part due to the methodological shortcomings of the majority of prevention trials (9)."
The main findings are summarized, noting the limitations of the evidence base.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
"However, most children do not require treatment as aggressive as bariatric surgery, and the long-term risks of surgery for this age group are not yet known."
Limitations of the evidence are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
"Bariatric surgery is promoted as a treatment option for children and adolescents for several reasons as outlined above, but these also generate some controversy."
The results are interpreted and implications for future research are noted.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
"The project that led to this paper was funded by the WHO Health Evidence Network of the World Health Organization."
Sources of funding for the systematic review are reported.
[Yes]

llm_message:
Here is the assessment of the systematic review using AMSTAR and PRISMA:

A1
Quote: "A systematic review was conducted. The search was limited to studies reported in English and performed in addition to Medline and PubMed, a manual search of the Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, Surgical Endoscopy, and the Journal of Laparoendoscopic & Advanced Surgical Techniques published between June 2000 and April 2008 was conducted."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "A data extraction form was created to standardize the collection of study elements from each included article. This form included the following information: inclusion/exclusion criteria, study title, author, characteristics of the journal (year of publication), study design, study period, sample size, and the focus of the study in use of the LAARP as a primary procedure or after colostomy."
Reasoning: A standardized data extraction form was used, but no mention of duplicate study selection and extraction.
[No]

A3
Quotes: "A systematic search of the MEDLINE, PUBMED, and Cochrane databases (June 2000 to April 2008) was conducted. The search terms used were "laparoscopic," "pull-through," "anorectal malformation," and "imperforate anus." In addition, a manual search of 4 surgical journals from the same period was performed. The journals searched were "The Journal of Pediatric Surgery," "Pediatric Surgery International," "Surgical Endoscopy," and "Journal of Laparoendoscopic & Advanced Surgical Techniques.""
Reasoning: At least two databases were searched and supplemented by manual search of journals.
[Yes]

A4
Quotes: "Inclusion criteria were studies of ARMs, regardless of level of the defect, with or without associated anomalies, use of LAARP as a primary procedure or with colostomy, and studies reported after the year 2000. Exclusion criteria included studies that were not reported in English and those that did not deal with human subjects."
Reasoning: Inclusion criteria were specified regardless of publication status. Exclusion criteria included language and non-human studies.
[Yes]

A5
Quotes: "Seventeen studies were included in the final analysis. Of the included studies, none were randomized, 2 were prospective in nature, and 4 compared outcomes of posterior sagittal anorectoplasty and LAARP. The studies included 124 patients (96 males, 28 females) with 80% reported as having high/intermediate malformations."
Reasoning: The number of included studies was provided, but no list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6
Quote: "The studies included 124 patients—96 males (77.4%) and 28 females (22.6%). Of the 124 patients, 110 (88.7%) had undergone previous colostomy, whereas 14 patients (11.2%) had undergone a primary laparoscopic repair without a colostomy. Most patients (80%) had either a high or intermediate ARM."
Reasoning: Aggregated characteristics of the included studies were provided.
[Yes]

A7
Quotes: "Analysis of study designs revealed 2 prospective studies (11.7%) [2,3], 4 comparative studies (23.5%) [2,4–6], and no randomized studies."
"Recently, Ozzechi et al [22] recently documented the scarcity of high-level evidence pertaining to minimal access surgery in children. In this article, we closely examined indications of LAARP because it was initially described. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first systematic review to examine literature pertaining to LAARP."
Reasoning: Study designs were reported but no formal assessment of scientific quality was described. The authors acknowledge the lack of high-quality evidence.
[No]

A8
Quote: "To the best of our knowledge, this is the first systematic review to examine literature pertaining to LAARP."
Reasoning: Scientific quality was not used in formulating conclusions, as it was not assessed.
[No]

A9
Reasoning: This was a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so methods for combining studies are not applicable.
[NA]

A10
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed in this systematic review without a meta-analysis.
[NA]

A11
Reasoning: Sources of funding and conflicts of interest for the systematic review and included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Laparoscopic-assisted anorectal pull-through for anorectal malformations: a systematic review and the need for standardization of outcome reporting"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]  

P2
Quote: "Introduction: Laparoscopic-assisted anorectal pull-through (LAARP) is becoming an increasingly common procedure to correct high and intermediate anorectal malformations (ARMs). The aim of this review was to evaluate worldwide experiences with LAARP with regard to indications, outcomes, and quality of reporting.
Method: A systematic review was conducted. The search was limited to studies reported in English and performed in addition to Medline and PubMed, a manual search of the Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, Surgical Endoscopy, and the Journal of Laparoendoscopic & Advanced Surgical Techniques published between June 2000 and April 2008 was conducted.
Results: Seventeen studies were included in the final analysis. Of the included studies, none were randomized, 2 were prospective in nature, and 4 compared outcomes of posterior sagittal anorectoplasty and LAARP. The studies included 124 patients (96 males, 28 females) with 80% reported as having high/intermediate malformations. All studies reported short-term outcomes. Reported outcomes included continence, rectal prolapse, the position of the rectum (7 studies using Kelly score), manometry (1 study), contrast enema (1 study), postural endosonography (3 studies), and postoperative complications (3 studies). Outcomes varied widely between reports precluding a meta-analysis.
Conclusion: The number of studies dealing with LAARP is low. There is a need for both a standardization and improvement in the quality of reporting in LAARP research. This will ultimately allow for evidence-based surgical decision making."
Reasoning: A structured abstract is provided with labeled sections for background, methods, results and conclusion.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Over the past several years, techniques have evolved in the repair of high and intermediate anorectal malformations (ARMs), starting with the abdominoperineal pull-through, sacroperineal pull-through, and posterior sagittal anorectoplasty (PSARP) and now moving toward the recently reported laparoscopically assisted anorectal pull-through (LAARP) procedure."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of the evolution of surgical techniques for ARMs.
[Yes]

P4
Reasoning: No explicit statement of the review questions with reference to PICOS.
[No]

P5
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6
Quotes: "Inclusion criteria were studies of ARMs, regardless of level of the defect, with or without associated anomalies, use of LAARP as a primary procedure or with colostomy, and studies reported after the year 2000. Exclusion criteria included studies that were not reported in English and those that did not deal with human subjects."
Reasoning: Study characteristics used as eligibility criteria were specified.
[Yes]

Quotes: "A systematic search of the MEDLINE, PUBMED, and Cochrane databases (June 2000 to April 2008) was conducted."
"In addition, a manual search of 4 surgical journals from the same period was performed. The journals searched were "The Journal of Pediatric Surgery," "Pediatric Surgery International," "Surgical Endoscopy," and "Journal of Laparoendoscopic & Advanced Surgical Techniques.""

[No]

[NA]

Reasoning: The number of included studies was reported, but no details on the number screened or assessed for eligibility, reasons for exclusions, or a flow diagram.
[No]

Reasoning: Aggregated characteristics of the included studies were provided.

Reasoning: Results for individual studies were not presented.

Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

Reasoning: Risk of bias across studies was not assessed in this systematic review without a meta-analysis.
[NA]

P23
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24
Quote: "One in 5000 infants is born with an ARM. The evolution of surgical techniques for dealing with this complex group of malformations led to the description of the PSARP by deVries and Pena [18] in 1982. Posterior sagittal anorectoplasty became the standard of care for dealing with ARM. Despite the excellent exposure of anatomy and exact placement of the distal rectum within the muscle complex, the technique is not perfect, especially in patients with "high" ARM defects [19–21]."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the evolution of surgical techniques and limitations of the PSARP approach.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Recently, Ozzechi et al [22] recently documented the scarcity of high-level evidence pertaining to minimal access surgery in children. In this article, we closely examined indications of LAARP because it was initially described. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first systematic review to examine literature pertaining to LAARP."
Reasoning: Limitations in the evidence base are acknowledged.
[Yes]

Quote: "In conjunction with the increased interest in minimal access surgery in children, there has been increased awareness among surgeons of the importance of evidence-based surgery."
Reasoning: Implications for future research in terms of the need for evidence-based surgery are provided.

Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were not described.
[No]

llm_message:
Here is the assessment of the systematic review's methodological quality based on AMSTAR:

A1. "We reviewed our experience and performed a systematic review of reports of EDT in pediatric patients." The review mentions performing a systematic review, but does not specify an a priori protocol. [No]

A2. No mention of duplicate study selection and data extraction. [No]

A3. "We searched PubMed, MEDLINE, and Embase by using the key words "pediatrics", and "children". Bibliographies of relevant publications were reviewed to identify reports that were not initially located with the Medline search." At least 2 databases and checking reference lists were used. [Yes] 

A4. No mention of including grey literature. [No]

A5. No list of included and excluded studies provided. [No]

A6. Table 1 provides some characteristics of the included studies like sample size, outcomes, and survival rates. However, key details like population characteristics are missing. [No]

A7. "For publications that did not report certain variables, those cases were systematically excluded when analyzing that missing variable." This suggests assessing study quality based on missing data, but the specific criteria are not described a priori. [No]

A8. No mention of study quality being considered in the analysis and conclusions. [No]

A9. Quantitative synthesis of studies was not performed. [NA]

A10. No assessment of publication bias. [NA] 

A11. No reporting of conflicts of interest for the included studies. The funding source for the systematic review itself is reported. [No]

Here is the assessment of the systematic review's reporting quality based on PRISMA:

P1. "Pediatric emergency department thoracotomy: A large case series and systematic review" The title identifies the article as a systematic review. [Yes]

P2. The abstract is structured with labeled sections for Background/purpose, Methods, Results, and Conclusion. However, some details like data sources and study appraisal methods are missing. [No]

P3. "Trauma remains the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children and adolescents [1,2]. By recognizing this, care of the injured child has improved with aggressive efforts to standardize treatment." Provides rationale for the review in the context of trauma morbidity and mortality in children. [Yes]

P4. "To address this issue, we reviewed our experience at a level 1 trauma center and report the largest analysis over the past 25 years. In conjunction, we performed a systematic review of all published reports regarding pediatric EDT and combined the data from those reports with the data from our institution" Specifies the review questions being addressed. [Yes]

P5. No mention of a review protocol or registration. [No]

P6. "These reports obtained from a Medline search for all publications regarding EDT in the pediatric population for the past 40 year using the keywords "thoracotomy", "emergency", "trauma", "resuscitation", "pediatrics", and "children"." Specifies study eligibility criteria and rationale. [Yes]

P7. "We searched PubMed, MEDLINE, and Embase by using the key words "pediatrics", and "children". Bibliographies of relevant publications were reviewed to identify reports that were not initially located with the Medline search." Describes information sources and dates searched. [Yes]

P8. The full search strategy is not provided such that it could be repeated. [No]

P9. "These reports obtained from a Medline search for all publications regarding EDT in the pediatric population for the past 40 year using the keywords "thoracotomy", "emergency", "trauma", "resuscitation", "pediatrics", and "children". Bibliographies of relevant publications were reviewed to identify reports that were not initially located with the Medline search." Describes the study selection process. [Yes]

P10. No description of the data collection process. [No]

P11. Table 1 lists the variables for which data were extracted. [Yes]  

P12. No description of assessing risk of bias in individual studies. [No]

P13. No summary measures specified. [No]

P14. No description of methods for combining results. [NA]

P15. No assessment of risk of bias across studies. [NA]

P16. No additional analyses performed. [NA]

P17. Figure 2 provides a flow diagram of the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included. [Yes]

P18. Table 1 provides the characteristics of included studies. [Yes]

P19. No presentation of risk of bias within studies. [No]

P20. Figure 1 and Table 3 present the outcomes for each study. [Yes]

P21. No meta-analysis performed. [NA]

P22. No assessment of risk of bias across studies reported. [NA]

P23. No additional analyses performed. [NA] 

P24. "Overall, the mortality rates are comparable between adults and pediatric patients following EDT. Children who sustain penetrating trauma and have SOL in the emergency department or are without SOL for a short period of time prior to arrival have been salvageable. There are no reported survivors in children less than the age of 14 years who required an EDT after sustaining penetrating trauma." Summarizes the main findings. [Yes]

P25. "There are limitations to this study. First, all of the data obtained from our institution were collected retrospectively, and thus not specifically collected for research purposes. As for all data reviewed, some of the variables may have been missing or misclassified. Also, differences in trauma management between physicians and institutions may not allow for generalizations to be made." Discusses limitations. [Yes]

P26. "Continued evaluation of this technique is warranted to develop adequate guidelines." Provides a general interpretation and implications for future research. [Yes]

P27. "* Corresponding author at: Division of Pediatric Surgery, DeWitt-Daughtry Family Department of Surgery, University of Miami Miller School of Medicine, 1120 NW 14th Street, Suite 450K, Miami, FL 33136. Tel.: +1 305 243 5072." Reports the funding source for the systematic review. [Yes]

A11. No reporting of conflicts of interest for the included studies. The funding source for the systematic review itself is reported. [No]

Here is the assessment of the systematic review's reporting quality based on PRISMA:

P1. "Pediatric emergency department thoracotomy: A large case series and systematic review" The title identifies the article as a systematic review. [Yes]

P2. The abstract is structured with labeled sections for Background/purpose, Methods, Results, and Conclusion. However, some details like data sources and study appraisal methods are missing. [No]

P3. "Trauma remains the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children and adolescents [1,2]. By recognizing this, care of the injured child has improved with aggressive efforts to standardize treatment." Provides rationale for the review in the context of trauma morbidity and mortality in children. [Yes]

P4. "To address this issue, we reviewed our experience at a level 1 trauma center and report the largest analysis over the past 25 years. In conjunction, we performed a systematic review of all published reports regarding pediatric EDT and combined the data from those reports with the data from our institution" Specifies the review questions being addressed. [Yes]

P5. No mention of a review protocol or registration. [No]

P6. "These reports obtained from a Medline search for all publications regarding EDT in the pediatric population for the past 40 year using the keywords "thoracotomy", "emergency", "trauma", "resuscitation", "pediatrics", and "children"." Specifies study eligibility criteria and rationale. [Yes]

P7. "We searched PubMed, MEDLINE, and Embase by using the key words "pediatrics", and "children". Bibliographies of relevant publications were reviewed to identify reports that were not initially located with the Medline search." Describes information sources and dates searched. [Yes]

P8. The full search strategy is not provided such that it could be repeated. [No]

P9. "These reports obtained from a Medline search for all publications regarding EDT in the pediatric population for the past 40 year using the keywords "thoracotomy", "emergency", "trauma", "resuscitation", "pediatrics", and "children". Bibliographies of relevant publications were reviewed to identify reports that were not initially located with the Medline search." Describes the study selection process. [Yes]

P10. No description of the data collection process. [No]

P11. Table 1 lists the variables for which data were extracted. [Yes]  

P12. No description of assessing risk of bias in individual studies. [No]

P13. No summary measures specified. [No]

P14. No description of methods for combining results. [NA]

P15. No assessment of risk of bias across studies. [NA]

P16. No additional analyses performed. [NA]

P17. Figure 2 provides a flow diagram of the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included. [Yes]

P18. Table 1 provides the characteristics of included studies. [Yes]

P19. No presentation of risk of bias within studies. [No]

P20. Figure 1 and Table 3 present the outcomes for each study. [Yes]

P21. No meta-analysis performed. [NA]

P22. No assessment of risk of bias across studies reported. [NA]

P23. No additional analyses performed. [NA] 

P24. "Overall, the mortality rates are comparable between adults and pediatric patients following EDT. Children who sustain penetrating trauma and have SOL in the emergency department or are without SOL for a short period of time prior to arrival have been salvageable. There are no reported survivors in children less than the age of 14 years who required an EDT after sustaining penetrating trauma." Summarizes the main findings. [Yes]

P25. "There are limitations to this study. First, all of the data obtained from our institution were collected retrospectively, and thus not specifically collected for research purposes. As for all data reviewed, some of the variables may have been missing or misclassified. Also, differences in trauma management between physicians and institutions may not allow for generalizations to be made." Discusses limitations. [Yes]

P26. "Continued evaluation of this technique is warranted to develop adequate guidelines." Provides a general interpretation and implications for future research. [Yes]

P27. "* Corresponding author at: Division of Pediatric Surgery, DeWitt-Daughtry Family Department of Surgery, University of Miami Miller School of Medicine, 1120 NW 14th Street, Suite 450K, Miami, FL 33136. Tel.: +1 305 243 5072." Reports the funding source for the systematic review. [Yes]

llm_message:
A1
Quotes: "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)."
Reasoning: The authors state that the review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol that was registered, indicating an a priori design.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK). Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion."
Reasoning: Study selection and data extraction were done independently by two investigators with a process for resolving conflicts, meeting the criteria.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "All study designs except expert opinion were included, and no restrictions were made on the basis of study language or geographical location. Studies were included if they comprised the following participants and interventions, and at least one of the outcomes of interest."
"previously published literature and expert opinion. Multiple search strategies were used to identify relevant articles from Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar, published between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2012. Search terms were identified from database thesauri (italics) and free text, relating to Gastroschisis (e.g. Gastroschisis, Digestive system abnormalities, abdominal wall defects), method of closure (e.g. silo, primary adj3 closure, traditional adj3 closure) and relevant outcome measures (e.g. hospital+ ischaemic bowel, complications), and were combined using Boolean operators."
Reasoning: The authors searched multiple electronic databases, provided search terms, and supplemented the search with other sources like Google Scholar.
[Yes]

A4
Quotes: "All study designs except expert opinion were included, and no restrictions were made on the basis of study language or geographical location."
Reasoning: The authors explicitly state that no restrictions were made based on publication status or language.
[Yes]

A5
Quotes: "Using the stated search strategy, 3081 papers were identified. After removal of duplicates, 751 unique articles remained. From this, 8 papers were deemed to meet the inclusion criteria, all of which were cohort studies (Fig. 1). No randomised controlled trials were identified that met the inclusion criteria. All papers bar one were published in English language journals. One Spanish paper was translated. Unpublished data were obtained from two authors [2, 9]."
Reasoning: The authors provide a flow diagram showing the number of included and excluded studies at each stage. The excluded studies are not explicitly listed but the reasons for exclusion at each stage are provided.
[Yes]

A6
Quotes: "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR. The largest study was Owen 2010 [2] with 290 eligible patients. The majority of the remaining studies included fewer than 50 participants (Table 2)."
"Although reporting of baseline characteristics was variably done by the included studies, where it was reported, there were no statistically significant differences in birth-weight, gestational age, or associated anomalies between the OPFC and SR groups."
Reasoning: The authors provide aggregate data on the number of participants and interventions in each included study in Table 2. They also comment on the reporting of baseline characteristics.
[Yes]

A7
Quotes: "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK). Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion. Where required, unpublished data were requested from the authors of each of the included studies to allow for meta-analysis."
"Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
Reasoning: The authors used the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria to assess the quality and risk of bias of the included studies.
[Yes]

A8
Quotes: "Despite showing some benefit of OPFC over SR, our results are tempered by the low quality of the available studies, which were small and variably reported. Coordinating research through a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could alleviate many of these problems. A similar national approach could be used in other smaller surgical specialties."
Reasoning: The authors appropriately consider the low quality of the included studies when formulating their conclusions and recommendations.
[Yes]

A9
Quotes: "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout. Dichotomous outcomes were meta-analysed using Mantel–Haenszel fixed effects methods to produce summary odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Continuous variables were meta-analysed using the inverse-variance fixed-effect method to produce weighted mean differences and 95% confidence intervals. All analyses were performed using Review Manager 5.2 (Copenhagen: The Nordic Cochrane Centre, The Cochrane Collaboration, 2012.)"
Reasoning: The authors assessed heterogeneity and used appropriate fixed-effect methods to combine the study results in meta-analysis.
[Yes]

A10
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors did not assess publication bias, likely because there were fewer than 10 included studies, making assessment not feasible.
[NA] 

A11
Quotes: "Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorship. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (http:// www.nihr.ac.uk/Pages/default.aspx). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript."
Reasoning: The authors declare the source of funding for the systematic review. However, they do not report sources of support for each of the included primary studies.
[No]

P1
Quotes: "Challenges of Improving the Evidence Base in Smaller Surgical Specialties, as Highlighted by a Systematic Review of Gastroschisis Management"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
Quotes: The abstract contains labeled sections for Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusions.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with the required sections.
[Yes]

P3
Quotes: "With variation existing around the specifics of management of some of the most common neonatal surgical conditions including oesophageal atresia, gastroschisis and Hirschsprung's disease, research should be commonplace. Yet despite these fertile conditions for research, for these three conditions, only fourteen prospectively registered clinical trials and two systematic reviews could be identified on a search of the major registries at the time of writing (Table 1). Whilst both the low incidence of many of the studied conditions, and the difficulties in gaining ethical approval are at least in part responsible for the lack of paediatric surgical research, we do not believe that they account for the whole story."
Reasoning: The authors describe the rationale for the review in the context of the lack of research on common neonatal surgical conditions despite variation in management practices.
[Yes]

P4
Quotes: "Using a systematic review and meta-analysis of gastroschisis as an example, we aimed to highlight some of the key challenges in paediatric surgical research, and suggest ways in which the strength of our clinical evidence base could be improved."
Reasoning: The objective is stated, although it does not explicitly reference the PICOS elements.
[Yes]

P5
Quotes: "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)."
Reasoning: The authors state that a protocol exists and provide the registration number and database where it can be accessed.
[Yes]

P6
Quotes: "Studies were included if they involved infants born with simple gastroschisis, defined as gastroschisis with an intact continuous bowel that is not compromised or breached at delivery or presentation. Infants with complex gastroschisis, defined as the presence of at least one of intestinal perforation, necrosis, or atresia were excluded from this review, as they only account for approximately 11.5% of infants with gastroschisis, are known to have a worse prognosis than the majority with simple gastroschisis [2], and thus represent a major confounder in any examination of the outcomes of different management techniques."
Reasoning: The authors specify the study characteristics (participants, interventions) used as eligibility criteria along with a rationale.
[Yes]

P7
Quotes: "previously published literature and expert opinion. Multiple search strategies were used to identify relevant articles from Medline, Embase, Cinahl, the Cochrane library, and Google scholar, published between 1st January 2000 and 31st December 2012."
Reasoning: The authors describe the information sources searched, including the databases and date ranges.
[Yes]

P8
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not present the full electronic search strategy for any of the databases.
[No]

P9
Quotes: "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK). Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion."
Reasoning: The authors state the process for selecting studies, including the number of reviewers and how disagreements were resolved.
[Yes]

P10
Quotes: "Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion. Where required, unpublished data were requested from the authors of each of the included studies to allow for meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The authors describe the method of data extraction, including the number of reviewers, how disagreements were resolved, and the process for obtaining missing data.
[Yes]

P11
Quotes: "Primary outcome measures:
1. Mortality
2. Length of hospital stay
3. Time to complete enteral feeding/duration of parenteral feeding
Secondary outcome measures:
1. Duration of ventilator use
2. Infective complication
3. Perforation
4. Ischaemic bowel
5. Necrotising Enterocolitis (NEC)
6. Anastomotic stricture
7. Adhesional small bowel obstruction
8. Complications related to stoma
9. Short bowel syndrome
10. Liver disease associated with intestinal failure"
Reasoning: The authors list all the primary and secondary outcomes for which data were sought.
[Yes]

P12
Quotes: "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
Reasoning: The authors describe the methods used to assess risk of bias in the included studies.
[Yes]

P13
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not explicitly state the principal summary measures. However, based on the forest plots, it appears they used odds ratios for dichotomous outcomes and mean differences for continuous outcomes.
[No]

P14
Quotes: "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout. Dichotomous outcomes were meta-analysed using Mantel–Haenszel fixed effects methods to produce summary odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Continuous variables were meta-analysed using the inverse-variance fixed-effect method to produce weighted mean differences and 95% confidence intervals."
Reasoning: The authors describe the methods used to combine the study results, including the assessment of heterogeneity and the use of fixed-effect meta-analysis methods.
[Yes]

P15
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention any assessment of risk of bias across studies, such as publication bias or selective reporting.
[No]

P16
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not describe any additional analyses.
[No]

P17
Quotes: "Using the stated search strategy, 3081 papers were identified. After removal of duplicates, 751 unique articles remained. From this, 8 papers were deemed to meet the inclusion criteria, all of which were cohort studies (Fig. 1). No randomised controlled trials were identified that met the inclusion criteria. All papers bar one were published in English language journals. One Spanish paper was translated. Unpublished data were obtained from two authors [2, 9]."
Reasoning: The authors provide a flow diagram (Figure 1) showing the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.
[Yes]

P18
Quotes: The authors present the characteristics of each included study, including the setting, number of neonates, intervention, and outcomes in Table 2.
Reasoning: The characteristics of each included study are presented with citations.
[Yes]

P19
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors assess the quality and risk of bias of the included studies using STROBE and GRADE, but do not present the results for each individual study.
[No]

P20
Quotes: The authors present forest plots (Figures 2 and 3) showing the results of individual studies for each primary outcome, with odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals.
Reasoning: The results for each individual study are presented for all outcomes, with effect estimates and confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P21
Quotes: The authors present forest plots (Figures 2 and 3) showing the pooled results of the meta-analyses for each primary outcome, with odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals.
Reasoning: The results of each meta-analysis are presented with confidence intervals and measures of consistency (heterogeneity).
[Yes]

P22
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not present any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[No]

P23
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not report any additional analyses.
[No]

P24
Quotes: "All three primary outcome measures appeared to favour the OPFC group over the SR group. Both length of stay and number of post-operative days to complete enteral feeding were clinically and statistically significantly longer in the SR group, with a mean difference of 8.97 days, (95% CI 2.14–15.80 days), and a mean difference of 7.19 days (95%CI 2.01–12.36 days) respectively (Fig. 2). Although the odds of death were raised in the SR group (OR 1.96, 95%CI 0.71–5.35), this difference was not statistically significant (Table 3 and Fig. 2). Results for secondary outcome measures are displayed in Table 3 and Fig. 3."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings for the primary and secondary outcomes, including the strength of evidence based on the effect estimates and confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P25
Quotes: "As is representative of most research in paediatric surgery [14], our meta-analysis was limited by the fact that the majority of studies available for inclusion were small, retrospective case series or cohort studies. Due to the impact of chance and confounding on the results of these studies, it is impossible to generate robust guidelines based upon them. To produce evidence-based guidelines, the type of study used for assessment of any given intervention should progress as described by the IDEAL recommendations [15] through the use of large cohort studies, to the gold standard randomised controlled trial. Doing so not only increases the weight of the conclusions of the primary research, but also of any meta-analysis including them."
Reasoning: The authors discuss several limitations of the review, including the small size and retrospective nature of the included studies, the potential for chance and confounding to impact the results, and the inability to generate robust guidelines based on these studies alone.
[Yes]

P26
Quotes: "Despite showing some benefit of OPFC over SR, our results are tempered by the low quality of the available studies, which were small and variably reported. Coordinating research through a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could alleviate many of these problems. A similar national approach could be used in other smaller surgical specialties."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of the low quality of available evidence and suggest coordinating research through a national approach to address the problems.
[Yes]

P27
Quotes: "Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorship. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (http:// www.nihr.ac.uk/Pages/default.aspx). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript."
Reasoning: The authors describe the sources of funding for the systematic review and the role of the funders.
[Yes]

Quotes: "All three primary outcome measures appeared to favour the OPFC group over the SR group. Both length of stay and number of post-operative days to complete enteral feeding were clinically and statistically significantly longer in the SR group, with a mean difference of 8.97 days, (95% CI 2.14–15.80 days), and a mean difference of 7.19 days (95%CI 2.01–12.36 days) respectively (Fig. 2). Although the odds of death were raised in the SR group (OR 1.96, 95%CI 0.71–5.35), this difference was not statistically significant (Table 3 and Fig. 2). Results for secondary outcome measures are displayed in Table 3 and Fig. 3."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings for the primary and secondary outcomes, including the strength of evidence based on the effect estimates and confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P25
Quotes: "As is representative of most research in paediatric surgery [14], our meta-analysis was limited by the fact that the majority of studies available for inclusion were small, retrospective case series or cohort studies. Due to the impact of chance and confounding on the results of these studies, it is impossible to generate robust guidelines based upon them. To produce evidence-based guidelines, the type of study used for assessment of any given intervention should progress as described by the IDEAL recommendations [15] through the use of large cohort studies, to the gold standard randomised controlled trial. Doing so not only increases the weight of the conclusions of the primary research, but also of any meta-analysis including them."
Reasoning: The authors discuss several limitations of the review, including the small size and retrospective nature of the included studies, the potential for chance and confounding to impact the results, and the inability to generate robust guidelines based on these studies alone.
[Yes]

P26
Quotes: "Despite showing some benefit of OPFC over SR, our results are tempered by the low quality of the available studies, which were small and variably reported. Coordinating research through a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could alleviate many of these problems. A similar national approach could be used in other smaller surgical specialties."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of the low quality of available evidence and suggest coordinating research through a national approach to address the problems.
[Yes]

P27

The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript."
Reasoning: The authors describe the sources of funding for the systematic review and the role of the funders.
[Yes]

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quotes: "The data obtained included number of patients treated, treatment modality employed, effectiveness of each treatment modality, and the outcomes after treatment."
Reasoning: The authors do not state that at least two people independently selected studies and extracted data.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched. All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of descriptive form describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
Reasoning: The authors searched 3 databases and other relevant sources.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: "All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of descriptive form describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
Reasoning: The authors included articles irrespective of publication type.
[Yes]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: See Tables 1-4.
Reasoning: The authors provide aggregated data on patient characteristics, interventions, and outcomes in table format.
[Yes]

[No]

Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not report sources of support for the review or included studies.
[No]

P1. Title
Quotes: "Management of Recurrent Tracheoesophageal Fistulas: A Systematic Review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: See the structured abstract on the first page.
Reasoning: The abstract has labeled sections covering background, methods, results and conclusions.
[Yes]  

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "The spectrum of esophageal atresia (EA) and tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) include an isolated EA, EA with a proximal and/or distal TEF and the "H" or "N" type fistula. Since the initial description of the open surgical repair1 and subsequent thoracoscopic approaches2,3 the outcomes have been very encouraging. Anastomotic leaks, esophageal strictures, gastroesophageal reflux, and tracheomalacia are complications pediatric surgeons are familiar with. The incidence of a fistula recurrence range from 1.9 to 11% after open and thoracoscopic repairs.2,4–8"
Reasoning: The introduction describes the background and rationale for the review.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quotes: "We aim to comparatively review all published treatment options, and outcomes, for managing RTEF."
Reasoning: The objectives are stated, but do not fully reference the PICOS.
[No]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quotes: "All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of descriptive form describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
Reasoning: The authors specify the study characteristics used as eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quotes: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched."
Reasoning: The authors describe the databases and other information sources searched.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quotes: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula."
Reasoning: The authors provide the keywords used but not the full search strategy.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quotes: "All English language articles published by August 2013, irrespective of descriptive form describing the management of, and outcome after, RTEF in children under 18 years were reviewed."
Reasoning: The authors state the process for selecting studies.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quotes: "The data obtained included number of patients treated, treatment modality employed, effectiveness of each treatment modality, and the outcomes after treatment."
Reasoning: The authors describe the data that was extracted but not the method of extraction.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: "The data obtained included number of patients treated, treatment modality employed, effectiveness of each treatment modality, and the outcomes after treatment."
Reasoning: The authors list the data items that were sought.
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing risk of bias in individual studies.
[No]

Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not state the principal summary measures.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quotes: "A synthesis of the data is presented in a descriptive form due to the heterogeneity of the included articles."
Reasoning: The authors describe synthesizing the data descriptively due to heterogeneity.
[Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing risk of bias across studies.
[No]

Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention any additional analyses.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quotes: "A total of 44 papers between 1955 and 2013 described 165 patients; 57 ET and 108 OS. Of the 57 ET patients, there was an 84% success rate compared with 93.5% of 108 OS patients; the failed ET cases were all successfully treated by OS."
Reasoning: The authors provide the number of studies and patients included but not the number screened or reasons for exclusions.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quotes: See Tables 1-4.
Reasoning: The authors present aggregated study characteristics in table format.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not present data on risk of bias within studies.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: See Tables 1-4.
Reasoning: The authors present some individual study data in the tables.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform a meta-analysis.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors did not assess risk of bias across studies.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform any additional analyses.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "OS for RTEF has a low morbidity and mortality, a higher success rate, and requires fewer treatments than an endoscopic repair. The ideal ET is undecided but it remains a viable alternative provided treatment failures are anticipated and prompt redo treatments initiated to prevent ongoing respiratory morbidity."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "This finding should however be interpreted with caution due to the small numbers, particularly in the "sealant only" group (n = 6)."
Reasoning: The authors mention the limitation of small sample sizes in one comparison but do not discuss limitations at the review level.
[No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Minimally invasive techniques are widely accepted to be better tolerated by patients and whenever possible such options should be explored, thus supporting the case for ET; however, the outcomes should be comparable. Several authors have used a variety of techniques for ET, summarized above, all hoping to achieve better outcomes. There have been three literature reviews on ET. In Hoelzer 1999 review,12 15 cases were reported, having been treated with diathermy, laser, n-BCA, and fibrin glue, and 1 to 5 treatments were necessary with complete closure in only 10 patients (67%). Meier et al in 200726 reported an overall success rate of 60% of 62 patients culled from the literature (fibrin glue 55% [n = 22], n-BCA 48% [n = 29], laser 80% [n = 5], diathermy 50% [n = 10], n-BCA + sealant100% [n = 5]); the mean number of applications ranged from 1 to 5.5. They concluded that ET is safe, effective, has less morbidity than OS and recommended fibrin glue but advised close follow-up. Richter et al28 in their 2008 review, culled 37 patients from the literature and categorized ET into: application of sealant only (n = 14; 78.6% success), de-epithelization of the fistula tract only (n = 8; 62.5% success), de-epithelization combined with sealant (n = 15; 93.3%). Overall there was an 81.1% success rate (48.6% after a single attempt) and they concluded that de-epithelization with diathermy combined with fibrin glue sealant will yield the best results; fibrin glue by nature would work better if the opening is small, as it is opposed and not stretched."
Reasoning: The authors provide an interpretation of the results in the context of previous literature reviews.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not describe sources of funding for the review.
[No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "Gastrostomy tube placement remains a highly popular intervention with a number of indications, in both adult and pediatric populations. Since initially introduced in 1986 as an open surgical approach, it has evolved into a procedure performed using multiple different techniques by several different operators, including surgeons, gastroenterologists, endoscopists and interventional radiologists."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Selection of older, heavier children for the open procedure may be explained by the lack of evidence documenting safety of PEG in infants at the time of study completion. The first large pediatric review of PEG in small (<6 kg) neonates with failure to thrive was in 2011 [38]. As there is currently no literature supporting patient age or weight as a predictive factor for success and safety of tube placement, we are unable to draw conclusions on the influence of these discrepancies of baseline demographics on the results."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "The most commonly reported disadvantages of LAP over PEG are increased operative length and cost. Three of the 10 comparative studies commented on operative length, 2 of which reported a statistically significant decrease in operative time in the PEG group compared to LAP. However, Zamakhshary et al. [11] reported cumulative operative time (for the PEG group including conversion to low-profile button under general anesthesia) and reported no significant difference in operative length between the two techniques when this conversion was accounted for (54.4 minutes LAP versus 53.7 minutes PEG). Only one investigation commented on the discrepancy in direct costs between the two insertion techniques. On average, the procedure-related hospital charges during an LAP insertion visit were found to be $1050 higher than in PEG. Given that the study is single institutional and now 10 years out of date, these absolute cost numbers are likely inaccurate and hard to generalize. Increased operative time secondary to inexperience with laparoscopic equipment was the primary contributor to the increased cost affiliated with LAP."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide an interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not reported.
[No]

Reasoning: Table 2 provides some characteristics of the included studies along with citations.
[Yes]

P19
[NA] - Risk of bias assessment of individual studies was not performed (P12).

P20
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not present effect estimates and confidence intervals for each study.
[No]  

P21
[NA] - The review does not appear to include a meta-analysis or quantitative synthesis.

P22
[NA] - The review does not appear to include a meta-analysis or quantitative synthesis.

P23 
[NA] - The review does not appear to include a meta-analysis or quantitative synthesis.

P24
Quote: "The early results of topical Mitomycin C application for the treatment of severe, recurrent esophageal strictures refractory to repeated balloon dilations are encouraging. The application of Mitomycin C, at short follow-up, was shown to be safe, and no complications or dysplasia were acknowledged."
Reasoning: The discussion summarizes the main findings on the safety and short-term efficacy of mitomycin C for esophageal strictures.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Although the etiology causing the stenosis was very heterogeneous, all children were homogenous in that repeated dilations did not show improvement and that none had previously been treated with Mitomycin C."
Reasoning: The authors acknowledge a limitation in the heterogeneity of the included patients.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Questions not yet answered include technical aspects of the proper and safe way of application, the optimal indication, time point of initial treatment, dosage, as well as the number of applications. All patients who undergo topical application of Mitomycin C for esophageal structures should be included in long-term follow-up programs."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation and discuss implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27

Reasoning: The authors report a funding source for the review.

llm_message:
A1 - Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "A computerized comprehensive search supplemented by a manual review of the literature was performed for all peer-reviewed publications comparing laparoscopic and open appendectomy, fundoplication and hernia repair cohorts."
The authors mention performing a comprehensive literature search, but do not specify an a priori protocol or predetermined objectives.
[No]

A2 - Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? 
No relevant quotes found. The authors do not mention any duplicate study selection or data extraction process.
[No]

A3 - Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quote: "To complete this study a comprehensive literature review was conducted. All available electronic databases including the British Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIOSIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and IngentaConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992–2009 for all English and non-English language articles."
The authors searched multiple electronic databases comprehensively.
[Yes]

A4 - Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
No relevant quotes found. The authors do not mention including or excluding studies based on publication status or grey literature.
[No]

A5 - Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria."
The authors report the total number of included studies but do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
[No]

A6 - Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
The authors provide key characteristics of the included studies in an aggregated table.
[Yes] 

A7 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
The authors assessed study quality and provided the ratings in Table 1.
[Yes]

A8 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
No relevant quotes found. The authors do not appear to consider study quality when formulating the conclusions of the review.
[No]

A9 - Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "Meta-analysis was conducted using weighted mean differences (WMD) as the summary statistic, comparing the laparoscopic treatment groups with the reference (open surgery) groups using the Mantel-Haenszel method."
"A negative WMD (less than 0) favored the laparoscopic treatment group, and the point estimate of the WMD was considered statistically significant at the p<0.05 level if the 95% confidence interval did not include the value zero."
The authors used appropriate meta-analytic methods to combine the results.
[Yes]

A10 - Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
No relevant quotes found. The authors do not mention assessing publication bias.
[No]

A11 - Was the conflict of interest included?
No relevant quotes found. The authors do not report sources of funding or conflicts of interest for the review or included studies.
[No]

P1 - Title
Quote: "Pediatric Surgical Technique: Laparoscopic or Open Approach? A systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"  
The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2 - Abstract / Structured summary
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for Introduction, Method/Design, Results, and Conclusion, covering the key elements.
[Yes]

P3 - Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "As in adult surgery, laparoscopy has become an integral part of pediatric surgical practice [6–8,18]. One study in 1998 surveyed pediatric surgeons in the United States and Canada to determine the extent of incorporation of laparo-scopic techniques into their practice, with an estimated 82% of surgeons utilizing this approach [6]."
The authors describe the rationale for the review in the context of the increasing use of laparoscopy in pediatric surgery.
[Yes]

P4 - Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The laparoscopic treatment of pediatric populations remains controversial. In order to evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of this surgical approach a number of outcome measures for laparoscopic and open techniques were analyzed in a comparative fashion."
The objectives are stated, although without explicit reference to PICOS elements.
[Yes]

P5 - Methods / Protocol and registration
No relevant quotes found. The authors do not mention a published protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6 - Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Given the breadth of minimally invasive procedures performed in practice, this review focused on three specific procedures for which outcome data exists: Laparoscopic appendectomy, Laparoscopic fundoplication (anti-reflux procedure) and Laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair."
The authors specify the procedures of interest but do not fully describe the eligibility criteria in terms of PICOS.
[No]

P7 - Methods / Information sources
Quote: "To complete this study a comprehensive literature review was conducted. All available electronic databases including the British Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIOSIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and IngentaConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992–2009 for all English and non-English language articles."
The authors describe the electronic databases searched and date ranges.
[Yes]

P8 - Methods / Search
Quote: "The keywords used during the search were: "endoscopic surgery, fundoplication, appendectomy and appendectomy, inguinal hernia, outcomes, minimally invasive surgery, laparoscopy, endoscopy, laparotomy, open surgery, effectiveness, costs, cost-effectiveness, paediatric and pediatric, infant and neonate". No limits were used. Further searches were performed to obtain articles from the bibliographic sections of the studies identified from the original electronic database search."
The authors provide the keywords used for the search but not the full search strategies.
[No]

P9 - Methods / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria."
The number of included studies is reported but the selection process is not described in detail.
[No]  

P10 - Methods / Data collection process
No relevant quotes found. The data collection process is not described.
[No]

P11 - Methods / Data items
Quote: "These outcome measures included: Length of stay (LOS) after the procedure, Operating room (OR) time, Frequency of postoperative complications and Total hospital costs."
The authors list the outcome variables that data was sought for.
[Yes]

P12 - Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
The authors assessed study quality which relates to risk of bias.
[Yes]

P13 - Methods / Summary measures
Quote: "Meta-analysis was conducted using weighted mean differences (WMD) as the summary statistic, comparing the laparoscopic treatment groups with the reference (open surgery) groups using the Mantel-Haenszel method."
The authors specify the principal summary measure (weighted mean difference).
[Yes]

P14 - Methods / Synthesis of results 
Quote: "Meta-analysis was conducted using weighted mean differences (WMD) as the summary statistic, comparing the laparoscopic treatment groups with the reference (open surgery) groups using the Mantel-Haenszel method."
The meta-analysis methods are described.
[Yes]

P15 - Methods / Risk of bias across studies
No relevant quotes found. Assessment of risk of bias across studies, such as publication bias, is not mentioned.
[No]

P16 - Methods / Additional analyses
No relevant quotes found. No additional analyses are mentioned.
[NA]

P17 - Results / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria."
The number of included studies is provided but a flow diagram is not included.
[No]

P18 - Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
Study characteristics are provided in an aggregated table.
[Yes]

P19 - Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
Results of the study quality assessment are reported in Table 1.
[Yes]

P20 - Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: "Individual study LOS and OR time outcome data for laparoscopic and open appendectomy procedures are summarized in Fig. 1, 2, respectively."
"Of the 16 studies, 13 measured LOS and 12 showed a reduction in LOS for the laparoscopic group ranging from 0.1 to 5.5 days; only 1 study reported an increase for the LA group of 1 day."
Forest plots and a narrative summary are provided for the individual study results on key outcomes.
[Yes]

P21 - Results / Synthesis of results
Quote: "Meta-analysis was conducted using weighted mean differences (WMD) as the summary statistic, comparing the laparoscopic treatment groups with the reference (open surgery) groups using the Mantel-Haenszel method."
Meta-analysis results are reported, including forest plots with confidence intervals and p-values.
[Yes]

P22 - Results / Risk of bias across studies
No relevant quotes found. Results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies are not reported.
[NA]

P23 - Results / Additional analysis
No relevant quotes found. No additional analyses were mentioned.
[NA]

P24 - Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "Clearly, LOS is significantly reduced in favor of the laparoscopic approach, with an overall weighted mean difference for LOS of −1.44 days (95% CI, −1.89 to −0.99, p<0.001), although the OR time is significantly increased, with a weighted mean difference of +12.8 min (95% CI, +3.7 to +21.9, p=0.006), favoring the open surgical technique."
The authors summarize the main findings for the key outcomes.
[Yes]

P25 - Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "The validity of the results of this review largely depends on the validity of the included studies. Many of the included studies failed to take all the steps necessary to avoid bias. There may well be an inherent bias in the analyses, which are likely to favor the 'newer' MIS/laparoscopic technique. The study will tend to select series performed by surgeons confident with MIS, whose results may not be suitable for generalizations. Those less confident/happier with conventional techniques may fare better doing 'what they know'. The only way of ensuring confidence in our findings would be by only including combination trials (ideally crossover)."
The authors discuss several important limitations of the review.
[Yes]

P26 - Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "This review strengthens the use of MIS in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three laparoscopic procedures reviewed showed better patient outcomes compared to open procedures in the form of reduced LOS and complication rates."
The authors provide a general interpretation of the results.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
No relevant quotes found. Sources of funding for the systematic review are not reported.
[No]
