llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol, ethics approval, or a priori objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Two additional papers were included from references (n = 2)"
Reasoning: Implies at least study selection was done in duplicate.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "The indexed reference libraries EMBASE and Medline were searched between January 1955 and January 2013 using the search terms presented in Table 1, using mapped and exploded terms. Additionally, the references of all included studies, the Cochrane Library and the titles of papers published in the journal Obesity Surgery from January 1992 till January 2013 were searched. Only papers written in English were retrieved."
Reasoning: At least 2 databases plus reference checking and additional sources were searched.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "A total of 2303 unique citations were returned by the search strategy (Fig. 1). Of these, 2185 were excluded based on abstract review. Two additional papers were included from references (n = 2)"
Reasoning: A flow diagram with numbers of included and excluded studies was provided, but not a full list.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "In total, 637 patients from 23 studies were included in the meta-analysis. There were significant decreases in BMI at 1 year (average weighted mean BMI difference: −13.5 kg m−2; 95% confidence interval [CI] −14.1 to −11.9). Complications were inconsistently reported. There was some evidence of co-morbidity resolution and improvements in HRQoL post-surgery."
Reasoning: Some aggregate characteristics were provided but not in table format for each study.
[No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "We also conducted a number of sensitivity analyses to examine whether change in BMI was effected by (i) the refinement of surgical techniques as publication date increased; (ii) gender and (iii) greater pre-surgery BMI."
Reasoning: Sensitivity analyses were conducted but no formal quality assessment of each study was reported.
[No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Reasoning: Quality was not assessed (see A7), so could not be incorporated into conclusions.
[NA]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quote: "Formulas outlined in the Cochrane Guidelines were used to derive necessary statistics or process individual data from each of the studies included in the meta-analysis (20). Median BMI estimates were not included in our review as variances are needed to meta-analyse data."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine the studies.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: None relevant. 
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the review and included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Bariatric surgery for obese children and adolescents: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: Identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quote: The abstract contains labeled Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion sections summarizing the key elements.
Reasoning: Provides a structured summary with the required elements.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "The global prevalence of obesity is rising in children and adolescents (1). In the United Kingdom, e.g. among individuals aged 11–15 years, the prevalence was 14.7% in 1995 and 18.3% in the 2010 round of the National Child Measurement Programme (2). The largest increases in body mass index (BMI) are seen in the top 5% of the BMI distribution (3). Treatment guidelines for obese children from National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) recommend lifestyle intervention support, assessment of co-morbidities, and referral to secondary care if morbidities are present (3,4). Children and adolescents for whom lifestyle change and standard clinical care are ineffective in reducing BMI are increasingly being considered for bariatric surgery, which encompasses a number of different surgical procedures (4)."
Reasoning: Describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "We aimed to (i) systematically review the literature on bariatric surgery in children and adolescents; (ii) meta-analyse change in BMI 1 year post-surgery and (iii) report complications, co-morbidity resolution and health-related quality of life (HRQoL)."
Reasoning: Provides an explicit statement of the review questions and inclusion criteria.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Examination of other gastric procedures, including VBG and jejunoileal bypass methods, were excluded as they are not currently recommended for use in paediatric populations (7,19). Study populations defined by specific causes of obesity were excluded. Because of the high possibility of selection bias, non-sequential case series and studies with less than 10 individuals were excluded. In non-randomized controlled trials (non-RCTs), only data from the surgical groups was considered."
Reasoning: Specifies the study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "The indexed reference libraries EMBASE and Medline were searched between January 1955 and January 2013 using the search terms presented in Table 1, using mapped and exploded terms. Additionally, the references of all included studies, the Cochrane Library and the titles of papers published in the journal Obesity Surgery from January 1992 till January 2013 were searched. Only papers written in English were retrieved."
Reasoning: Describes the databases searched and date last searched, plus additional information sources.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quote: Table 1 provides the search terms used for EMBASE and Medline.
Reasoning: The full search strategy is provided for the two main databases.
[Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Studies were included if (i) they assessed BMI before and a minimum of six months after individuals predominately received AGB, RYGB, BPD or SG and (ii) the mean age of the population was between 6 and 18 years at study entry (18)."
Reasoning: States the process for selecting studies based on the eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quote: "We used a standard data extraction method to collect the following information on each study: years during which the surgery was performed, authors, country, study design, mean age and variance of study participants, type of surgery, gender distribution, complications, co-morbidities, pre-/post-surgery BMI with variance and number of participants, length of follow-up and loss to follow-up. Two authors independently screened the abstracts and extracted data was verified by a second author (JAB and RKS)."
Reasoning: Describes the method of data extraction, done in duplicate.
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quote: "We used a standard data extraction method to collect the following information on each study: years during which the surgery was performed, authors, country, study design, mean age and variance of study participants, type of surgery, gender distribution, complications, co-morbidities, pre-/post-surgery BMI with variance and number of participants, length of follow-up and loss to follow-up."
Reasoning: Lists the data items sought from each study.
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies were specified.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quote: "The summary effect measure of unstandardized change in BMI at the time point closest to 12 months post-surgery was produced using the DerSimonian and Laird random effects method (21). The effect of heterogeneity was quantified using the I2 measure and a test for heterogeneity (22)."
Reasoning: Specifies the main summary measures.
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Reasoning: Meta-analysis methods were not described in detail. Measures of consistency were not specified.
[No]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No methods for assessing risk of bias across studies were specified.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quote: "We also conducted a number of sensitivity analyses to examine whether change in BMI was effected by (i) the refinement of surgical techniques as publication date increased; (ii) gender and (iii) greater pre-surgery BMI. Funnel plots and Egger's test were used to evaluate publication bias and small study effects."
Reasoning: Describes the additional sensitivity analyses performed.
[Yes]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 2303 unique citations were returned by the search strategy (Fig. 1). Of these, 2185 were excluded based on abstract review. Two additional papers were included from references (n = 2)"
Reasoning: Provides a flow diagram with the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "In total, 637 patients from 23 studies were included in the meta-analysis. There were significant decreases in BMI at 1 year (average weighted mean BMI difference: −13.5 kg m−2; 95% confidence interval [CI] −14.1 to −11.9). Complications were inconsistently reported."
Reasoning: Presents some aggregate characteristics of included studies but not for each individual study.
[No]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Reasoning: Risk of bias of individual studies was not assessed (see P12).
[NA]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quote: Figure 2 presents a forest plot with BMI change results for each individual study.
Reasoning: Provides the individual study results with a forest plot.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quote: "A total of 637 patients from 23 studies were included in the meta-analysis. There were significant decreases in BMI at 1 year (average weighted mean BMI difference: −13.5 kg m−2; 95% confidence interval [CI] −14.1 to −11.9)."
Reasoning: Presents the meta-analysis results with confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Risk of bias across studies was not assessed (see P15).
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quote: "We also conducted a number of sensitivity analyses to examine whether change in BMI was effected by (i) the refinement of surgical techniques as publication date increased; (ii) gender and (iii) greater pre-surgery BMI. Funnel plots and Egger's test were used to evaluate publication bias and small study effects. Potential risks to the robustness of the estimates found during these tests are reported in the results."
Reasoning: Reports the results of the additional sensitivity analyses.
[Yes]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "Bariatric surgery in obese children and adolescents is associated with a significant reduction in BMI after 12 months (average weighted mean BMI difference: −13.5 kg m−2; 95% CI −15.1, −11.9). RYGB was associated with the largest reduction in BMI, followed by SG and then AGB."
Reasoning: Summarizes the main findings including the strength of evidence for the main outcome.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "There was some evidence to suggest that bariatric surgery is related to co-morbidity resolution, sleep apnoea, type 2 diabetes and dyslipidaemia, particularly with RYGB surgery. All studies assessing HRQoL showed significant improvements from baseline to post-surgery follow-up."
Reasoning: Discusses some limitations at the review level, such as inconsistent reporting.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "As bariatric surgery seems to be associated with a risk of complications and has the potential to impact on future patterns for a lifetime, a balance must be made between the potential benefits and harms at an individual case level. Surgery access is largely mediated through multidisciplinary teams (e.g. paediatricians, psychologists and dieticians) (42,43), and when applied in this context, bariatric surgery appears to be a viable choice to achieve weight loss in obese adolescents for whom all other interventions have failed. In the absence of higher levels of evidence, results from this systematic review appear to suggest that the potential benefits of surgery for weight loss outweigh the risks. Current guidelines suggest that paediatric-adolescent bariatric care should be handled within the controlled and restricted setting of a multidisciplinary team. However, long-term, prospectively designed studies, with clear inclusion and reporting of effects, side effects, complications and co-morbidity resolution, alongside measures of HRQoL, are needed to more firmly establish the harms and benefits of bariatric surgery in children and adolescents."
Reasoning: Provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quote: "No conflict of interest was declared."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were not described.
[No]

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol, ethics approval, or a priori objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Two additional papers were included from references (n = 2)"
Reasoning: Implies at least study selection was done in duplicate.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "The indexed reference libraries EMBASE and Medline were searched between January 1955 and January 2013 using the search terms presented in Table 1, using mapped and exploded terms. Additionally, the references of all included studies, the Cochrane Library and the titles of papers published in the journal Obesity Surgery from January 1992 till January 2013 were searched. Only papers written in English were retrieved."
Reasoning: At least 2 databases plus reference checking and additional sources were searched.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "A total of 2303 unique citations were returned by the search strategy (Fig. 1). Of these, 2185 were excluded based on abstract review. Two additional papers were included from references (n = 2)"
Reasoning: A flow diagram with numbers of included and excluded studies was provided, but not a full list.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "In total, 637 patients from 23 studies were included in the meta-analysis. There were significant decreases in BMI at 1 year (average weighted mean BMI difference: −13.5 kg m−2; 95% confidence interval [CI] −14.1 to −11.9). Complications were inconsistently reported. There was some evidence of co-morbidity resolution and improvements in HRQoL post-surgery."
Reasoning: Some aggregate characteristics were provided but not in table format for each study.
[No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "We also conducted a number of sensitivity analyses to examine whether change in BMI was effected by (i) the refinement of surgical techniques as publication date increased; (ii) gender and (iii) greater pre-surgery BMI."
Reasoning: Sensitivity analyses were conducted but no formal quality assessment of each study was reported.
[No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Reasoning: Quality was not assessed (see A7), so could not be incorporated into conclusions.
[NA]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quote: "Formulas outlined in the Cochrane Guidelines were used to derive necessary statistics or process individual data from each of the studies included in the meta-analysis (20). Median BMI estimates were not included in our review as variances are needed to meta-analyse data."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine the studies.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: None relevant. 
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the review and included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Bariatric surgery for obese children and adolescents: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: Identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quote: The abstract contains labeled Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion sections summarizing the key elements.
Reasoning: Provides a structured summary with the required elements.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "The global prevalence of obesity is rising in children and adolescents (1). In the United Kingdom, e.g. among individuals aged 11–15 years, the prevalence was 14.7% in 1995 and 18.3% in the 2010 round of the National Child Measurement Programme (2). The largest increases in body mass index (BMI) are seen in the top 5% of the BMI distribution (3). Treatment guidelines for obese children from National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) recommend lifestyle intervention support, assessment of co-morbidities, and referral to secondary care if morbidities are present (3,4). Children and adolescents for whom lifestyle change and standard clinical care are ineffective in reducing BMI are increasingly being considered for bariatric surgery, which encompasses a number of different surgical procedures (4)."
Reasoning: Describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "We aimed to (i) systematically review the literature on bariatric surgery in children and adolescents; (ii) meta-analyse change in BMI 1 year post-surgery and (iii) report complications, co-morbidity resolution and health-related quality of life (HRQoL)."
Reasoning: Provides an explicit statement of the review questions and inclusion criteria.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Examination of other gastric procedures, including VBG and jejunoileal bypass methods, were excluded as they are not currently recommended for use in paediatric populations (7,19). Study populations defined by specific causes of obesity were excluded. Because of the high possibility of selection bias, non-sequential case series and studies with less than 10 individuals were excluded. In non-randomized controlled trials (non-RCTs), only data from the surgical groups was considered."
Reasoning: Specifies the study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "The indexed reference libraries EMBASE and Medline were searched between January 1955 and January 2013 using the search terms presented in Table 1, using mapped and exploded terms. Additionally, the references of all included studies, the Cochrane Library and the titles of papers published in the journal Obesity Surgery from January 1992 till January 2013 were searched. Only papers written in English were retrieved."
Reasoning: Describes the databases searched and date last searched, plus additional information sources.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quote: Table 1 provides the search terms used for EMBASE and Medline.
Reasoning: The full search strategy is provided for the two main databases.
[Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Studies were included if (i) they assessed BMI before and a minimum of six months after individuals predominately received AGB, RYGB, BPD or SG and (ii) the mean age of the population was between 6 and 18 years at study entry (18)."
Reasoning: States the process for selecting studies based on the eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quote: "We used a standard data extraction method to collect the following information on each study: years during which the surgery was performed, authors, country, study design, mean age and variance of study participants, type of surgery, gender distribution, complications, co-morbidities, pre-/post-surgery BMI with variance and number of participants, length of follow-up and loss to follow-up. Two authors independently screened the abstracts and extracted data was verified by a second author (JAB and RKS)."
Reasoning: Describes the method of data extraction, done in duplicate.
[Yes]

Quote: "We used a standard data extraction method to collect the following information on each study: years during which the surgery was performed, authors, country, study design, mean age and variance of study participants, type of surgery, gender distribution, complications, co-morbidities, pre-/post-surgery BMI with variance and number of participants, length of follow-up and loss to follow-up."

Reasoning: Meta-analysis methods were not described in detail. Measures of consistency were not specified.

llm_message:
A1 - Protocol/a priori design:
"We performed a systematic review of the literature on preputial reconstruction (PR) during hypospadias repair to determine the cumulative risk of preputial skin complications and the influence of PR on urethroplasty complications, namely, fistula formation and overall reoperation rate of the repair."
The objectives and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2 - Duplicate study selection and data extraction:
No information provided on whether at least two independent reviewers selected studies and extracted data.
[No]

A3 - Comprehensive literature search:
"A systematic search of the literature published after 06/1995 was performed in 06/2015 using the keyword "hypospadias." Only studies on the outcome of PR in children, defined as dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce or secondary phimosis needing circumcision, were selected. A meta-analysis of studies comparing PR vs. circumcision was performed for the outcomes "hypospadias fistula formation" and "reoperation rate.""
At least 2 databases (MEDLINE/PubMed, Scopus, and The Cochrane library) were searched over a 20-year period using the keyword "hypospadias".
[Yes]

A4 - Grey literature as inclusion criterion:
No information provided on whether grey literature was included or excluded based on publication type.
[No]

A5 - List of included and excluded studies:
"Twenty studies were identified. Nineteen reported the outcome of PR in 2115 patients."
A list of included studies is provided in Table 1, but no list of excluded studies is provided.
[No]

A6 - Characteristics of included studies:
"Characteristics of included studies are detailed in Table 1. The vast majority (13, 65%) were surgical series (LOE 4), three (15%) were retrospective case–control studies (LOE 4), two (10%) were longitudinal cohort studies (LOE 3), and the remaining two (10%) were RCTs (LOE 2)."
Aggregated data on study characteristics is provided.
[Yes]

A7 - Scientific quality assessment of included studies:
"Also the latter, however, were fraught with significant methodological bias such as lack of power analysis, unclear randomization method, and/or lack of blinding."
The scientific quality of included studies was assessed and documented.
[Yes]

A8 - Scientific quality used in formulating conclusions:
"Preputial reconstruction is an option during hypospadias repair, but some authors suggest isolated PR to be the procedure of choice in minor variants of hypospadias in order to conceal the malformation while avoiding the risks associated with urethroplasty."
The results of the quality assessment were considered in the analysis and conclusions.
[Yes]

A9 - Methods to combine findings:
"A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
Appropriate methods were used to combine the findings of studies, including assessment of heterogeneity and use of fixed-effects models.
[Yes]

A10 - Publication bias assessment:
"Funnel Plot did not show evidence of significant bias among studies (Figure 3)."
Publication bias was assessed using a funnel plot.
[Yes]

A11 - Conflict of interest stated:
No information provided on conflict of interest for the systematic review or included studies.
[No]

P1 - Title:
"Does Preputial Reconstruction Increase Complication Rate of Hypospadias Repair? 20-Year Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
The article is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis in the title.
[Yes]

P2 - Structured abstract:
The article has a structured abstract with labeled sections for Introduction, Materials and Methods, Results, and Conclusion.
[Yes]

P3 - Introduction rationale:
"Preputial asymmetry is one of the components of hypospadias. The prepuce stands like a hood over the glans penis, open ventrally, and redundant dorsally. Preputial reconstruction (PR) is an option during hypospadias repair, but many surgeons favor circumcision for the concern that PR might increase the complication rate of hypospadias repair (1)."
The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4 - Introduction objectives:
"We performed a systematic review of the literature on preputial reconstruction (PR) during hypospadias repair to determine the cumulative risk of preputial skin complications and the influence of PR on urethroplasty complications, namely, fistula formation and overall reoperation rate of the repair."
The research question is stated with reference to participants, interventions, and outcomes.
[Yes]

P5 - Methods protocol and registration:
No information provided on a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6 - Methods eligibility criteria:
"Only studies on the outcome of PR in children, defined as dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce or secondary phimosis needing circumcision, were selected."
Study characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.
[Yes]

P7 - Methods information sources:
"A systematic search of the literature published after 06/1995 was performed in 06/2015 using the keyword "hypospadias." Only studies on the outcome of PR in children, defined as dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce or secondary phimosis needing circumcision, were selected."
Information sources and dates searched are described.
[Yes]

P8 - Methods search:
The full search strategy is not presented such that it could be repeated.
[No]

P9 - Methods study selection:
"One-thousand two-hundred thirty records were retrieved by searching MEDLINE/PubMed, 2461 Web of Sciences, and 1 the Cochrane library. Three doctors reviewed separately the abstracts. Papers relevant to the topic of the review were selected by consensus. A second review was performed of these papers and their reference lists."
The process for selecting studies is described.
[Yes]

P10 - Methods data collection process:
No information provided on the method of data extraction.
[No]

P11 - Methods data items:
No information provided on the data items sought.
[No]

P12 - Methods risk of bias in individual studies:
"Also the latter, however, were fraught with significant methodological bias such as lack of power analysis, unclear randomization method, and/or lack of blinding."
Methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies are described.
[Yes]

P13 - Methods summary measures:
"A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97)."
The principal summary measures (odds ratios) are stated.
[Yes]

P14 - Methods synthesis of results:
"A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
The methods for combining results and assessing consistency are described.
[Yes]

P15 - Methods risk of bias across studies:
"Funnel Plot did not show evidence of significant bias among studies (Figure 3)."
Risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence was assessed.
[Yes]

P16 - Methods additional analyses:
"Only two studies including one prospective longitudinal cohort study and one retrospective case–control study compared overall reoperation rate in patients undergoing distal hypospadias repair associated with PR vs. circumcision. Again, a meta-analysis of these (Figure 4) showed no increased risk of reoperation in patients undergoing PR."
Additional analyses (subgroup analyses) were described.
[Yes]

P17 - Results study selection:
"One-thousand two-hundred thirty records were retrieved by searching MEDLINE/PubMed, 2461 Web of Sciences, and 1 the Cochrane library. Three doctors reviewed separately the abstracts. Papers relevant to the topic of the review were selected by consensus. A second review was performed of these papers and their reference lists. In the review, we included only studies reporting data on complications of PR (dehiscence of reconstructed prepuce and phimosis), on urethroplasty complications (fistula formation), and on reoperation rates in patients undergoing hypospadias repair with preservation of the prepuce. Studies including only patients undergoing hypospadias repair associated with circumcision, reporting PR in adults or for conditions other than hypospadias, studies with incomplete data (no separate results reported in patients undergoing PR), duplicate publications, population-based studies, single-case reports, reviews, editorials, letter to the editor, meeting abstracts, book chapters, and experimental studies were excluded."
A flow diagram is provided showing the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included.
[Yes]

P18 - Results study characteristics:
Characteristics of included studies are provided in Table 1.
[Yes]

P19 - Results risk of bias within studies:
"Also the latter, however, were fraught with significant methodological bias such as lack of power analysis, unclear randomization method, and/or lack of blinding."
Results of the risk of bias assessment for individual studies are presented.
[Yes]

P20 - Results of individual studies:
Data for individual studies are provided in Table 2 and Figures 2-4.
[Yes]

P21 - Results synthesis of results:
"A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
Results of the meta-analysis are presented with confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P22 - Results risk of bias across studies:
"Funnel Plot did not show evidence of significant bias among studies (Figure 3)."
Results of the assessment of risk of bias across studies are presented.
[Yes]

P23 - Results additional analyses:
"Only two studies including one prospective longitudinal cohort study and one retrospective case–control study compared overall reoperation rate in patients undergoing distal hypospadias repair associated with PR vs. circumcision. Again, a meta-analysis of these (Figure 4) showed no increased risk of reoperation in patients undergoing PR."
Results of the additional analyses are provided.
[Yes]

P24 - Discussion summary of evidence:
"This systematic review shows that according to available evidence PR carries an 8% risk of specific preputial complications, whereas it does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repairs."
The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25 - Discussion limitations:
"Preputial reconstruction is an option during hypospadias repair, but some authors suggest isolated PR to be the procedure of choice in minor variants of hypospadias in order to conceal the malformation while avoiding the risks associated with urethroplasty. The diverse regions of origin of studies included in present review suggests that the procedure is requested all-over the world and Klijn et al. underlined that the request is growing also in centers where circumcision is offered as first option."
Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26 - Discussion conclusions:
"Preputial reconstruction is an option particularly in patients with distal hypospadias without associated penile curvature. It carries an 8% risk of specific complications, the most common being dehiscence of reconstructed prepuce, whereas secondary phimosis needing circumcision seems to be exceptional although we lack long-term follow-up data on these patients. Overall, PR does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repair."
A general interpretation of the results is provided.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding:
No information provided on sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

Data for individual studies are provided in Table 2 and Figures 2-4.
[Yes]

P21 - Results synthesis of results:
"A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
Results of the meta-analysis are presented with confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P22 - Results risk of bias across studies:
"Funnel Plot did not show evidence of significant bias among studies (Figure 3)."
Results of the assessment of risk of bias across studies are presented.
[Yes]

P23 - Results additional analyses:
"Only two studies including one prospective longitudinal cohort study and one retrospective case–control study compared overall reoperation rate in patients undergoing distal hypospadias repair associated with PR vs. circumcision. Again, a meta-analysis of these (Figure 4) showed no increased risk of reoperation in patients undergoing PR."
Results of the additional analyses are provided.
[Yes]

P24 - Discussion summary of evidence:
"This systematic review shows that according to available evidence PR carries an 8% risk of specific preputial complications, whereas it does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repairs."
The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25 - Discussion limitations:
"Preputial reconstruction is an option during hypospadias repair, but some authors suggest isolated PR to be the procedure of choice in minor variants of hypospadias in order to conceal the malformation while avoiding the risks associated with urethroplasty. The diverse regions of origin of studies included in present review suggests that the procedure is requested all-over the world and Klijn et al. underlined that the request is growing also in centers where circumcision is offered as first option."
Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26 - Discussion conclusions:
"Preputial reconstruction is an option particularly in patients with distal hypospadias without associated penile curvature. It carries an 8% risk of specific complications, the most common being dehiscence of reconstructed prepuce, whereas secondary phimosis needing circumcision seems to be exceptional although we lack long-term follow-up data on these patients. Overall, PR does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repair."
A general interpretation of the results is provided.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding:
No information provided on sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "The aim of this study was to determine, based on a systematic review, the most favorable age at which orchiopexy should be performed."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established a priori.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Two researchers quality assessed each study; comparing the scores for each item on each tool to reach a consensus. If no consensus could be reached, they consulted a third researcher."
"One researcher extracted data from each of the included studies, and a second researcher checked the data for accuracy and completeness."
Reasoning: Study selection and data extraction were done in duplicate with a consensus procedure.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "We conducted electronic searches of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE (1966 onwards), Embase (1980 onwards), and CINAHL (1982 onwards) to find relevant articles."
"We also excluded any editorials and case reviews. We hand-searched the reference lists of relevant articles for additional studies."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases were searched and supplemented by hand searching reference lists.
[Yes]

A4
Quote: "Due to the heterogeneity of the data, we could not conduct a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The authors did not explicitly state that they searched for reports regardless of publication type.
[No]

A5
Quote: "After screening, we quality assessed the 32 remaining studies that met our criteria (Fig. 1). Publication dates ranged from 1974 to 2011."
Reasoning: A flow diagram of included studies was provided, but a list of excluded studies was not.
[No]

A6
Quote: "From there, we were able to reach a conclusion regarding the ideal timing of orchiopexy in cryptorchid children based on the highest quality research available."
Reasoning: Characteristics of the included studies were not provided in an aggregated form.
[No]

A7
Quotes: "We used the Jadad et al. [21] tool to assess the quality of all relevant RCTs. This scale contains seven items, two of which are reverse-scored. The maximum score is 5, with higher scores indicating greater methodological quality."
"We used the MINORS criteria [22] to assess the quality of all relevant non-randomized studies. This tool contains 12 items, each of which can be scored from 0 to 2, for a maximum possible score of 24 (comparison studies) or 16 (non-comparison studies). Higher scores are indicative of greater methodological quality."
Reasoning: The scientific quality of included studies was assessed using the Jadad and MINORS tools.
[Yes]

A8
Quote: "Previous research has shown that testicular location may affect both fertility and malignancy; compared with unilateral undescended testes, intra-abdominal testes were associated with decreased fertility potential [5, 38, 59] and increased malignancy risk [60, 61]."
Reasoning: The results of the methodological quality assessment were considered when formulating conclusions.
[Yes]

A9
Quote: "Due to the heterogeneity of the data, we could not conduct a meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The authors stated they could not combine the studies in a meta-analysis due to heterogeneity.
[Yes]

A10
Quotes: "We did not find any systematic reviews or meta-analyses reporting on the impact of age at orchiopexy on fertility (Table 1)."
"Some studies also reported on semen analysis in adulthood (i.e., sperm count, sperm concentration) [11, 25, 29–32, 35, 37, 38, 40, 41]. The overall consensus was that earlier orchiopexy had better outcomes; specifically, the highest quality study [11] showed that sperm count and highly motile spermatozoa were significantly increased when orchiopexy was performed at <1 year compared to 1–2 years of age."
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed, likely because this was a systematic review without a meta-analysis.
[NA]

A11
Quote: "Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a "yes," must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies."
Reasoning: Sources of funding were not reported for the systematic review or the included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Ideal timing of orchiopexy: a systematic review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: "The ideal management of cryptorchidism is a highly debated topic within the field of pediatric surgery. The optimal timing of orchiopexy is particularly unclear, as existing literature reports mixed recommendations. The aim of this study was to determine, based on a systematic review, the most favorable age at which orchiopexy should be performed. We conducted a systematic search of MEDLINE, Embase, CINAHL, and the Cochrane Library to find relevant articles. Two researchers quality assessed each study using the following tools: AMSTAR (systematic reviews), Jadad (RCTs), and MINORS (non-RCTs). We developed a conclusion based on the highest quality studies. We found one relevant systematic review, one RCT, and 30 non-RCTs. Fertility potential was greatest when orchiopexy was performed before 1 year of age. Additionally, orchiopexy before 10–11 years may protect against the increased risk of testicular cancer associated with cryptorchidism. Orchiopexy should not be performed before 6 months of age, as testes may descend spontaneously during the first few months of life. The highest quality evidence recommends orchiopexy between 6 and 12 months of age. Surgery during this timeframe may optimize fertility potential and protect against testicular malignancy in children with cryptorchidism."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, study appraisal and synthesis methods, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Cryptorchidism, the failure of one or both testes to descend into the scrotum prenatally, occurs in 2.4–5 % of newborns [1, 2]. Many of these testes will descend spontaneously shortly after birth, but approximately 23 % will remain undescended unless surgically corrected [3]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about cryptorchidism.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "The aim of this study was to determine, based on a systematic review, the most favorable age at which orchiopexy should be performed."
Reasoning: The introduction provides an explicit statement of the question being addressed, referencing the population (cryptorchid boys) and intervention (orchiopexy).
[Yes]

P5
Quote: "Potential sources of support should be clearly acknowledged in both the systematic review and the included studies. Note: To get a "yes," must indicate source of funding or support for the systematic review AND for each of the included studies."
Reasoning: The existence of a review protocol is not mentioned.
[No]

P6
Quotes: "We identified experts with proficiency in this area, based on the number of previous publications."
"We included all studies that examined the effect of age at orchiopexy on fertility or malignancy, even if these outcomes were not the primary focus. If we deemed a study relevant based on the title and abstract, we obtained the full text article to further screen for relevance."
Reasoning: The methods section specifies the study characteristics (population, intervention, comparators, outcomes) and report characteristics (no date or language limits mentioned) used as eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

Reasoning: The information sources searched are described but the date last searched is not provided.
[No]

Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented for any of the databases searched.
[No]

P9
Quotes: "After screening, we quality assessed the 32 remaining studies that met our criteria (Fig. 1)."

Reasoning: The study selection process is described, including screening by two independent researchers with a consensus procedure.

Quotes: "The ideal timing of orchiopexy for cryptorchidism has long been debated. Although the recommended age for this surgery has decreased over the years, the literature is still unclear about the exact age at which orchiopexy should be performed to optimize patient outcomes."

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "Our objective was to compare the outcomes of these procedures in a systematic review and meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The objective is stated, but there is no mention of a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-registered research objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Two researchers independently assessed each study and compared their scores for each item to reach a consensus. If an agreement could not be reached, they consulted a third researcher."
Reasoning: Two researchers independently performed study selection and compared their results to reach consensus, with a third researcher consulted if needed.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "To identify all studies comparing MIS with open surgery for CDH repair, we conducted an electronic search of MEDLINE (1966 onwards), Embase (1980 onwards), and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL). We used the keywords "diaphragmatic hernia", "thoracoscopy", "laparoscopy", "minimally invasive surgery", and "open". We excluded any studies that did not pertain to humans and children. We also excluded editorials, case reviews, and any studies that did not compare outcomes of MIS with open surgery for Bochdalek-type hernia."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases were searched with keywords provided. Additional sources like current contents, textbooks, or experts were not mentioned.
[No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quote: "We excluded any studies that did not pertain to humans and children. We also excluded editorials, case reviews, and any studies that did not compare outcomes of MIS with open surgery for Bochdalek-type hernia."
Reasoning: Exclusion based on publication type is mentioned, but no explicit statement about including grey literature.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: "Our initial search of MEDLINE, Embase and CENTRAL yielded 160 studies (Fig. 1). After applying our exclusion criteria, 9 studies remained. We identified one additional relevant study through hand-searching, thus we included 10 studies in total [8–17]."
Reasoning: A flow diagram of study selection is provided, but no list of excluded studies is given.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "We did not identify any randomized controlled trials (RCTs) as all identified studies were retrospective in nature. Characteristics of studies included in the meta-analysis are detailed in Table 1."
Reasoning: Study characteristics are provided in an aggregated table (Table 1).
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Two researchers independently assessed each study for methodological quality using MINORS. The score for each study is reported in Table 1. All studies were retrospective in nature and none employed a blinding technique for data collection."
Reasoning: Study quality was assessed using the MINORS tool by two independent researchers and scores are reported.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quote: "Our pooled analysis revealed that MIS had a significantly longer operative time than open surgery (mean difference 58.71 min [42.03, 69.39] p < 0.001, Fig. 3F). This finding was consistent even when we performed a subgroup analysis with only the studies that reported follow-up time ≥12 months [10–12,14] (OR 3.21 [1.12, 9.18] p = 0.03, Fig. 3E)."
Reasoning: The results take into account the quality of included studies by performing subgroup analyses with higher quality studies.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "We used a fixed-effects model. When heterogeneity was moderate to high (Q test p > 0.10, I2 > 50%), we used a random-effects model [7]. We used weighted mean differences to analyze continuous data and odds ratios to analyze categorical variables."
"Heterogeneity: Chi2 = 6.51, df = 5 (P = 0.26); I2 = 23%"
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine study findings based on heterogeneity assessment. Heterogeneity statistics are reported for each meta-analysis.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quote: "To address the risk of publication bias, we created a funnel plot for the recurrence outcome (Fig. 2). All of the studies fell within the 95% confidence interval lines, although the plot was slightly asymmetrical, indicating the possibility of publication bias."
Reasoning: Publication bias was assessed using a funnel plot for one of the main outcomes (recurrence).
[Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quote: Not applicable, as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis.
Reasoning: Conflict of interest is not mentioned for the systematic review itself or the included studies.
[No]

Quote: "Traditionally, CDH repair was performed using an open approach, most often by laparotomy. Quote: See Figure 1 flow diagram.

Reasoning: The MINORS tool was used to assess risk of bias in the included studies.
[Yes]

Quote: "Our primary outcome of interest was hernia recurrence after surgery. Secondary outcomes included operative time, total length of stay (LOS), postoperative ventilator time and postoperative mortality."
Reasoning: The main outcome measures are stated.

Reasoning: The methods for meta-analysis are not described as no meta-analysis was done.

[Yes]

Reasoning: The characteristics of included studies are provided in Table 1.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quote: "Two researchers independently assessed each study for methodological quality using MINORS. The score for each study is reported in Table 1. All studies were retrospective in nature and none employed a blinding technique for data collection."
Reasoning: The risk of bias assessment for each included study is reported.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quote: See Figures 3A-I.
Reasoning: Forest plots showing the results for individual studies are provided for each outcome.
[Yes]

Reasoning: No meta-analysis results are presented.
[NA]

Reasoning: The results of the publication bias assessment are not reported.
[NA]

Quote: Not applicable, as no additional analyses were performed.
Reasoning: No additional analyses were mentioned in the methods, so no results are expected.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "Our analysis revealed that MIS was associated with a higher recurrence rate which is consistent with the findings from Lansdale et al. [3]. Furthermore, they did not perform a separate analysis for patients requiring patch repair. We have conducted a more comprehensive review, in which we include the 3 studies originally reviewed by Lansdale et al., as well as 7 additional studies that have been published in the last 2 years."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including their consistency with previous evidence.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "Despite the growing popularity of minimally invasive techniques in pediatric surgery, research comparing MIS versus open repair of CDH is scarce. All existing literature is retrospective in design and is thus limited by weaknesses such as selection bias. RCTs are regarded as the highest quality clinical evidence; however it would be difficult, if not impossible, to conduct such studies in this patient group."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Our review was significantly longer for MIS than for open surgery. This is consistent with the findings from Lansdale et al. [3]. Operative time was significantly longer for MIS than open surgery. This may be related to the technical difficulty of the MIS procedure, and while operative time can be reduced with surgeon experience, it is unlikely that MIS will ever be as fast as open surgery."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quote: Not mentioned
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "We used the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis (PRISMA) statement to report our findings."
Reasoning: The authors mention using PRISMA to report their findings, but do not explicitly state that they established the research question and inclusion criteria a priori.
[No]

A2
Quotes: "Hsu and Chang independently searched and reviewed the articles. When discrepancies occurred over the results, discussions with a third author (Yang) were made to reach a consensus."
"The obtained data were analyzed with Cochrane Collaboration Review Manager (RevMan®, version 5.3)."
Reasoning: The authors mention that two authors independently searched and reviewed articles, with a third author resolving discrepancies, and they used Cochrane software for the analysis, suggesting duplicate study selection and data extraction.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "We searched PubMed® for comparative studies (from January 1990 to 2014 September) that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic versus open pyeloplasty. Searches were limited to studies published in English. We used the following keywords: robotic, pyeloplasty, ureteropelvic junction obstruction, children, and pediatric."
Reasoning: The authors searched PubMed and provided the search terms, but only searched one database and did not mention supplementing the electronic search.
[No]

A4
Reasoning: The authors do not mention searching for grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5
Reasoning: The authors provide a flowchart (Fig. 1) showing the number of studies included and excluded at each stage, but do not provide a list of the excluded studies.
[No]

A6
Quote: "Totally, seven retrospective comparative trials [9–15] and three studies [4, 16, 17] using national database were included. The demographic data of the patients in the 10 included trials are shown in Table 1."
Reasoning: The authors provide the characteristics of the included studies in an aggregated form in Table 1.
[Yes]

A7
Quotes: "Two authors of this paper, Hsu and Chang, evaluated the quality of the study."
"We extracted the following information from each study: study population characteristics, study design, inclusion and exclusion criteria, operation method, surgical approach, days of hospital stay, complication rate, follow-up period, and assessment of success rate."
Reasoning: The authors mention assessing study quality and extracting information on study design and methods, but do not provide the results of the quality assessment for each study.
[No]

A8
Reasoning: The authors do not appear to have assessed the scientific quality of the included studies, so this item is not applicable.
[NA]

A9
Quotes: "The meta-analysis was performed using the Review Manager® statistical software (Version 5.3, Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, England)."
"We analyzed the dichotomous outcomes using risk ratios (RRs) as the summary statistic. Chi-square statistical tests (Q statistics) and the I2 test were used to test the heterogeneity between the trials. Studies without mean values and standard deviation for continuous variables were not included for calculation. The parameters with mean value and 95 % confidence interval were transformed into mean values with standard deviation for calculation of weighted mean difference."
Reasoning: The authors used Review Manager software to perform the meta-analysis, used appropriate summary statistics, and assessed heterogeneity using Chi-square and I2 tests.
[Yes]

A10
Quote: "We analyzed the possible publication bias by generating funnel plots of the trials used for all of the evaluated comparisons of outcomes. No clear bias was apparent."
Reasoning: The authors assessed publication bias using funnel plots.
[Yes]

A11
Reasoning: The authors do not report the sources of funding or conflicts of interest for the included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Comparing the efficacy and safety between robotic-assisted versus open pyeloplasty in children: a systemic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quotes: The abstract includes structured sections with background, methods, results, and conclusions.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured and includes the required elements.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Open dismembered pyeloplasty remained the best standard treating children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJO) despite the introduction of minimal invasive therapy. The progress of this technique had shifted from standard laparoscopic (LP), mini-laparoscopic, robotic-assisted pyeloplasty (RP), and laparoendoscopic single-site incision (LESS) to robotic LESS pyeloplasty [1]. The technique of laparoscopic pyeloplasty had been introduced for two decades [2]. A recent systemic review and meta-analysis revealed that laparoscopic pyeloplasty required longer time than open method though it had comparable efficacy, safety, and better consensus [3]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about pyeloplasty techniques in children.
[Yes]

P4
Reasoning: The authors do not provide an explicit statement of the review questions with reference to PICOS.
[No]

P5
Quote: "We used the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis (PRISMA) statement to report our findings."
Reasoning: The authors mention using the PRISMA statement, but do not indicate if a review protocol exists or where it can be accessed.
[No]

P6
Quote: "We searched PubMed® for comparative studies (from January 1990 to 2014 September) that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic versus open pyeloplasty. Searches were limited to studies published in English."
Reasoning: The authors specify the databases, date range, and language of the search, but do not fully describe the study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria.
[No]

P7
Quote: "We searched PubMed® for comparative studies (from January 1990 to 2014 September) that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic versus open pyeloplasty."
Reasoning: The authors describe searching PubMed up to September 2014, but do not mention other information sources.
[No]

P8
Reasoning: The authors do not present the full electronic search strategy for any database.
[No]

P9
Quote: "The following criteria were used to filter studies for our analysis: randomized controlled trials or comparative studies that compared children who received either robotic or open dismembered pyeloplasty for ureteropelvic junction obstruction with data on perioperative parameters, complication rate, and success rate."
Reasoning: The authors describe the criteria used to select studies for inclusion, but do not fully describe the process of study selection.
[No]

P10
Reasoning: The authors do not describe the method of data extraction in detail.
[No]

P11
Reasoning: The authors do not provide a list of all variables for which data were sought.
[No]

P12
Reasoning: The authors mention assessing study quality but do not describe the methods used.
[No]

P13
Quote: "We analyzed the dichotomous outcomes using risk ratios (RRs) as the summary statistic."
Reasoning: The authors state that they used risk ratios as the summary measure for dichotomous outcomes.
[Yes]

P14
Quote: "We analyzed the dichotomous outcomes using risk ratios (RRs) as the summary statistic. Chi-square statistical tests (Q statistics) and the I2 test were used to test the heterogeneity between the trials."
Reasoning: The authors describe the methods used for the meta-analysis, including the summary statistic and assessment of heterogeneity.
[Yes]

P15
Quote: "We analyzed the possible publication bias by generating funnel plots of the trials used for all of the evaluated comparisons of outcomes."
Reasoning: The authors describe assessing publication bias using funnel plots.
[Yes]

P16
Reasoning: The authors do not describe any additional analyses.
[No]

P17
Quote: Figure 1 shows a flowchart of study selection with the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.
Reasoning: The flowchart provides the required information on study selection.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "Totally, seven retrospective comparative trials [9–15] and three studies [4, 16, 17] using national database were included. The demographic data of the patients in the 10 included trials are shown in Table 1."
Reasoning: The authors state the number of included studies and provide an aggregated table of their characteristics.
[Yes]

P19
Reasoning: The authors do not present the risk of bias for each included study.
[No]

P20
Reasoning: The authors do not present the individual study results with a summary of the data for each intervention group.
[No]

P21
Reasoning: The authors report the results of the meta-analyses, including the pooled effect estimates and confidence intervals, but do not include measures of consistency for each analysis.
[No]

P22
Reasoning: The authors do not present the results of the risk of bias assessment across studies.
[No]

P23
Reasoning: The authors do not report any additional analyses.
[No]

P24
Quote: "Despite the wide acceptance of robotic surgery in adults, open pyeloplasty remained the mainstay of surgical option in treating children with UPJO. According to the national database analysis, the trends of performing robotic-assisted pyeloplasty are increasing in the recent years, while the proportion still remained low [7]. Our systemic review did not find any randomized control trials or prospective observational trials comparing RP with the gold standard OP. Until now, there were only seven comparative studies, and three studies using national database to compare these two methods can be searched on PubMed."
Reasoning: The authors provide a summary of the main findings and their relevance to key groups in the discussion.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Although robotics bears the advantage of better intracorporeal suture and minimal invasiveness with pyeloplasty. The major drawback of stentless pyeloplasty was a higher rate of urinoma formation [24, 25]."
Reasoning: The authors discuss some limitations of robotic pyeloplasty, but do not fully address limitations at the study, outcome, and review levels.
[No]

P26
Quote: "The meta-analysis done by Cundy et al. [22] showed a borderline significantly lower estimated blood loss in RP group and no instance of blood transfusion was required. Usually, blood transfusion is rare in children undergoing pyeloplasty. However, the national survey of RP reported higher risks of blood transfusions in the RP group (1.2 %) than in OP (0.4 %) [4], which may reflect the real world of surgery done by general pediatric urologists, while the reported case–control series were reported by experienced laparoendoscopists. In general, the very narrow operation site, especially in children, which could prolong the learning curve for this robotic intervention, might cause practice, the higher transfusion, and complication rates in RP group. Moreover, it is likely that surgeons performed most of the robotic cases in their early learning phase. Lastly, the chance of technical error of robotics was around 5 %, in which conversion to standard laparoscopic pyeloplasty is required which highlights the need of keeping laparoscopic skills in performing robotic surgery [11]."
Reasoning: The authors provide an interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and discuss implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Reasoning: The authors do not describe the sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

"The obtained data were analyzed with Cochrane Collaboration Review Manager (RevMan®, version 5.3)."

Reasoning: The authors searched PubMed and provided the search terms, but only searched one database and did not mention supplementing the electronic search.

Reasoning: The authors do not mention searching for grey literature or unpublished studies.
