llm_message:
A1
Quote: "We searched all publications from August 1998 to March 2012 in the MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane library databases and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register using different combinations of the following terms: "Hirschsprung's disease," "perineal," "transanal," "transabdominal" and "pull-through.""
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "There was no difference in incidence of postoperative enterocolitis. Where postoperative soiling was reported, this was considered as equivalent to incontinence, as no study reported both outcomes simultaneously."
"Our review was limited to published studies and no contact with authors was made to obtain unpublished data."
Reasoning: The authors do not mention duplicate study selection and data extraction.
[No]

A3
Quote: "We searched all publications from August 1998 to March 2012 in the MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane library databases and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register using different combinations of the following terms: "Hirschsprung's disease," "perineal," "transanal," "transabdominal" and "pull-through." The reference lists of the full articles were also manually searched to identify additional eligible studies. After identifying relevant titles and abstracts, the studies were assessed for eligibility for inclusion in our meta-analysis."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases were searched and the search was supplemented by checking reference lists.
[Yes]

A4
Quote: "After identifying relevant titles and abstracts, the studies were assessed for eligibility for inclusion in our meta-analysis. All studies included in the meta-analysis were published in English, although no language restriction was imposed."
Reasoning: The authors state that no language restriction was imposed, implying they searched for reports regardless of publication status.
[Yes]

A5
Quote: "Of 93 studies reporting the outcome of the transanal approach in treating Hirschsprung's disease, 18 studies that compared outcome after TERPT with those after TAB were eligible for inclusion in our analysis. Two studies used a different methodology for assessment of comparative results from other studies and were excluded [26,27]. Four studies contained data that overlapped with later studies from the same centers [13,25,28,29], leaving 1 RCT and 11 OCS for meta-analysis [10,14–24] (Fig. 1)."
Reasoning: The authors provide the number of included and excluded studies with reasons for exclusions.
[Yes]

A6
Quote: "Our study included 792 patients; 444 underwent TERPT and 348 underwent TAB (including 215 Soave from eight studies, 94 Duhamel from five studies, 24 Swenson from two studies and 15 Rehbein procedures from one study). Almost all TERPTs were done as single-stage procedures while staged procedures with preoperative colostomy were common in many TABs (Table 1). In two studies, three groups (TERPT, single- and multi-stage TAB) were compared to each other; for these, we analyzed the single-stage TAB for comparison with TERPT [16,22]."
Reasoning: The authors provide aggregated data on the participants, interventions and outcomes of the included studies.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "Each included study was independently appraised by 3 reviewers (C.Y., S.N., N.K.L.) and data were extracted and entered into a database. Any disagreements were resolved by consensus."
Reasoning: The scientific quality of the included studies was assessed independently by 3 reviewers.
[Yes]

A8
Quote: "There were significant differences in the age of patients and duration of follow-up between the two groups, that is, the TERPT group had younger patients and had a shorter duration of follow-up. Kim et al. [10] showed that postoperative continence, stooling and enterocolitis tended to improve over time. As such, the benefits of TERPT in functional outcomes could potentially be even greater with longer follow-up."
Reasoning: The authors consider the methodological quality and differences between studies when formulating their conclusions.
[Yes]

A9
Quotes: "Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated for dichotomous variables using the Mantel–Haenszel method. Pooled mean differences (MD) were measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method in meta-analysis."
"Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2. A fixed-effects model was used if I2<50% and a random-effects model was used if I2≥50%. Statistical analysis was performed using Review Manager 5.1.0 (Cochrane Collaboration)."
Reasoning: Appropriate statistical methods were used to combine the findings of studies and assess heterogeneity.
[Yes]

A10
Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing publication bias.
[No]

A11
Reasoning: The authors acknowledge sources of funding for the systematic review but do not report on the funding sources of the included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Transanal endorectal pull-through (TERPT) has become popular for single-stage treatment of Hirschsprung's disease."
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: "Aim: Transanal endorectal pull-through (TERPT) has become popular for single-stage treatment of Hirschsprung's disease. The benefits of TERPT over the conventional transabdominal approach (TAB) are still unclear. We performed a comprehensive meta-analysis comparing the clinical outcomes of TERPT and TAB.
Methods: Original articles published from 1998 to 2012 were searched from Medline, Embase, and Cochrane databases. Randomized controlled trials (RCT) and observational clinical studies (OCS) comparing TERPT and TAB were included. Outcomes evaluated included operative time, hospital stay and incidence of postoperative incontinence/soiling, constipation and enterocolitis. Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated for dichotomous variables; pooled mean differences (MD) were measured for continuous variables."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, appraisal methods, results and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Since the first description of aganglionosis in the myenteric plexus of the distal colon in congenital megacolon by Dalla Valle et al., a variety of surgical procedures have been described in an attempt to restore normal bowel function in Hirschsprung's disease (HD) [1–6]. For many years, surgical treatment of HD involved staged procedures; an initial diverting enterostomy was followed by definitive transabdominal pull-through surgery with subsequent closure of the colostomy. These multi-stage surgeries have gradually been replaced by the primary pull-through surgery in many centers [7]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of the history and evolution of surgical treatments for Hirschsprung's disease.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "We performed a comprehensive meta-analysis comparing the clinical outcomes of TERPT and TAB."
Reasoning: The objectives are stated but do not explicitly reference the PICOS elements.
[No]

P5
Reasoning: The authors do not mention the existence of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6
Quote: "We searched all publications from August 1998 to March 2012 in the MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane library databases and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register using different combinations of the following terms: "Hirschsprung's disease," "perineal," "transanal," "transabdominal" and "pull-through." The reference lists of the full articles were also manually searched to identify additional eligible studies. After identifying relevant titles and abstracts, the studies were assessed for eligibility for inclusion in our meta-analysis. All studies included in the meta-analysis were published in English, although no language restriction was imposed."
Reasoning: The authors specify the study characteristics used as eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "We searched all publications from August 1998 to March 2012 in the MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane library databases and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register using different combinations of the following terms: "Hirschsprung's disease," "perineal," "transanal," "transabdominal" and "pull-through.""
Reasoning: The information sources and dates of coverage are described but the date last searched is not provided.
[No]

P8
Reasoning: The authors do not present the full electronic search strategy such that it could be repeated.
[No]

P9
Quote: "After identifying relevant titles and abstracts, the studies were assessed for eligibility for inclusion in our meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is partially described but more details could have been provided.
[No]

P10
Quote: "Each included study was independently appraised by 3 reviewers (C.Y., S.N., N.K.L.) and data were extracted and entered into a database. Any disagreements were resolved by consensus."
Reasoning: The method of data extraction is described.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "Outcomes evaluated included operative time, hospital stay and incidence of postoperative incontinence/soiling, constipation and enterocolitis."
Reasoning: The outcomes for which data were sought are defined but the review does not comprehensively list all variables.
[No]

P12
Quote: "Each included study was independently appraised by 3 reviewers (C.Y., S.N., N.K.L.) and data were extracted and entered into a database. Any disagreements were resolved by consensus."
Reasoning: The authors state the included studies were appraised but do not describe the methods used to assess risk of bias.
[No]

P13
Quote: "Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated for dichotomous variables using the Mantel–Haenszel method. Pooled mean differences (MD) were measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method in meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are stated.
[Yes]

P14
Quotes: "Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated for dichotomous variables using the Mantel–Haenszel method. Pooled mean differences (MD) were measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method in meta-analysis."
"Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2. A fixed-effects model was used if I2<50% and a random-effects model was used if I2≥50%. Statistical analysis was performed using Review Manager 5.1.0 (Cochrane Collaboration)."
Reasoning: The methods of handling data and combining results are described, including the measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P15
Reasoning: The authors do not specify any assessment of risk of bias across studies that may affect the cumulative evidence.
[No]

P16
Reasoning: No additional analyses are described.
[NA]

P17
Quote: "Of 93 studies reporting the outcome of the transanal approach in treating Hirschsprung's disease, 18 studies that compared outcome after TERPT with those after TAB were eligible for inclusion in our analysis. Two studies used a different methodology for assessment of comparative results from other studies and were excluded [26,27]. Four studies contained data that overlapped with later studies from the same centers [13,25,28,29], leaving 1 RCT and 11 OCS for meta-analysis [10,14–24] (Fig. 1)."
Reasoning: The authors provide the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included with reasons for exclusions at each stage, accompanied by a flow diagram (Fig. 1).
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "Our study included 792 patients; 444 underwent TERPT and 348 underwent TAB (including 215 Soave from eight studies, 94 Duhamel from five studies, 24 Swenson from two studies and 15 Rehbein procedures from one study). Almost all TERPTs were done as single-stage procedures while staged procedures with preoperative colostomy were common in many TABs (Table 1). In two studies, three groups (TERPT, single- and multi-stage TAB) were compared to each other; for these, we analyzed the single-stage TAB for comparison with TERPT [16,22]."
Reasoning: The authors present the characteristics of each included study in an aggregated form in the text and in Table 1.
[Yes]

P19
Reasoning: The authors do not present data on the risk of bias of each study.
[No]

P20
Reasoning: Simple summary data for each group and effect estimates with confidence intervals are not provided for each study for all outcomes. Some of this information is provided in the forest plots but not comprehensively.
[No]

P21
Reasoning: The results of each meta-analysis are presented in the forest plots, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P22
Reasoning: The authors do not present any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[No]

P23
Reasoning: No additional analyses are described.
[NA]

P24
Quote: "Our meta-analysis suggests that the TERPT is superior to the conventional TAB pull-through for Hirschsprung's disease. To our knowledge, this study is the first systematic review and meta-analysis comparing TERPT to TAB pull-through for Hirschsprung's disease.
TERPT is a minimally invasive procedure, with the advantages of better cosmesis, less postoperative pain and avoidance of abdominal contamination [8]. Many studies have also suggested that TERPT reduces operative time and hospital stay compared to conventional open surgery, which is shown by our meta-analysis [14–19,22,24]. However, we note a significant heterogeneity among the studies for operative time and duration of hospital stay. This heterogeneity may be attributed to variation in the skills of the surgeons and differences in postoperative care pathways in different centers."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings and their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "All TERPT procedures were performed after 1996, while the earliest open procedure included in this meta-analysis was from 1990. In the intervening years, factors other than the surgical approach, such as improvements in pediatric perioperative care, management of complications, or even administration-driven attention to length of hospital stay, may have partially contributed to the apparent better outcomes in the TERPT group."
Reasoning: The authors discuss some limitations at the review level, such as differences between the TERPT and open procedure groups that could have influenced the findings.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Postoperative enterocolitis is one of the main complications after pull-through surgery. The reported incidence of postoperative enterocolitis in the literature ranges from 4.6% to 54% [32]. A recent review showed that the incidence of postoperative and recurrent enterocolitis was markedly lower in TERPT (10% and 2% respectively) [32]. Our meta-analysis also showed a tendency to a lower incidence of enterocolitis in the TERPT group compared with TAB, although the difference was not statistically significant."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and discuss implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "The authors would like to thank Mr. Fahad Javaid Siddiqui, Assistant Professor of Epidemiology, Singapore Clinical Research Institute, for his invaluable help with statistical analysis."
Reasoning: The authors acknowledge a source of support for the systematic review but do not describe the role of funders.
[No]

Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of the history and evolution of surgical treatments for Hirschsprung's disease.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "We performed a comprehensive meta-analysis comparing the clinical outcomes of TERPT and TAB."
Reasoning: The objectives are stated but do not explicitly reference the PICOS elements.
[No]

P5
Reasoning: The authors do not mention the existence of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6
Quote: "We searched all publications from August 1998 to March 2012 in the MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane library databases and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register using different combinations of the following terms: "Hirschsprung's disease," "perineal," "transanal," "transabdominal" and "pull-through." The reference lists of the full articles were also manually searched to identify additional eligible studies. After identifying relevant titles and abstracts, the studies were assessed for eligibility for inclusion in our meta-analysis. All studies included in the meta-analysis were published in English, although no language restriction was imposed."
Reasoning: The authors specify the study characteristics used as eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "We searched all publications from August 1998 to March 2012 in the MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane library databases and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register using different combinations of the following terms: "Hirschsprung's disease," "perineal," "transanal," "transabdominal" and "pull-through.""
Reasoning: The information sources and dates of coverage are described but the date last searched is not provided.
[No]

P8
Reasoning: The authors do not present the full electronic search strategy such that it could be repeated.
[No]

P9
Quote: "After identifying relevant titles and abstracts, the studies were assessed for eligibility for inclusion in our meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is partially described but more details could have been provided.
[No]

P10
Quote: "Each included study was independently appraised by 3 reviewers (C.Y., S.N., N.K.L.) and data were extracted and entered into a database. Any disagreements were resolved by consensus."
Reasoning: The method of data extraction is described.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "Outcomes evaluated included operative time, hospital stay and incidence of postoperative incontinence/soiling, constipation and enterocolitis."
Reasoning: The outcomes for which data were sought are defined but the review does not comprehensively list all variables.
[No]

P12
Quote: "Each included study was independently appraised by 3 reviewers (C.Y., S.N., N.K.L.) and data were extracted and entered into a database. Any disagreements were resolved by consensus."
Reasoning: The authors state the included studies were appraised but do not describe the methods used to assess risk of bias.
[No]

P13
Quote: "Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated for dichotomous variables using the Mantel–Haenszel method. Pooled mean differences (MD) were measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method in meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are stated.
[Yes]

P14
Quotes: "Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated for dichotomous variables using the Mantel–Haenszel method. Pooled mean differences (MD) were measured for continuous variables using the inverse variance method in meta-analysis."
"Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2. A fixed-effects model was used if I2<50% and a random-effects model was used if I2≥50%. Statistical analysis was performed using Review Manager 5.1.0 (Cochrane Collaboration)."
Reasoning: The methods of handling data and combining results are described, including the measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P15
Reasoning: The authors do not specify any assessment of risk of bias across studies that may affect the cumulative evidence.
[No]

P16
Reasoning: No additional analyses are described.
[NA]

P17
Quote: "Of 93 studies reporting the outcome of the transanal approach in treating Hirschsprung's disease, 18 studies that compared outcome after TERPT with those after TAB were eligible for inclusion in our analysis. Two studies used a different methodology for assessment of comparative results from other studies and were excluded [26,27]. Four studies contained data that overlapped with later studies from the same centers [13,25,28,29], leaving 1 RCT and 11 OCS for meta-analysis [10,14–24] (Fig. 1)."
Reasoning: The authors provide the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included with reasons for exclusions at each stage, accompanied by a flow diagram (Fig. 1).
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "Our study included 792 patients; 444 underwent TERPT and 348 underwent TAB (including 215 Soave from eight studies, 94 Duhamel from five studies, 24 Swenson from two studies and 15 Rehbein procedures from one study). Almost all TERPTs were done as single-stage procedures while staged procedures with preoperative colostomy were common in many TABs (Table 1). In two studies, three groups (TERPT, single- and multi-stage TAB) were compared to each other; for these, we analyzed the single-stage TAB for comparison with TERPT [16,22]."
Reasoning: The authors present the characteristics of each included study in an aggregated form in the text and in Table 1.
[Yes]

P19
Reasoning: The authors do not present data on the risk of bias of each study.
[No]

P20
Reasoning: Simple summary data for each group and effect estimates with confidence intervals are not provided for each study for all outcomes. Some of this information is provided in the forest plots but not comprehensively.
[No]

P21
Reasoning: The results of each meta-analysis are presented in the forest plots, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P22
Reasoning: The authors do not present any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[No]

P23
Reasoning: No additional analyses are described.
[NA]

P24
Quote: "Our meta-analysis suggests that the TERPT is superior to the conventional TAB pull-through for Hirschsprung's disease. To our knowledge, this study is the first systematic review and meta-analysis comparing TERPT to TAB pull-through for Hirschsprung's disease.
TERPT is a minimally invasive procedure, with the advantages of better cosmesis, less postoperative pain and avoidance of abdominal contamination [8]. Many studies have also suggested that TERPT reduces operative time and hospital stay compared to conventional open surgery, which is shown by our meta-analysis [14–19,22,24]. However, we note a significant heterogeneity among the studies for operative time and duration of hospital stay. This heterogeneity may be attributed to variation in the skills of the surgeons and differences in postoperative care pathways in different centers."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings and their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "All TERPT procedures were performed after 1996, while the earliest open procedure included in this meta-analysis was from 1990. In the intervening years, factors other than the surgical approach, such as improvements in pediatric perioperative care, management of complications, or even administration-driven attention to length of hospital stay, may have partially contributed to the apparent better outcomes in the TERPT group."
Reasoning: The authors discuss some limitations at the review level, such as differences between the TERPT and open procedure groups that could have influenced the findings.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Postoperative enterocolitis is one of the main complications after pull-through surgery. The reported incidence of postoperative enterocolitis in the literature ranges from 4.6% to 54% [32]. A recent review showed that the incidence of postoperative and recurrent enterocolitis was markedly lower in TERPT (10% and 2% respectively) [32]. Our meta-analysis also showed a tendency to a lower incidence of enterocolitis in the TERPT group compared with TAB, although the difference was not statistically significant."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and discuss implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "The authors would like to thank Mr. Fahad Javaid Siddiqui, Assistant Professor of Epidemiology, Singapore Clinical Research Institute, for his invaluable help with statistical analysis."
Reasoning: The authors acknowledge a source of support for the systematic review but do not describe the role of funders.
[No]

"Outcomes of endopyelotomy for pelviureteric junction obstruction in the paediatric population: A systematic review"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for background, objective, study design, results, and conclusion. However, it is missing some recommended elements like data sources, participants, interventions, appraisal and synthesis methods, limitations, registration number.

"The study aimed to systematically analyse published literature to give an overall success rate for endopyelo tomy in children."

[Yes]

P7
"Medline and Embase databases were searched using relevant key search terms (pelviu reteric junction, ureteropelvic junction, obstruction, paediatric, pediatric, child$, balloon, dilatation, endopyelo tomy, pyelo plasty). P25
"This study is limited by the data given in the individual series: varied criteria used for patient selection and outcome as well as inconsistent pre and post operative imaging data precluded a metaanalysis. Designating procedures as failures if there were subsequent procedures to the PUJ lowered success rates from author-given figures for some studies. Complications rates after endopyelotomy are higher than those for open and minimally invasive pyeloplasty. Success rates for endopyelotomy do not compare favourably with pyeloplasty and crossing vessels should be excluded before considering the procedure."
Limitations at the study, outcome, and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
"The study found success rates of 71% for primary endopyelotomy and 75% for secondary procedures, neither of which compare favourably with established outcome data for open and laparoscopic pyeloplasty. Crossing vessels are a significant concern in children with primary PUJO and should be excluded before considering endopyelotomy. Furthermore, due consideration must be given to the greater costs and complication rates associated with the procedure."
The conclusion provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
"None."
Sources of funding and support are not described.
[No]

The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched. Finally, data regarding patients with thoracotomy from our own institution were also obtained. Eligibility criteria were then applied to remaining studies (Table 1)."
Searching 4 databases, reference lists, conference proceedings, and own institutional data represents a comprehensive search.

Use of the MINORS criteria and a local checklist to assess study quality.

"Is Screening of Intestinal Foregut Anatomy in Heterotaxy Patients Really Necessary? A Systematic Review in Search of the Evidence"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for Objective, Summary of Background Data, Methods, Results, and Conclusion.
The abstract is structured with the required sections.
[Yes]

P3
"Heterotaxy is an abnormal arrangement of thoraco-abdominal viscera across a left-to-right axis in contrast to normal patterning of "situs solitus." Traditionally, a mirror-image pattern of arrangement was included in the definition, but this so-called "situs inversus" is now considered separately."
The introduction provides rationale by describing heterotaxy and how it differs from situs solitus and situs inversus.
[Yes]

P4
"(1) Is screening of intestinal rotational anatomy obligatory in "asymptomatic" patients with heterotaxy? (2) Does detection of an anomaly warrant surgical correction?"
The introduction explicitly states the review questions.
[Yes]

P5
No relevant quotes found.

[No]

See Table 1 for inclusion and exclusion criteria.

The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched. The information sources searched are described, including databases with dates, reference lists, conference proceedings, and the authors' own institution.
[Yes]

No relevant quotes found.

[No]

The study selection process of applying eligibility criteria is mentioned.
[Yes]

Data extraction of primary and secondary outcomes is described.

No relevant quotes found.

[No]

Assessment of risk of bias in individual studies using MINORS and a local checklist is described.

The main findings and strength of evidence are summarized.
[Yes]

P25
"Although this systematic review favors a "watchful waiting" approach over prophylactic surgery in patients with heterotaxy, what exactly this should constitute is not standardized. Those 5 papers advocating a conservative approach of the asymptomatic patients emphasize the need for "regular" or "close" follow-up, and where this is not possible, or when symptoms develop, imaging is warranted."
Limitations such as lack of standardization of the watchful waiting approach are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
"We fully acknowledge that there are some limitations with the present study. Follow-up reporting data in studies we analyzed was sometimes poor. This may influence long-term outcome(s) of both a "watchful waiting" policy and operative intervention. Adequate reporting in studies was thus by no means always satisfactory. MINORS scoring highlighted these fact(s) (Fig. 1). Here, we found that little reference was made in many studies as to the nature of cardiac comorbidity(s) and cardiac mortality out with the perioperative period. It is heart anomalies, which most often are the determinant of life expectancy guiding the appropriateness of surgical correction of IRA. All studies included were retrospective observational studies with no valid comparator group (Oxford EBM—Level IV evidence32). As a result, there were some significant inherent bias(s) indicating interpretation of studies with care."
The authors acknowledge limitations with the data and studies analyzed.
[Yes]

P27
No relevant quotes found.
No description of funding sources.
[No]

"Although this systematic review favors a "watchful waiting" approach over prophylactic surgery in patients with heterotaxy, what exactly this should constitute is not standardized. Those 5 papers advocating a conservative approach of the asymptomatic patients emphasize the need for "regular" or "close" follow-up, and where this is not possible, or when symptoms develop, imaging is warranted."
Limitations such as lack of standardization of the watchful waiting approach are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
"We fully acknowledge that there are some limitations with the present study. Follow-up reporting data in studies we analyzed was sometimes poor. This may influence long-term outcome(s) of both a "watchful waiting" policy and operative intervention. Adequate reporting in studies was thus by no means always satisfactory. MINORS scoring highlighted these fact(s) (Fig. 1). Here, we found that little reference was made in many studies as to the nature of cardiac comorbidity(s) and cardiac mortality out with the perioperative period. It is heart anomalies, which most often are the determinant of life expectancy guiding the appropriateness of surgical correction of IRA. All studies included were retrospective observational studies with no valid comparator group (Oxford EBM—Level IV evidence32). As a result, there were some significant inherent bias(s) indicating interpretation of studies with care."
The authors acknowledge limitations with the data and studies analyzed.
[Yes]

[No]

The authors provided the characteristics of the included studies in an aggregated table.

The drawback is that SILA is associated with higher conversion rate, and perhaps higher surgical difficulty and hospitalization costs. Whether it can achieve improvement in cosmesis remains to be confirmed."
The authors considered the methodological quality when formulating the conclusions of the review.

No relevant quotes found.

P10
"Three researchers extracted data from each study by using a structured sheet and entered the data into a database. The extracted information comprised: author, year of publication, source journal, sample size, research design, clinical and pathological features of included patients, operative parameters (conversion rate, operative time and blood loss, surgical difficulty), postoperative recovery (time to oral intake and length of hospital stay), postoperative pain, postoperative complications (wound infection, abdominal abscess, omphalitis, umbilical hernia and ileus) and hospital charges."
The authors described the method of data extraction from reports.

"Single-incision laparoscopic surgery is developing rapidly in the surgical field, with increasing numbers of surgeons focusing on this technique [23]. "We have identified some limitations of this meta-analysis. llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not mention a protocol, ethics approval, or a priori objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quotes: "All other manuscripts (e.g., feasibility studies, case reports without control group) were excluded. Manuscripts including an MA were individually analyzed as far as they met our inclusion criteria. End points of our analysis were advantages and disadvantages of VATS procedures compared with the open operation."
Reasoning: The authors mention analyzing manuscripts but do not specify that at least two people independently selected studies and extracted data.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "The Web site was last accessed on January 2, 2013." "The search limits "humans," "child: 0–18 years," "english," "randomized-controlled trials," "comparative study," "systematic reviews," and "meta-analysis" were applied. Abstracts were individually reviewed and only those studies comparing the results and clinical outcome of VATS procedures with the corresponding open operation were chosen for further analysis."
Reasoning: The authors searched PubMed and applied relevant search limits, but did not report searching additional databases or other sources.
[No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not mention including or excluding studies based on publication status or searching for grey literature.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: None relevant 
Reasoning: The authors do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: See Table 3 which provides details on the included studies.
Reasoning: The authors provide an aggregated table with characteristics of the included studies.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: "An SR and classification of the methodological quality of studies can be classified as Level 1 or Level 2 according to the CEBM criteria. Contrasting to the great enthusiasm about both pediatric VATS procedures and the principles of evidence-based medicine, the best available evidence derives from RCS that can be classified as CEBM Level 3 at best."
Reasoning: The authors classified studies according to CEBM levels of evidence, which is a method of assessing study quality.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: "Except from one preliminary study and a most recently published pilot study, only RCS on pediatric VATS are available for five different types of procedures. Therefore, the best available evidence according to the CEBM criteria is Level 3."
Reasoning: The authors appropriately consider the limited quality of evidence (mostly Level 3) when formulating their conclusions.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "A total of 3 meta-analysis (MA) and 18 retrospective comparative studies (RCS) investigating 5 different VATS procedures (repair of congenital diaphragmatic hernia [CDH], repair of esophageal atresia/tracheoesophageal fistula (EA/TEF), lung resection, treatment of pneumothorax, and resection of neuroblastoma) were included in this study."
Reasoning: The authors included meta-analyses but did not assess heterogeneity or the appropriateness of combining studies, as they did not conduct their own quantitative synthesis.
[NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors did not assess publication bias.
[NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: "Conflict of Interest: None."
Reasoning: The authors report no conflicts of interest for their review, but do not report the funding sources of the included studies.
[No]

P1. Title
Quotes: "Thoracoscopic Procedures in Pediatric Surgery: What is the Evidence?"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: See the structured abstract with labeled sections for background, materials and methods, results, and conclusion.
Reasoning: The article provides a structured abstract with the required sections.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "The use of video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) has evolved quickly and it has gained widespread acceptance among pediatric surgeons during the last decade."
Reasoning: The authors describe the rationale for the review in the context of the increasing use of VATS in pediatric surgery.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quotes: "According to a recent classification of the Oxford Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine (CEBM), studies can be classified into Levels 1 to 5 in order of descending quality. We aimed to identify comparative studies investigating VATS versus open procedures in pediatric surgery and to classify publications according to the CEBM criteria."
Reasoning: The authors state their objectives of identifying comparative studies of VATS vs open surgery and classifying them by CEBM evidence levels.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not mention a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quotes: "Only studies published in English, comparing pediatric VATS with the corresponding open operation were included. End points were advantages and disadvantages of VATS as compared with the open procedure. Levels of evidence were determined using the recent CEBM criteria."
Reasoning: The authors specify the inclusion criteria related to PICOS and study characteristics.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quotes: "Clinical studies published in the English literature were identified by a Medline literature search using PubMed (www.pubmed.com). The Web site was last accessed on January 2, 2013."
Reasoning: The authors describe searching PubMed up to a specified date.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quotes: "The search limits "humans," "child: 0–18 years," "english," "randomized-controlled trials," "comparative study," "systematic reviews," and "meta-analysis" were applied."
Reasoning: The authors provide the search limits used but not the full search strategy.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quotes: "Abstracts were individually reviewed and only those studies comparing the results and clinical outcome of VATS procedures with the corresponding open operation were chosen for further analysis. All other manuscripts (e.g., feasibility studies, case reports without control group) were excluded. Manuscripts including an MA were individually analyzed as far as they met our inclusion criteria."
Reasoning: The authors state the process for selecting studies based on reviewing abstracts and full texts.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not describe the method of data extraction.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not specify all the variables for which data were sought.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: "An SR and classification of the methodological quality of studies can be classified as Level 1 or Level 2 according to the CEBM criteria. Contrasting to the great enthusiasm about both pediatric VATS procedures and the principles of evidence-based medicine, the best available evidence derives from RCS that can be classified as CEBM Level 3 at best."
Reasoning: The authors assessed study quality using CEBM levels of evidence.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not state the principal summary measures.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors included meta-analyses but did not conduct their own quantitative synthesis.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors did not assess risk of bias across studies.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors did not conduct any additional analyses.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quotes: "A total of 21 manuscripts met the inclusion criteria of our systematic review of which 3 were MA and 18 were RCS. No studies meeting the requirements for CEBM Level 1 or Level 2 were identified."
Reasoning: The authors report the number of included studies and reasons for exclusions, but do not provide a flow diagram.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quotes: See Table 3 which provides details on the included studies.
Reasoning: The authors provide a table with characteristics of each included study.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: "Three MA providing evidence of CEBM Level 3a were identified for three types of VATS procedures (repair of congenital diaphragmatic hernia [CDH], repair of esophageal atresia/tracheoesophageal fistula [EA/TEF], lung resection)."
Reasoning: The authors report the CEBM levels of evidence for each included study type.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: See Table 3 which provides results data for each included study.
Reasoning: The authors provide results for each individual study in a table.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors included meta-analyses but did not conduct their own quantitative synthesis.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors did not assess risk of bias across studies.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors did not conduct any additional analyses.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "Except from one preliminary study and a most recently published pilot study, only RCS on pediatric VATS are available for five different types of procedures. Therefore, the best available evidence according to the CEBM criteria is Level 3."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings on the limited strength of evidence.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Irrespective of the medical subspecialty, the employment of evidence-based medicine whenever possible is regarded as the most effective vehicle to achieve more efficient care. Evidence-based medicine is defined as the conscientious, explicit, and judicious use of current best evidence in making decisions about the care of individual patients."
Reasoning: The authors discuss limitations related to the lack of high-quality evidence but do not explicitly discuss limitations at the review level.
[No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Except from one preliminary study and a most recently published pilot study, only RCS on pediatric VATS are available for five different types of procedures. Therefore, the best available evidence according to the CEBM criteria is Level 3. Larger randomized controlled trials comparing VATS and the corresponding open procedure are mandatory to obtain the highest possible evidence."
Reasoning: The authors provide general conclusions in the context of the limited available evidence and need for further research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not report sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

Quotes: "Clinical studies published in the English literature were identified by a Medline literature search using PubMed (www.pubmed.com). The Web site was last accessed on January 2, 2013."
Reasoning: The authors describe searching PubMed up to a specified date.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quotes: "The search limits "humans," "child: 0–18 years," "english," "randomized-controlled trials," "comparative study," "systematic reviews," and "meta-analysis" were applied."
Reasoning: The authors provide the search limits used but not the full search strategy.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quotes: "Abstracts were individually reviewed and only those studies comparing the results and clinical outcome of VATS procedures with the corresponding open operation were chosen for further analysis. All other manuscripts (e.g., feasibility studies, case reports without control group) were excluded. Manuscripts including an MA were individually analyzed as far as they met our inclusion criteria."
Reasoning: The authors state the process for selecting studies based on reviewing abstracts and full texts.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not describe the method of data extraction.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not specify all the variables for which data were sought.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: "An SR and classification of the methodological quality of studies can be classified as Level 1 or Level 2 according to the CEBM criteria. Contrasting to the great enthusiasm about both pediatric VATS procedures and the principles of evidence-based medicine, the best available evidence derives from RCS that can be classified as CEBM Level 3 at best."
Reasoning: The authors assessed study quality using CEBM levels of evidence.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not state the principal summary measures.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors included meta-analyses but did not conduct their own quantitative synthesis.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors did not assess risk of bias across studies.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors did not conduct any additional analyses.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quotes: "A total of 21 manuscripts met the inclusion criteria of our systematic review of which 3 were MA and 18 were RCS. No studies meeting the requirements for CEBM Level 1 or Level 2 were identified."
Reasoning: The authors report the number of included studies and reasons for exclusions, but do not provide a flow diagram.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quotes: See Table 3 which provides details on the included studies.
Reasoning: The authors provide a table with characteristics of each included study.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: "Three MA providing evidence of CEBM Level 3a were identified for three types of VATS procedures (repair of congenital diaphragmatic hernia [CDH], repair of esophageal atresia/tracheoesophageal fistula [EA/TEF], lung resection)."
Reasoning: The authors report the CEBM levels of evidence for each included study type.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: See Table 3 which provides results data for each included study.
Reasoning: The authors provide results for each individual study in a table.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors included meta-analyses but did not conduct their own quantitative synthesis.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors did not assess risk of bias across studies.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors did not conduct any additional analyses.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "Except from one preliminary study and a most recently published pilot study, only RCS on pediatric VATS are available for five different types of procedures. Therefore, the best available evidence according to the CEBM criteria is Level 3."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings on the limited strength of evidence.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Irrespective of the medical subspecialty, the employment of evidence-based medicine whenever possible is regarded as the most effective vehicle to achieve more efficient care. Evidence-based medicine is defined as the conscientious, explicit, and judicious use of current best evidence in making decisions about the care of individual patients."
Reasoning: The authors discuss limitations related to the lack of high-quality evidence but do not explicitly discuss limitations at the review level.
[No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Except from one preliminary study and a most recently published pilot study, only RCS on pediatric VATS are available for five different types of procedures. Therefore, the best available evidence according to the CEBM criteria is Level 3. Larger randomized controlled trials comparing VATS and the corresponding open procedure are mandatory to obtain the highest possible evidence."
Reasoning: The authors provide general conclusions in the context of the limited available evidence and need for further research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The authors do not report sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

llm_message:
A1 - A priori design
Quotes:
"The first version of this systematic review was published in 2003 (Summerbell 2003), and included analysis of childhood obesity treatment studies published up until July 2001. The second version was published in 2009 providing an update to the 2003 review (Oude Luttikhuis 2009)."
"To reflect the rapid growth in this field, the third update to this review has been split across six reviews focusing on the following treatment approaches: surgery; drugs; parent only interventions; diet, physical activity and behavioural interventions for young children aged 0 to 4 years; school children aged 5 to 11 years; and adolescents aged 12 to 17 years."
Reasoning: The review is an update of previous reviews with a pre-specified focus.
[Yes]

A2 - Duplicate study selection and data extraction
Quotes:
"Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias and extracted data. Where necessary authors were contacted for additional information."
Reasoning: Two reviewers independently performed study selection and data extraction.
[Yes]

A3 - Comprehensive literature search
Quotes:
"We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE as well as LILACS, ICTRP Search Portal and ClinicalTrials.gov (all from database inception to March 2015). References of identified studies and systematic reviews were checked. No language restrictions were applied."
Reasoning: Multiple databases and trial registries were searched, and references of included studies were checked.
[Yes]

A4 - Grey literature
Quotes:
"We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE as well as LILACS, ICTRP Search Portal and ClinicalTrials.gov (all from database inception to March 2015)."
Reasoning: Trial registries were searched, which include grey literature.
[Yes]

A5 - List of included and excluded studies
Quotes:
"We included one RCT (a total of 50 participants, 25 in both the intervention and comparator group)."
"Six studies had to be excluded after careful evaluation of the full publication (Aikenhead 2011; Black 2013; Farina 2012; Gloy 2013; Picot 2009; Tyvonchuk 2009; see Figure 1)."
Reasoning: The included study is described, and excluded studies with reasons are listed and shown in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

A6 - Characteristics of included studies
Quotes:
"A detailed description of the characteristics of included studies is presented elsewhere (see Characteristics of included studies and appendices). The following is a succinct overview:"
Reasoning: The characteristics of the included study are reported in a table.
[Yes]

A7 - Scientific quality assessment
Quotes:
"Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias and extracted data."
"We planned to assess risk of bias using the Cochrane risk of bias tool (Higgins 2011a; Higgins 2011b). We applied the following criteria."
Reasoning: Risk of bias was independently assessed using the Cochrane risk of bias tool.
[Yes]

A8 - Scientific quality used in formulation of conclusions
Quotes:
"Our results are limited to two years of follow-up and are based on just one small Australian study with some risk of bias which was conducted in a private hospital, receiving funding from the gastric banding manufacturer. There is currently insufficient evidence to make an informed judgement about efficacy."
Reasoning: The limitations of the included study, including risk of bias, are considered when drawing conclusions.
[Yes]

A9 - Methods to combine findings
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so methods for combining study findings are not applicable.
[NA]

A10 - Publication bias assessment
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so assessment of publication bias is not applicable.
[NA] 

A11 - Conflict of interest stated
Quotes:
"We would like to thank Leanne Mohan (Teesside University) and Gudrun Paletta (Cochrane Metabolic and Endocrine Disorders Group) for helping with review management."
Reasoning: Sources of support for the systematic review are acknowledged, but not for the included study.
[No]

P1 - Title
Quote: "Surgery for the treatment of obesity in children and adolescents"
Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2 - Structured abstract
Quote: The abstract contains labeled Background, Objectives, Search methods, Selection criteria, Data collection and analysis, Main results sections.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with the required sections.
[Yes]

P3 - Rationale
Quote: "Child and adolescent overweight and obesity have increased globally, and are associated with significant short and long term health consequences."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of the increasing prevalence and consequences of child/adolescent obesity.
[Yes]

P4 - Objectives
Quote: "To assess the effects of surgical interventions for treating obesity in childhood and adolescence."
Reasoning: An explicit objective is provided.
[Yes]

P5 - Protocol and registration
Quote: "The first version of this systematic review was published in 2003 (Summerbell 2003), and included analysis of childhood obesity treatment studies published up until July 2001. The second version was published in 2009 providing an update to the 2003 review (Oude Luttikhuis 2009)."
Reasoning: Previous versions of the review are referenced, but no protocol or registration number is provided.
[No]

P6 - Eligibility criteria
Quote: "We selected randomised controlled trials (RCTs) of surgical interventions for treating obesity in children and adolescents (age < 18 years) with a minimum of six months follow-up. Interventions that specifically dealt with the treatment of eating disorders or type 2 diabetes, or included participants with a secondary or syndromic cause of obesity were excluded."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria for study design, participants, interventions, and follow-up are specified.
[Yes]

P7 - Information sources
Quote: "We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE as well as LILACS, ICTRP Search Portal and ClinicalTrials.gov (all from database inception to March 2015). References of identified studies and systematic reviews were checked."
Reasoning: The information sources searched are described, including the dates of coverage.
[Yes]

P8 - Search
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented for any of the databases.
[No]

P9 - Study selection
Quote: "Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias and extracted data."
Reasoning: The process of study selection by two independent reviewers is stated.
[Yes]

P10 - Data collection process
Quote: "Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias and extracted data. Where necessary authors were contacted for additional information."
Reasoning: Data extraction was done independently by two reviewers, and study authors were contacted for more information when needed.
[Yes]

P11 - Data items
Quote: "We defined the following outcomes as self-reported outcomes. • BMI and weight loss, if measured by participants. • Adverse events, if reported by participants. • Health-related quality of life and self esteem. • Participants views of the intervention. • Behaviour change."
Reasoning: The outcomes for which data were sought are defined.
[Yes]

P12 - Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "We planned to assess risk of bias using the Cochrane risk of bias tool (Higgins 2011a; Higgins 2011b). We applied the following criteria."
Reasoning: The Cochrane risk of bias tool was used to assess included studies.
[Yes]

P13 - Summary measures
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: No summary measures are specified as no meta-analysis was conducted.
[NA]

P14 - Synthesis of results
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed so methods of combining results are not applicable.
[NA]

P15 - Risk of bias across studies
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are not mentioned as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P16 - Additional analyses
Quote: "We planned to carry out the following subgroup analyses and wanted to investigate interaction. • Length of follow-up. • Impact and nature of maintenance periods. • The impact of comparator or control: whether concomitant therapy or no treatment (true control). • The impact of population demographics."
Reasoning: Planned subgroup analyses are described.
[Yes]

P17 - Study selection
Quote: See Figure 1 study flow diagram.
Reasoning: The flow diagram provides the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded with reasons at each stage.
[Yes]

P18 - Study characteristics
Quote: "A detailed description of the characteristics of included studies is presented elsewhere (see Characteristics of included studies and appendices). The following is a succinct overview:"
Reasoning: Characteristics of the included study are provided.
[Yes]

P19 - Risk of bias within studies
Quote: See Figure 2 risk of bias summary.
Reasoning: A risk of bias summary figure is presented showing judgements for each bias domain for the included study.
[Yes]

P20 - Results of individual studies
Quote: "We included one RCT (a total of 50 participants, 25 in both the intervention and comparator group). The intervention focused on laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding surgery, which was compared to a control group receiving a multi component lifestyle programme. The participating population consisted of Australian adolescents aged 14 to 18 years, with a mean age of 16.5 and 16.6 years in the gastric banding and lifestyle group, respectively which was conducted in a private hospital, receiving funding from the gastric banding manufacturer. The study authors were unable to blind participants, personnel and outcome assessors which may have resulted in a high risk of performance and detection bias. At 24 months follow-up, the mean change in BMI units was 12.7 (95% CI 11.3 to 14.2) for the surgery group compared to 1.3 (95% CI 0.4 to 2.9) for the lifestyle intervention."
Reasoning: Results are provided for the included study, including effect estimates and confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P21 - Synthesis of results
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed so results of each meta-analysis are not applicable.
[NA]

P22 - Risk of bias across studies
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: No assessment of risk of bias across studies is reported as no meta-analysis was done.
[NA]

P23 - Additional analyses
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The results of additional analyses are not provided.
[No]

P24 - Summary of evidence
Quote: "This review reports the findings from one RCT (50 participants). The intervention focused on laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding surgery, which was compared to a control group receiving a multi component lifestyle program. The study authors were unable to blind their participants, personnel and outcome assessors which may have resulted in a high risk of performance and detection bias. At 24 months follow-up, the mean change in BMI units was 12.7 (95% CI 11.3 to 14.2) for the surgery group compared to 1.3 (95% CI 0.4 to 2.9) for the control group. Adverse events were reported in 12/25 participants in the intervention group compared to 11/25 in the control group."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized including the strength of evidence for the main outcomes.
[Yes]

P25 - Limitations
Quote: "Our results are limited to two years of follow-up and are based on just one small Australian study with some risk of bias which was conducted in a private hospital, receiving funding from the gastric banding manufacturer. There is currently insufficient evidence to make an informed judgement about surgery for the treatment of obesity in children and adolescents."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study level (risk of bias, follow-up duration, funding source) and review level (only one small study) are discussed.
[Yes]

P26 - Conclusions
Quote: "Whilst an encouraging finding in terms of weight loss, there are several reasons to be cautious about these findings and more data are required, including data on whether this weight loss is maintained over the longer term. In addition, the financial burden of this type of surgery is high and the approach is not without risk. Long-term follow-up is also critical to comprehensively assess the impact of surgery as participants enter adulthood."
Reasoning: A general interpretation is provided in the context of the limitations and need for more evidence.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
Quote: "We would like to thank Leanne Mohan (Teesside University) and Gudrun Paletta (Cochrane Metabolic and Endocrine Disorders Group) for helping with review management."
Reasoning: Sources of funding and other support for the systematic review are described.
[Yes]
