A8 - Scientific quality used in formulation of conclusions
Quotes:
"Our results are limited to two years of follow-up and are based on just one small Australian study with some risk of bias which was conducted in a private hospital, receiving funding from the gastric banding manufacturer. There is currently insufficient evidence to make an informed judgement about efficacy."
Reasoning: The limitations of the included study, including risk of bias, are considered when drawing conclusions.
[Yes]

A9 - Methods to combine findings
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so methods for combining study findings are not applicable.
[NA]

A10 - Publication bias assessment
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so assessment of publication bias is not applicable.
[NA] 

A11 - Conflict of interest stated
Quotes:
"We would like to thank Leanne Mohan (Teesside University) and Gudrun Paletta (Cochrane Metabolic and Endocrine Disorders Group) for helping with review management."
Reasoning: Sources of support for the systematic review are acknowledged, but not for the included study.
[No]

P1 - Title
Quote: "Surgery for the treatment of obesity in children and adolescents"
Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2 - Structured abstract
Quote: The abstract contains labeled Background, Objectives, Search methods, Selection criteria, Data collection and analysis, Main results sections.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with the required sections.
[Yes]

P3 - Rationale
Quote: "Child and adolescent overweight and obesity have increased globally, and are associated with significant short and long term health consequences."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of the increasing prevalence and consequences of child/adolescent obesity.
[Yes]

P4 - Objectives
Quote: "To assess the effects of surgical interventions for treating obesity in childhood and adolescence."
Reasoning: An explicit objective is provided.
[Yes]

P5 - Protocol and registration
Quote: "The first version of this systematic review was published in 2003 (Summerbell 2003), and included analysis of childhood obesity treatment studies published up until July 2001. The second version was published in 2009 providing an update to the 2003 review (Oude Luttikhuis 2009)."
Reasoning: Previous versions of the review are referenced, but no protocol or registration number is provided.
[No]

P6 - Eligibility criteria
Quote: "We selected randomised controlled trials (RCTs) of surgical interventions for treating obesity in children and adolescents (age < 18 years) with a minimum of six months follow-up. Interventions that specifically dealt with the treatment of eating disorders or type 2 diabetes, or included participants with a secondary or syndromic cause of obesity were excluded."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria for study design, participants, interventions, and follow-up are specified.
[Yes]

P7 - Information sources
Quote: "We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE as well as LILACS, ICTRP Search Portal and ClinicalTrials.gov (all from database inception to March 2015). References of identified studies and systematic reviews were checked."
Reasoning: The information sources searched are described, including the dates of coverage.
[Yes]

P8 - Search
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented for any of the databases.
[No]

P9 - Study selection
Quote: "Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias and extracted data."
Reasoning: The process of study selection by two independent reviewers is stated.
[Yes]

P10 - Data collection process
Quote: "Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias and extracted data. Where necessary authors were contacted for additional information."
Reasoning: Data extraction was done independently by two reviewers, and study authors were contacted for more information when needed.
[Yes]

P11 - Data items
Quote: "We defined the following outcomes as self-reported outcomes. • BMI and weight loss, if measured by participants. • Adverse events, if reported by participants. • Health-related quality of life and self esteem. • Participants views of the intervention. • Behaviour change."
Reasoning: The outcomes for which data were sought are defined.
[Yes]

P12 - Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "We planned to assess risk of bias using the Cochrane risk of bias tool (Higgins 2011a; Higgins 2011b). We applied the following criteria."
Reasoning: The Cochrane risk of bias tool was used to assess included studies.
[Yes]

P13 - Summary measures
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: No summary measures are specified as no meta-analysis was conducted.
[NA]

P14 - Synthesis of results
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed so methods of combining results are not applicable.
[NA]

P15 - Risk of bias across studies
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are not mentioned as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P16 - Additional analyses
Quote: "We planned to carry out the following subgroup analyses and wanted to investigate interaction. • Length of follow-up. • Impact and nature of maintenance periods. • The impact of comparator or control: whether concomitant therapy or no treatment (true control). • The impact of population demographics."
Reasoning: Planned subgroup analyses are described.
[Yes]

P17 - Study selection
Quote: See Figure 1 study flow diagram.
Reasoning: The flow diagram provides the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded with reasons at each stage.
[Yes]

P18 - Study characteristics
Quote: "A detailed description of the characteristics of included studies is presented elsewhere (see Characteristics of included studies and appendices). The following is a succinct overview:"
Reasoning: Characteristics of the included study are provided.
[Yes]

P19 - Risk of bias within studies
Quote: See Figure 2 risk of bias summary.
Reasoning: A risk of bias summary figure is presented showing judgements for each bias domain for the included study.
[Yes]

P20 - Results of individual studies
Quote: "We included one RCT (a total of 50 participants, 25 in both the intervention and comparator group). The intervention focused on laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding surgery, which was compared to a control group receiving a multi component lifestyle programme. The participating population consisted of Australian adolescents aged 14 to 18 years, with a mean age of 16.5 and 16.6 years in the gastric banding and lifestyle group, respectively which was conducted in a private hospital, receiving funding from the gastric banding manufacturer. The study authors were unable to blind participants, personnel and outcome assessors which may have resulted in a high risk of performance and detection bias. At 24 months follow-up, the mean change in BMI units was 12.7 (95% CI 11.3 to 14.2) for the surgery group compared to 1.3 (95% CI 0.4 to 2.9) for the lifestyle intervention."
Reasoning: Results are provided for the included study, including effect estimates and confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P21 - Synthesis of results
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed so results of each meta-analysis are not applicable.
[NA]

P22 - Risk of bias across studies
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: No assessment of risk of bias across studies is reported as no meta-analysis was done.
[NA]

P23 - Additional analyses
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The results of additional analyses are not provided.
[No]

P24 - Summary of evidence
Quote: "This review reports the findings from one RCT (50 participants). The intervention focused on laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding surgery, which was compared to a control group receiving a multi component lifestyle program. The study authors were unable to blind their participants, personnel and outcome assessors which may have resulted in a high risk of performance and detection bias. At 24 months follow-up, the mean change in BMI units was 12.7 (95% CI 11.3 to 14.2) for the surgery group compared to 1.3 (95% CI 0.4 to 2.9) for the control group. Adverse events were reported in 12/25 participants in the intervention group compared to 11/25 in the control group."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized including the strength of evidence for the main outcomes.
[Yes]

P25 - Limitations
Quote: "Our results are limited to two years of follow-up and are based on just one small Australian study with some risk of bias which was conducted in a private hospital, receiving funding from the gastric banding manufacturer. There is currently insufficient evidence to make an informed judgement about surgery for the treatment of obesity in children and adolescents."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study level (risk of bias, follow-up duration, funding source) and review level (only one small study) are discussed.
[Yes]

P26 - Conclusions
Quote: "Whilst an encouraging finding in terms of weight loss, there are several reasons to be cautious about these findings and more data are required, including data on whether this weight loss is maintained over the longer term. In addition, the financial burden of this type of surgery is high and the approach is not without risk. Long-term follow-up is also critical to comprehensively assess the impact of surgery as participants enter adulthood."
Reasoning: A general interpretation is provided in the context of the limitations and need for more evidence.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
Quote: "We would like to thank Leanne Mohan (Teesside University) and Gudrun Paletta (Cochrane Metabolic and Endocrine Disorders Group) for helping with review management."
Reasoning: Sources of funding and other support for the systematic review are described.
[Yes]

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "We conducted a systematic review to determine whether single or 2-stage Fowler-Stephens orchiopexy results in better testicular viability."
Reasoning: The research question was established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Each author was allocated roughly 10 articles, and independently abstracted the data and assessed the quality of the reports. Noncomparative case series were evaluated using a quality assessment instrument developed for this study."
Reasoning: Data extraction was done independently by each author.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "We searched electronic databases, clinical trial registries and gray literature. We included reports describing boys younger than 18 years with a primary outcome of "testicular viability and position." We performed a meta-analysis using random effects models."
Reasoning: Multiple electronic databases and supplementary sources were searched.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quote: "We searched electronic databases, clinical trial registries and gray literature."
Reasoning: A search for gray literature was performed.
[Yes]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "After a thorough assessment 99 articles underwent a full review for evaluation of quality and an additional 13 studies from the gray literature search."
Reasoning: The number of included and excluded studies was provided but not a full reference list.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "The table summarizes the quality assessment results of the included articles."
Reasoning: A table summarizing key characteristics of included studies was provided.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "A calibration exercise was conducted to clarify any discordance. Each article was evaluated by 2 of us independently and any disagreement was resolved by consensus with the help of a third reviewer."
Reasoning: The quality of included studies was independently assessed.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: "Although the rate of testicular survival is high, the level of evidence of the studies was low, and a study of a more robust design, such as a randomized controlled trial, should be performed to evaluate and compare the efficacies of these therapies in the pediatric population."
Reasoning: The limitations of the low quality evidence were considered when drawing conclusions.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quote: "The effectiveness of single stage vs 2-stage Fowler-Stephens orchiopexy was evaluated based on testicular viability (size and location) following the procedure. Meta-analysis using weighted mean difference (random effects model) was conducted using R software (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Wien, Austria)."
Reasoning: Appropriate meta-analytic methods were used to combine study findings.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No assessment of publication bias was reported, likely because there were fewer than 10 studies.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Sources of support for the review and included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Is Staging Beneficial for Fowler-Stephens Orchiopexy? A Systematic Review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quote: See structured abstract on first page.
Reasoning: A structured abstract with labeled sections is provided.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Fowler and Stephens showed that by dividing the spermatic vessels a high intra-abdominal testis could be brought into the scrotum. This maneuver carries a potential complication of this technique."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is provided in the context of what is known.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "We conducted a systematic review to determine whether single or 2-stage Fowler-Stephens orchiopexy results in better testicular viability."
Reasoning: An explicit statement of the review question is provided.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Studies were considered relevant if they met the following inclusion criteria. Patients were younger than 18 years, had an intra-abdominal testis, had undergone single or 2-stage FSO (open or laparoscopic), and had data regarding testicular position and postoperative intraoperatively. RCTs and noncomparative case series were evaluated."
Reasoning: Study eligibility criteria are specified.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "We searched several electronic databases, including MEDLINE®, EMBASE®, CINAHL®, Cochrane Central Register of Control Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects and ACP Journal Club®. This search was restricted to articles published in English and was dated to February 2009."
Reasoning: Information sources searched are described.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "After a thorough assessment 99 articles underwent a full review for evaluation of quality and an additional 13 studies from the gray literature search."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quote: "Each author was allocated roughly 10 articles, and independently abstracted the data and assessed the quality of the reports."
Reasoning: The data extraction process is described.
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Data items collected are not explicitly defined.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "A calibration exercise was conducted to clarify any discordance. Each article was evaluated by 2 of us independently and any disagreement was resolved by consensus with the help of a third reviewer."
Reasoning: Risk of bias assessment for individual studies is described.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quote: "The effectiveness of single stage vs 2-stage FSO was evaluated based on testicular viability (size and location) following the procedure."
Reasoning: The main outcome measure is stated.
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quote: "Meta-analysis using weighted mean difference (random effects model) was conducted using R software (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Wien, Austria)."
Reasoning: The meta-analysis methods are described.
[Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are not mentioned.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No additional analyses are mentioned.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 1,807 potentially relevant articles were retrieved from the initial electronic database search and an additional 13 studies from the gray literature search. After a thorough assessment 99 articles underwent a full review for evaluation of quality and an additional 13 studies from the gray literature search."
Reasoning: The number of studies at each stage of selection is provided.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: See table on page 2014.
Reasoning: Characteristics of included studies are provided in a table.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment for each study are not presented.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quote: See forest plots in Figures 2-4 and 6-8.
Reasoning: Forest plots show the results of individual studies.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quote: "The pooled estimate of success rates was 80% for single stage FSO (95% CI 75 to 86) and the I2 was 11% (fig. 2). Among 36 articles (751 testes) including success rates of 2-stage FSO the pooled estimate of success rate was 85% (95% CI 81 to 90) and the I2 was 43% (fig. 3)."
Reasoning: Meta-analysis results with confidence intervals and heterogeneity are reported.
[Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Results of across-study bias assessment are not reported.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No additional analyses were mentioned in methods.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "Based on the results of this review, both approaches have a fairly high success rate, although 2-stage FSO appears to carry a higher rate of success over the single stage procedure, defined as postoperative viability of the testis (95% vs 80%, OR 2 in favor of 2-stage)."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "Although the rate of testicular survival is high, the level of evidence of the studies was low, and a study of a more robust design, such as a randomized controlled trial, should be performed to evaluate and compare the efficacies of these therapies in the pediatric population."
Reasoning: Limitations of the evidence are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Based on the results of this review, both approaches have a fairly high success rate, although 2-stage FSO appears to carry a higher rate of success over the single stage procedure, defined as postoperative viability of the testis (95% vs 80%, OR 2 in favor of 2-stage)."
Reasoning: Conclusions are provided in the context of the evidence.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the review are not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "Eligibility criteria for all studies published during the last 20 years that described open or laparoscopic operation for inguinal hernia, and the latter was compared with conventional OH."
The eligibility criteria were pre-specified.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Data regarding the following as limits: clinical trials, randomized controlled trials, multicenter retrospective, prospective studies, and expert opinion."
Data extraction was described, but no mention of duplicate study selection or data extraction.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "A literature search was performed on all studies published during the last 20 years, reporting on outcomes of OH and LH, in terms of operative time, recurrence rate and other complications, finding of rare hernias, and incidence of contralateral patency." "Publications were imposed initially, the search was limited to studies published in the English language for the full-text review and final analysis."
At least 2 databases (PubMed, Cochrane, Medline) were searched over a 20 year period. Only English language studies were included.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
The inclusion of grey literature like conference abstracts was not mentioned.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "Of the studies analyzed, there were 39 articles that met the inclusion criteria and were selected for the final analysis."
The number of included studies was provided, but no list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Fifty-three studies matched the inclusion criteria and were selected for the final analysis."
Table 1 provides an aggregated summary of the characteristics of included studies.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
The methodological quality of individual studies was not assessed.
[No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Since study quality was not assessed, it could not be incorporated into the conclusions.
[NA]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "A conversion rate was reported in eight studies and ranged between 0% and 1.7%, but in the majority of these studies, there was a 0% conversion rate." "Looking at the averages, there is no significant difference regarding recurrence rate comparing the two techniques (OH, 1.6% [26 recurrences out of 1539 hernia repairs]; LH, 1.4% [138 recurrences out of 9605 hernia repairs]) (P = .66)."
Quantitative synthesis was not performed, but results were described narratively in an appropriate manner, taking study heterogeneity into account.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Conflicts of interest for the systematic review and included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Laparoscopic Versus Open Inguinal Hernia Repair in Pediatric Patients: A Systematic Review"
The article title identifies the report as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for Aim, Materials and Methods, and Results. However, some key elements like the registration number are missing.
[No]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "The incidence of an inguinal hernia in children less than 18 years of age ranges from 0.8% to 4.4%."
Relevant background information is provided to contextualize the review.
[Yes]  

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The aim of this review is to analyze the current literature to determine the outcome of LH compared with OH."
The objective is stated, but without explicit reference to PICOS elements.
[No]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
A review protocol and registration number were not reported.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "The aim of this systematic review and meta-analysis was to compare the surgical strategies as regards operative time, recurrence rate, postoperative complications by means of a systematic review, and meta-analysis of the available literatures."
Reasoning: The aim is stated but there is no mention of a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined/a priori objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "The first author independently extracted data from the included studies. Details of publication (first author, year, country, the internal ring, trocars, and follow-up duration), inclusion and exclusion criteria, and demographics of the enrolled patients were collected and collated. Quality of the RCTs was assessed, including randomization, method of blinding, and allocation concealment."
Reasoning: Data extraction was done by one author independently, but no mention of duplicate study selection or a consensus procedure.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "We systematically searched PubMed for relevant studies reported from 2005 to 2014 with the keywords "laparoscopic herniorrhaphy", "pediatric inguinal hernia," and "open herniorrhaphy." Total reference lists of selected articles were also included. We limited our searches to the publications written in English."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases (PubMed and reference lists) were searched with keywords. Years were provided but full search strategy was not.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quote: "We limited our searches to the publications written in English."
Reasoning: Only published English studies were included, grey literature was not searched.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "Articles excluded because of failure to meet inclusion criteria (n = 235)"
Reasoning: A flow diagram is provided showing numbers excluded at each stage, but not a full list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Details of publication (first author, year, country, the internal ring, trocars, and follow-up duration), inclusion and exclusion criteria, and demographics of the enrolled patients were collected and collated."
Reasoning: Key characteristics of included studies like country, interventions, and follow-up duration were provided in an aggregated table.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Quality of the RCTs was assessed, including randomization, method of blinding, and allocation concealment."
Reasoning: The quality of included RCTs was assessed for key items like randomization, blinding, and allocation concealment.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: "Despite no significant difference was observed regarding the recurrence, LH can be accepted as a minimally invasive technique for PIH. In our systematic review of high-level evidence, LH was found to be superior to OH with respect to a shorter time for unilateral hernias in extraperitoneal approaches group and for bilateral hernias in both the groups."
Reasoning: The conclusions consider the quality of evidence, stating it is high-level evidence that found LH superior for certain outcomes.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "Review Manager (RevMan) software, version 5.3 was used for data statistical analysis. Weighted mean differences and odds ratios were used for continuous and dichotomous variables, respectively. The confidence interval (CI) was established at 95%. Statistical heterogeneity of the meta-analysis was assessed with the χ2 test and the I2 index. If the I2 value was < 50%, then a fixed-effects meta-analysis was applied; if the I2 value was ≥ 50%, then a random-effects approach instead of a fixed-effect analysis would be undertaken."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine studies, assessing heterogeneity and using a random effects model if I2 ≥ 50%.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Reasoning: There is no mention of assessing publication bias through a funnel plot or statistical test. However, this may not have been possible with the small number of included studies.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Reasoning: The source of funding for the systematic review is not reported, and sources of support for the included studies are not provided.
[No]

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quote: "Open Versus Laparoscopic Inguinal Herniotomy in Children: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Focusing on Postoperative Complications"
Reasoning: The title clearly identifies this as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quote: The abstract contains labeled sections for Purpose, Methods, Results, and Conclusions.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with the key PRISMA-recommended sections.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "There is an ongoing debate about whether laparoscopic or open herniorrhaphy (LH or OH) is the best choice for inguinal hernia in children. The aim of this study was to compare both of the surgical strategies as regards operative time, recurrence rate, postoperative complications by means of a systematic review, and meta-analysis of the available literatures."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is provided in the context of the ongoing debate about laparoscopic vs open herniorrhaphy in children.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The aim of this study was to compare both of the surgical strategies as regards operative time, recurrence rate, postoperative complications by means of a systematic review, and meta-analysis of the available literatures."
Reasoning: The objectives are stated, mentioning the comparison of surgical strategies and the outcomes of interest.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Reasoning: There is no mention of a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

[Yes]

[No]

Quote: "In this systematic review we summarized total RCTs available in the pediatric surgical literature, focusing on operative time, postoperative complications, and recurrence. Our results show that LH is superior for the inguinal hernia repair in children, with shorter operative time for unilateral hernias in extraperitoneal approaches group as well as for bilateral hernias. Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results.
[Yes]

Reasoning: There is no description of funding sources for the systematic review or the role of any funders.
[No]

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "The aim of this systematic review and meta-analysis was to compare the surgical strategies as regards operative time, recurrence rate, postoperative complications by means of a systematic review, and meta-analysis of the available literatures."
Reasoning: The aim is stated but there is no mention of a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined/a priori objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "The first author independently extracted data from the included studies. Details of publication (first author, year, country, the internal ring, trocars, and follow-up duration), inclusion and exclusion criteria, and demographics of the enrolled patients were collected and collated. Quality of the RCTs was assessed, including randomization, method of blinding, and allocation concealment."
Reasoning: Data extraction was done by one author independently, but no mention of duplicate study selection or a consensus procedure.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "We systematically searched PubMed for relevant studies reported from 2005 to 2014 with the keywords "laparoscopic herniorrhaphy", "pediatric inguinal hernia," and "open herniorrhaphy." Total reference lists of selected articles were also included. We limited our searches to the publications written in English."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases (PubMed and reference lists) were searched with keywords. Years were provided but full search strategy was not.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quote: "We limited our searches to the publications written in English."
Reasoning: Only published English studies were included, grey literature was not searched.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "Articles excluded because of failure to meet inclusion criteria (n = 235)"
Reasoning: A flow diagram is provided showing numbers excluded at each stage, but not a full list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Details of publication (first author, year, country, the internal ring, trocars, and follow-up duration), inclusion and exclusion criteria, and demographics of the enrolled patients were collected and collated."
Reasoning: Key characteristics of included studies like country, interventions, and follow-up duration were provided in an aggregated table.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Quality of the RCTs was assessed, including randomization, method of blinding, and allocation concealment."
Reasoning: The quality of included RCTs was assessed for key items like randomization, blinding, and allocation concealment.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: "Despite no significant difference was observed regarding the recurrence, LH can be accepted as a minimally invasive technique for PIH. In our systematic review of high-level evidence, LH was found to be superior to OH with respect to a shorter time for unilateral hernias in extraperitoneal approaches group and for bilateral hernias in both the groups."
Reasoning: The conclusions consider the quality of evidence, stating it is high-level evidence that found LH superior for certain outcomes.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "Review Manager (RevMan) software, version 5.3 was used for data statistical analysis. Weighted mean differences and odds ratios were used for continuous and dichotomous variables, respectively. The confidence interval (CI) was established at 95%. Statistical heterogeneity of the meta-analysis was assessed with the χ2 test and the I2 index. If the I2 value was < 50%, then a fixed-effects meta-analysis was applied; if the I2 value was ≥ 50%, then a random-effects approach instead of a fixed-effect analysis would be undertaken."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine studies, assessing heterogeneity and using a random effects model if I2 ≥ 50%.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Reasoning: There is no mention of assessing publication bias through a funnel plot or statistical test. However, this may not have been possible with the small number of included studies.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Reasoning: The source of funding for the systematic review is not reported, and sources of support for the included studies are not provided.
[No]

Quotes: "PubMed and MEDLINE databases were searched for all studies that reported cases of patients with HD who had undergone redo PT operations for RA or transition-zone bowel (TZB) after initial operation between 1985 and 2011." and "The search terms were "residual aganglionosis", "transition-zone bowel", "redo and repeat pull-through", "reoperation Hirschsprung's disease" and "postoperative follow-up and outcome Hirschsprung's disease"."

Reasoning: A structured abstract with labeled sections is not provided.

Quote: "Over the years, various PT operations have been used to treat patients with HD [18–23]. It has been shown in several studies that there is no statistically significant difference in the functional outcome with respect to bowel function between the various PT procedures [24–27]."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "Purpose Most patients with Hirschsprung's disease (HD) have a satisfactory outcome after pull-through (PT) operation. However, some children continue to have persistent bowel symptoms after the initial operation and may require redo PT. Redo PT operation in HD is usually indicated for anastomotic strictures or residual aganglionosis (RA). We designed this meta-analysis to determine the incidence and outcome of RA among patients with HD following PT operation."
Reasoning: The objectives are stated but do not explicitly reference all PICOS elements.

[No]

Reasoning: The number of studies included is provided but a flow diagram is not presented and reasons for exclusions at each stage are not given.
[No]

P18
Quote: "Twenty-nine articles reported 555 patients with HD who underwent redo PT operation. 193 (34.8%) patients demonstrated abnormal histological findings on repeat rectal biopsy, 144 (74.6%) patients revealed RA and 49 (25.4%) patients TZB (Table 1)."
Reasoning: Aggregate characteristics of included studies are presented but citations are not provided.

Reasoning: Not applicable as no additional analyses were reported.

P24
Quote: "Over the years, various PT operations have been used to treat patients with HD [18–23]. It has been shown in several studies that there is no statistically significant difference in the functional outcome with respect to bowel function between the various PT procedures [24–27]. For a PT operation to be successful, it is essential that all aganglionic bowel is resected and bowel with normal innervations is anastomosed to the anus. Our meta-analysis reveals that RA and TZB are the underlying causes of persistent bowel symptoms in one-third of all patients requiring redo PT operation."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "A major problem with the intraoperative frozen section biopsies is that it can indicate the presence of ganglion cells without differentiating between hypo- and dysganglionosis [29]."
Reasoning: Some limitations at the study level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Constipation after PT operation in the vast majority of patients can be managed by non-operative methods such as laxatives and enemas [10, 11]. Postoperative enterocolitis requires rectal irrigation with or without metronidazole prophylaxis [25]. However, if a patient continues to have persistent constipation, abdominal distension or recurrent episodes of enterocolitis, a full thickness rectal biopsy is indicated to rule out RA or TZB [33]."
Reasoning: A general interpretation is provided in the context of other evidence and implications for future practice are discussed.
[Yes]

P27
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]

[Yes]

P27
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "With this meta-analysis on complications and long-term outcome in newborns with LGEA managed by DPA, we provide an overview of the available patient cohorts that were published so far. Based on this data, it is recommended to perform a DPA when the patient is 2–4 months old. At this age, the distance between the two ends usually is <2.0 cm [22–24]. Successful primary anastomosis with delays of up to 12 months [25] and initial gaps of up to 7.0 cm [26] or eight vertebral bodies [27] have been reported (Fig. 5)."
Reasoning: The discussion summarizes the main findings and their relevance to key groups like healthcare providers.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "In most studies, early complications after DPA were leaks, which occurred in up to 50 % of their patients [20, 22, 23, 25, 28–40]. Most of the anastomotic leaks were minor and subsided spontaneously on total parenteral nutrition without the need for surgical intervention. However, some investigators reported major disruption and failure of conservative management with need for drainage or reoperation in up to 15 % of their cases [38, 40]."
Reasoning: The discussion addresses some limitations at the study level like the high incidence of leaks and need for reinterventions in some studies. However, review-level limitations like incomplete retrieval of studies or reporting biases are not discussed.
[No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "In conclusion, this meta-analysis shows that the DPA provides good long-term functional results. However, the high incidence of GER and associated strictures requires early intervention to prevent ongoing feeding problems due to strictures and esophagitis. Long-term follow-up is recommended because of the potential risk of Barrett's metaplasia."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of long-term outcomes and implications for clinical practice.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The article does not describe sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?

Quote: "One reviewer (GF) screened all titles and abstracts to assess whether each report was potentially eligible for inclusion and whether or not the full text was available. Then, the relevant full text articles of all studies, which were considered as appropriate ones, were reviewed by one researcher (GF) who evaluated the articles and extracted the data."
Reasoning: Study selection and data extraction were done by a single reviewer, not in duplicate.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "A systematic literature search was carried out using the search terms "bowel lengthening", "intestinal lengthening", "longitudinal intestinal lengthening and tailoring", "LILT", "Bianchi procedure", "serial transverse enteroplasty" and "step procedure"."
"The last search was done on December, 10th, 2012. The reference lists of retrieved reports were also cross-screened for additional studies."
Reasoning: At least 2 sources (search terms indicate multiple databases) plus reference screening were used.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "Fig. 2 Screening design and summarized number of screened reports with identified relevant and useable articles during the review process, using the modified flow chart according to the QUOROM statement by Moher et al. [10]."
Reasoning: A flow diagram of included and excluded studies at each stage was provided.
[Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Table 1 List of evaluated and reviewed STEP (n = 109) and LILT (n = 363) procedures in published case reports from 1991 to 2012."
Reasoning: A table listing the characteristics of included studies was provided.
[Yes]

Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No assessment of study quality or risk of bias was mentioned.

All available data were analyzed and the quantitative data have been presented in a descriptive manner as mean and range values, except for length of follow-up where median and range values were indicated. Mean %-values indicated in this review were calculated from all %-values of the respective item published within reviewed reports."
Reasoning: Appropriate descriptive statistics were used to summarize the findings. No meta-analysis was performed.

P1. Title
Quote: "Comparison of LILT and STEP procedures in children with short bowel syndrome — A systematic review of the literature"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quote: The abstract contains labeled sections for Purpose, Methods, Results, and Conclusions.
Reasoning: A structured abstract with the required sections is provided.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a serious disorder in which the intestinal resorptive capacity is insufficient to provide an adequate alimentary supply [1]. The estimated incidence in children is 24.5 per 100,000 live births with a higher incidence reported in preterm infants [2]. The estimated mortality is 2/100,000 population/year for children with SBS under 4 years [2] and 37.5% of neonates with SBS [3]. SBS in children occurs after congenital or acquired loss of part of the intestine [4], in most cases due to gastroschisis, necrotizing enterocolitis, mid-gut volvulus and intestinal atresia [5]."
Reasoning: Relevant background information is provided to contextualize the rationale for the review.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The first pivotal aim in the therapy of SBS is to ensure alimentation of the child by parenteral nutrition (PN), which results in significant improvements in mortality rates and improved thrive and quality of life in paediatric SBS [65,66]."
Reasoning: The objective of comparing LILT and STEP for treating SBS in children is implied but not explicitly stated in the introduction.
[No]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "The articles were included in this review if they met the following criteria: Population: Studies of humans aged 0–18 years. Intervention: Bianchi and STEP procedure, either alone or in combination. Type of study: All study designs were eligible for inclusion. Case series with 1 or more cases were included."
Reasoning: Eligibility criteria for population, intervention, and study design were provided.
[Yes]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "The first pivotal aim in the therapy of SBS is to ensure alimentation of the child by parenteral nutrition (PN), which results in significant improvements in mortality rates and improved thrive and quality of life in paediatric SBS [65,66]. Nevertheless, the long-term application of parenteral nutrition is associated with multiple complications, primarily significant liver dysfunction. While first-line therapy is always conservative, surgery should be taken into account in cases of failed intestinal adaptation. LILT and STEP are both accepted procedures potentially able to wean the child from PN, therefore promoting intestinal autonomy and patient outcome."
Reasoning: The main findings were summarized in the context of the key population (children with SBS).
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "multiple reports, calculated mean values in this review are only indicative and only allow a very cautious estimation of effectiveness of both procedures. Therefore, the results are encouraging, but not fully validated and further investigations with larger series are needed."
"A prospective randomized trial including both procedures with emphasis on LILT and STEP, then an insight into indications criteria for LILT and STEP and finally a comparison of associated outcome of both procedures from published data in children."
Reasoning: Some limitations at the review level were acknowledged, such as the inclusion of multiple reports and lack of validation. Study-level limitations were not discussed.
[No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "LILT and STEP are accepted procedures for non-transplant surgical management of small bowel syndrome in children. Larger series are needed to further assess accurate selection of eligible patients and to estimate effectiveness of procedures. A considerably higher number of cases for accurate evaluation might be accomplished through the widespread use of a centralised register."
Reasoning: The conclusions provided a general interpretation and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quote: "Acknowledgements: The authors are very grateful to "Heidelberger Stiftung Chirurgie" for supporting this publication."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were reported.
[Yes]

P1. Title

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Short bowel syndrome (SBS) is a serious disorder in which the intestinal resorptive capacity is insufficient to provide an adequate alimentary supply [1]. The estimated incidence in children is 24.5 per 100,000 live births with a higher incidence reported in preterm infants [2]. The estimated mortality is 2/100,000 population/year for children with SBS under 4 years [2] and 37.5% of neonates with SBS [3]. SBS in children occurs after congenital or acquired loss of part of the intestine [4], in most cases due to gastroschisis, necrotizing enterocolitis, mid-gut volvulus and intestinal atresia [5]."
Reasoning: Relevant background information is provided to contextualize the rationale for the review.

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The article does not mention a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined research objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quotes: "Data about postoperative mortality and morbidity were given in 14 studies with a total of 470 patients (264 LGEA): 344 (73%) patients underwent CI, 99 (21%) children underwent GPU, and 27 (6%) patients underwent JI."
Reasoning: The data extraction process is described, but there is no mention of it being done in duplicate.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "A literature search (PubMed and Embase) was performed, and all human studies published in the English-language literature between 2006 and 2011 describing esophageal replacement for LGEA were identified, using the medical subject headings "Esophageal Atresia," "Long-gap," "Esophagoplasty," "Replacement," "Interposition," "Substitution," "Graft," and their combinations. All titles and abstracts were scanned and appropriate citations were reviewed. Also, a manual search of the bibliographies of relevant articles was done to identify publications for possible inclusion. Included were prospective, retrospective, and comparative studies."
Reasoning: At least 2 databases were searched along with reference scanning, fulfilling the criteria for a comprehensive search.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The inclusion of grey literature or unpublished studies is not mentioned.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: "A total of 15 studies (4 comparative retrospective, 8 retrospective, and 3 prospective) including 470 patients (264 LGEA) were identified; 344 (73%) patients underwent CI, 99 (21%) GPU, and 27 (6%) JI."
Reasoning: The number of included studies is provided, but there is no list of the actual studies or excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: See Table 1 which provides details on the author, year, replacement performed, number of patients, and study type for each included study.
Reasoning: An aggregated table provides the key characteristics of the included studies.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The article does not mention assessing the quality of the included studies.
[No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
[NA] - Question A7 was answered "No"

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "Studies were divided into the following three groups: JI, CI, and GPU. To perform the statistical overview Comprehensive Meta Analysis software (Version 2.2.064) was used. Data were computed using a random effects approach."
Reasoning: Appropriate meta-analysis methods were used to combine the study findings.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Publication bias is not mentioned or assessed in the article.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: "Conflict of interest: None"
Reasoning: Conflicts of interest for the systematic review are reported, but not for the individual included studies.
[No]

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quote: "Long-Gap Esophageal Atresia: a Meta-Analysis of Jejunal Interposition, Colon Interposition, and Gastric Pull-Up"
Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the article as a meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quote: The abstract contains labeled sections for Aim, Methods, Main Results, and Conclusion.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with the key required sections.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "There is still no consensus about the optimal surgical approach for esophageal replacement in the case of long-gap esophageal atresia (LGEA) or extensive corrosive strictures."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is provided in the context of the lack of consensus on the optimal surgical approach.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The aim of this article was to perform a meta-analysis comparing the most widely used techniques for esophageal replacement in children: jejunal interposition (JI), colon interposition (CI), and gastric pull-up (GPU)."
Reasoning: The objectives are clearly stated, although the PICOS elements are not fully specified.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "The articles were reviewed with a special focus on mortality, postoperative morbidity, and long-term follow-up. Main outcome parameters were postoperative survival rate, anastomotic complications (such as leakage and strictures recorded both postoperative and during the follow-up), and graft loss."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria in terms of outcomes of interest are provided.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "A literature search (PubMed and Embase) was performed, and all human studies published in the English-language literature between 2006 and 2011 describing esophageal replacement for LGEA were identified, using the medical subject headings "Esophageal Atresia," "Long-gap," "Esophagoplasty," "Replacement," "Interposition," "Substitution," "Graft," and their combinations."
Reasoning: The databases searched and date ranges are specified.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quote: The full search strategy is not provided.
Reasoning: Key search terms are mentioned but the full electronic search strategy is not presented.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "All titles and abstracts were scanned and appropriate citations were reviewed. Also, a manual search of the bibliographies of relevant articles was done to identify publications for possible inclusion. Included were prospective, retrospective, and comparative studies."
Reasoning: The process of screening titles/abstracts and reviewing full-texts is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quote: None relevant
Reasoning: The data extraction process is not described in detail.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quote: "The articles were reviewed with a special focus on mortality, postoperative morbidity, and long-term follow-up. Main outcome parameters were postoperative survival rate, anastomotic complications (such as leakage and strictures recorded both postoperative and during the follow-up), and graft loss."
Reasoning: The key data items and outcomes of interest are defined.
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Assessment of risk of bias in individual studies is not mentioned.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quote: "Mortality is similar: postoperative survival rate after CI was 96%, after GPU 90.4%. Anastomotic strictures (16.3% after CI vs 17.7% after GPU) and graft loss (4.2% after CI vs 4.8% after GPU) are comparable after these two procedures."
Reasoning: The primary summary measures are postoperative survival rate, anastomotic strictures, and graft loss.
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
[NA] - Meta-analysis methods are described but measures of consistency like I2 are not reported.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies like publication bias are not mentioned.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: No additional analyses like sensitivity analysis or meta-regression are mentioned.
[No]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 15 studies (4 comparative retrospective, 8 retrospective, and 3 prospective) including 470 patients (264 LGEA) were identified; 344 (73%) patients underwent CI, 99 (21%) GPU, and 27 (6%) JI."
Reasoning: The number of included studies and patients is provided, but a full study flow diagram is not included.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: See Table 1 which provides details on the author, year, replacement performed, number of patients, and study type for each included study.
Reasoning: The characteristics of each included study are presented.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment of individual studies are not provided, consistent with no risk of bias assessment being mentioned in the methods.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: Data for individual studies are provided in Tables 2a, 2b, and 2c.
Reasoning: For the main outcomes, data are provided for each study allowing them to be viewed independently.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
[NA] - No meta-analysis results with confidence intervals or consistency measures are reported.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
[NA] - Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.

P23. Results / Additional analysis
[NA] - No additional analyses were mentioned in the methods.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "The present article set out to perform a meta-analysis of the literature regarding esophageal replacement for LGEA or extensive corrosive strictures, in an attempt to elucidate the best approach. Comparison is challenging as outcomes are reported differently. GPU and CI appear comparable regarding the main outcomes of the present study: postoperative mortality, anastomotic complications, and graft loss."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, although the strength of evidence for each outcome is not explicitly stated.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "Far fewer studies describe the results of GPU and only two authors describe their experience with JI. If all studies about esophageal replacement for LGEA were similar we could compute a simple mean of the effect sizes, but considering the above mentioned methodological heterogeneity a simple comparison of the mean of the event rates described by different investigators seems inadequate."
Reasoning: Some key limitations related to the small number of studies for certain procedures are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Concluding, from this systematic review of the most recent experiences in esophageal replacement for LGEA and extensive corrosive strictures, no surgical approach emerges distinctly as the best procedure. Comparison is challenging as outcomes are reported differently. GPU and CI appear comparable regarding the main outcomes of the present study: postoperative mortality, anastomotic complications, and graft loss."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of the limitations.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]

[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quote: The full search strategy is not provided.
Reasoning: Key search terms are mentioned but the full electronic search strategy is not presented.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "All titles and abstracts were scanned and appropriate citations were reviewed. Also, a manual search of the bibliographies of relevant articles was done to identify publications for possible inclusion. Included were prospective, retrospective, and comparative studies."
Reasoning: The process of screening titles/abstracts and reviewing full-texts is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quote: None relevant
Reasoning: The data extraction process is not described in detail.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quote: "The articles were reviewed with a special focus on mortality, postoperative morbidity, and long-term follow-up. Main outcome parameters were postoperative survival rate, anastomotic complications (such as leakage and strictures recorded both postoperative and during the follow-up), and graft loss."
Reasoning: The key data items and outcomes of interest are defined.
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Assessment of risk of bias in individual studies is not mentioned.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quote: "Mortality is similar: postoperative survival rate after CI was 96%, after GPU 90.4%. Anastomotic strictures (16.3% after CI vs 17.7% after GPU) and graft loss (4.2% after CI vs 4.8% after GPU) are comparable after these two procedures."
Reasoning: The primary summary measures are postoperative survival rate, anastomotic strictures, and graft loss.
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
[NA] - Meta-analysis methods are described but measures of consistency like I2 are not reported.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies like publication bias are not mentioned.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: No additional analyses like sensitivity analysis or meta-regression are mentioned.
[No]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 15 studies (4 comparative retrospective, 8 retrospective, and 3 prospective) including 470 patients (264 LGEA) were identified; 344 (73%) patients underwent CI, 99 (21%) GPU, and 27 (6%) JI."
Reasoning: The number of included studies and patients is provided, but a full study flow diagram is not included.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: See Table 1 which provides details on the author, year, replacement performed, number of patients, and study type for each included study.
Reasoning: The characteristics of each included study are presented.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment of individual studies are not provided, consistent with no risk of bias assessment being mentioned in the methods.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: Data for individual studies are provided in Tables 2a, 2b, and 2c.
Reasoning: For the main outcomes, data are provided for each study allowing them to be viewed independently.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
[NA] - No meta-analysis results with confidence intervals or consistency measures are reported.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
[NA] - Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.

P23. Results / Additional analysis
[NA] - No additional analyses were mentioned in the methods.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "The present article set out to perform a meta-analysis of the literature regarding esophageal replacement for LGEA or extensive corrosive strictures, in an attempt to elucidate the best approach. Comparison is challenging as outcomes are reported differently. GPU and CI appear comparable regarding the main outcomes of the present study: postoperative mortality, anastomotic complications, and graft loss."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, although the strength of evidence for each outcome is not explicitly stated.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "Far fewer studies describe the results of GPU and only two authors describe their experience with JI. If all studies about esophageal replacement for LGEA were similar we could compute a simple mean of the effect sizes, but considering the above mentioned methodological heterogeneity a simple comparison of the mean of the event rates described by different investigators seems inadequate."
Reasoning: Some key limitations related to the small number of studies for certain procedures are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Concluding, from this systematic review of the most recent experiences in esophageal replacement for LGEA and extensive corrosive strictures, no surgical approach emerges distinctly as the best procedure. Comparison is challenging as outcomes are reported differently. GPU and CI appear comparable regarding the main outcomes of the present study: postoperative mortality, anastomotic complications, and graft loss."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of the limitations.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]
