llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "The APSA Outcomes and Evidence Based Practice Committee proposed five broadly applicable questions regarding asymptomatic malrotation as the focus for this systematic review."
The review questions were established a priori by the APSA committee.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Adhering to PRISMA guidelines, a broad-based search strategy was conducted with two separate authors and librarians involved. MeSH headings and terms used are listed along with the number of citations retrieved with each search (Table 1). Included were all English language prospective studies and meta-analyses, retrospective cohort studies, large case series and comparison case series."
Two separate authors conducted study selection according to PRISMA guidelines.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE)."
"A total of 224 abstracts were found in a broad search strategy and screened. No prospective studies were found. Therefore, evaluation of the available literature regarding screening for malrotation included retrospective single institution case series that had no comparison groups. Historical bias, selection bias, and institutional bias were noted in most studies."
Multiple electronic databases were searched. Years and databases used were not specified. Supplemental searching of other sources was not mentioned.
[No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
No list of included or excluded studies was provided.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Table 4 Ladd procedure for patients with heterotaxy syndrome and asymptomatic malrotation."
A table of included study characteristics was provided.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Historical bias, selection bias, and institutional bias were noted in most studies."
Study quality was assessed in terms of risk of bias.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quote: "Multicenter and prospective data should be collected to better assess the risk profile for this complex group of patients. A multidisciplinary approach involving surgery, cardiology, critical care and the patient's caregivers can help guide a watchful waiting management plan in individual cases."
The limitations of the retrospective, single-center studies were considered when formulating the conclusions and recommendations.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
The studies were not combined quantitatively.
[NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
No assessment of publication bias was mentioned.
[NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Conflicts of interest for the systematic review authors were not reported. Funding sources of the included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Asymptomatic malrotation: Diagnosis and surgical management An American Pediatric Surgical Association outcomes and evidence based practice committee systematic review"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for objective, methods, results, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Malrotation, also known as intestinal rotation abnormality (IRA), can pose a great risk to the pediatric patient owing to the potential for a catastrophic event such as midgut volvulus, ischemic bowel, and possible short gut syndrome or death [1]. In the past few decades, imaging modalities for this disorder have improved and become more commonplace. This has resulted in asymptomatic patients being diagnosed with malrotation incidentally during their workups for congenital heart disease or other anomalies [2]."
The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The APSA Outcomes and Evidence Based Practice Committee proposed five broadly applicable questions regarding asymptomatic malrotation as the focus for this systematic review."
The review questions are explicitly stated.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Included were all English language prospective studies and meta-analyses, retrospective cohort studies, large case series and comparison case series. Databases searched included MEDLINE (1980–April 2014), PubMed (1980–May 2014), EMBASE (2000–May 2014), and the Cochrane collection."
Eligibility criteria for study designs, language, and databases are provided with rationale.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "Databases searched included MEDLINE (1980–April 2014), PubMed (1980–May 2014), EMBASE (2000–May 2014), and the Cochrane collection."
Information sources are described with dates of coverage. The search date was not provided.
[No]

P8. Methods / Search
The full search strategies are not presented.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Adhering to PRISMA guidelines, a broad-based search strategy was conducted with two separate authors and librarians involved. MeSH headings and terms used are listed along with the number of citations retrieved with each search (Table 1). Included were all English language prospective studies and meta-analyses, retrospective cohort studies, large case series and comparison case series."
The process for selecting studies is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
No information is provided on the data extraction process.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
No list of data items is provided.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "Historical bias, selection bias, and institutional bias were noted in most studies."
Methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies are described.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
No summary measures are specified.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
No methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are specified.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 224 abstracts were found in a broad search strategy and screened. No prospective studies were found. Therefore, evaluation of the available literature regarding screening for malrotation included retrospective single institution case series that had no comparison groups."
The number of studies screened and included are provided. Reasons for exclusions at each stage are not given and no flow diagram is presented.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "Table 4 Ladd procedure for patients with heterotaxy syndrome and asymptomatic malrotation."
Study characteristics are provided in a table with citations.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quote: "Historical bias, selection bias, and institutional bias were noted in most studies."
Results of the risk of bias assessments are presented.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
No results of individual studies are provided, only a summary table.
[No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
No assessment of risk of bias across studies was reported.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "Ryerson et al. conducted a broad search survey of 224 patients with malrotation and an intestinal rotation abnormality (IRA). There were 86 patients who underwent a Ladd procedure prior to hospital discharge. Observation can be considered when extensive education for parents and caregivers and close clinical follow-up."
"Pockett et al. from Alberta reported on 7 asymptomatic patients with HS over three years who underwent elective Ladd procedure. They compared this group to 22 patients without HS, all of whom were symptomatic [11]. Their complication rate in the HS group was 57% (four patients) vs. 9% (2 patients) in the non-HS population."
The main findings are summarized, including their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "Multicenter and prospective data should be collected to better assess the risk profile for this complex group of patients. A multidisciplinary approach involving surgery, cardiology, critical care and the patient's caregivers can help guide a watchful waiting management plan in individual cases."
Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Our review would support the following management algorithm: When a patient is diagnosed with malrotation as a result of a screening study, particularly on another study, consideration should be given to three factors: 1) presence of symptoms, 2) status of cardiac disease, and 3) age. All patients need to undergo an UGI to confirm the diagnosis. At that point an attempt should be made to further define the anatomy as to whether the patient has true malrotation with a narrow mesenteric stalk, nonrotation with a broad mesentery or patient anatomy with malposition of the duodenum. Patients who are symptomatic should undergo a diagnostic laparoscopy and Ladd procedure but normal anatomy is confirmed. True malrotation may be considered abnormal. Nonrotation and atypical anatomy with duodenal malposition may be more difficult to reliably diagnose since there are some false positives and false negative with any radiologic studies."
A general interpretation of the results is provided in the context of other evidence, with implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
No funding sources are reported for the systematic review or the included studies.
[No]
original_llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "The APSA Outcomes and Evidence Based Practice Committee proposed five broadly applicable questions regarding asymptomatic malrotation as the focus for this systematic review."
The review questions were established a priori by the APSA committee.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Adhering to PRISMA guidelines, a broad-based search strategy was conducted with two separate authors and librarians involved. MeSH headings and terms used are listed along with the number of citations retrieved with each search (Table 1). Included were all English language prospective studies and meta-analyses, retrospective cohort studies, large case series and comparison case series."
Two separate authors conducted study selection according to PRISMA guidelines.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "At least two electronic sources should be searched. The report must include years and databases used (e.g., Central, EMBASE, and MEDLINE)."
"A total of 224 abstracts were found in a broad search strategy and screened. No prospective studies were found. Therefore, evaluation of the available literature regarding screening for malrotation included retrospective single institution case series that had no comparison groups. Historical bias, selection bias, and institutional bias were noted in most studies."
Multiple electronic databases were searched. Years and databases used were not specified. Supplemental searching of other sources was not mentioned.
[No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
No list of included or excluded studies was provided.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Table 4 Ladd procedure for patients with heterotaxy syndrome and asymptomatic malrotation."
A table of included study characteristics was provided.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Historical bias, selection bias, and institutional bias were noted in most studies."
Study quality was assessed in terms of risk of bias.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quote: "Multicenter and prospective data should be collected to better assess the risk profile for this complex group of patients. A multidisciplinary approach involving surgery, cardiology, critical care and the patient's caregivers can help guide a watchful waiting management plan in individual cases."
The limitations of the retrospective, single-center studies were considered when formulating the conclusions and recommendations.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
The studies were not combined quantitatively.
[NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
No assessment of publication bias was mentioned.
[NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Conflicts of interest for the systematic review authors were not reported. Funding sources of the included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Asymptomatic malrotation: Diagnosis and surgical management An American Pediatric Surgical Association outcomes and evidence based practice committee systematic review"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for objective, methods, results, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Malrotation, also known as intestinal rotation abnormality (IRA), can pose a great risk to the pediatric patient owing to the potential for a catastrophic event such as midgut volvulus, ischemic bowel, and possible short gut syndrome or death [1]. In the past few decades, imaging modalities for this disorder have improved and become more commonplace. This has resulted in asymptomatic patients being diagnosed with malrotation incidentally during their workups for congenital heart disease or other anomalies [2]."
The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The APSA Outcomes and Evidence Based Practice Committee proposed five broadly applicable questions regarding asymptomatic malrotation as the focus for this systematic review."
The review questions are explicitly stated.

No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

Eligibility criteria for study designs, language, and databases are provided with rationale.

Quote: "Databases searched included MEDLINE (1980–April 2014), PubMed (1980–May 2014), EMBASE (2000–May 2014), and the Cochrane collection."

Quotes: "Ryerson et al. conducted a broad search survey of 224 patients with malrotation and an intestinal rotation abnormality (IRA). There were 86 patients who underwent a Ladd procedure prior to hospital discharge. Observation can be considered when extensive education for parents and caregivers and close clinical follow-up."
"Pockett et al. from Alberta reported on 7 asymptomatic patients with HS over three years who underwent elective Ladd procedure. They compared this group to 22 patients without HS, all of whom were symptomatic [11]. Their complication rate in the HS group was 57% (four patients) vs. 9% (2 patients) in the non-HS population."
The main findings are summarized, including their relevance to key groups.

Reasoning: The authors provide the number of included studies and some basic characteristics.

A7
Quote: "Each included article was appraised by three reviewers (GJ, LZL and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently. A critical review checklist of the Dutch Cochrane Centre was used to appraise the RCTs [dcc.cochrane.org, last updated July 2010]. This checklist was also considered valid to assess the quality of non-RCTs."
Reasoning: The authors used a validated checklist to assess the quality of included studies.
[Yes]

A8
Quote: "Although shorter hospital stay is noted in LO, it does not provide significant advantage over open surgery for treating NPT. However, due to the publishing bias, a series of RCTs are necessary to explore the efficiencies of LO in the management of NPT in children."
Reasoning: The authors consider the quality of evidence when formulating conclusions and recommendations.
[Yes]

A9
Quote: "Statistical analyses were performed using Review Manager 4.2.10 Software (The Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK). Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 statistics. If the I2 value was less than 50%, a fixed effects meta-analysis was applied; if the I2 value was 50% or more, the random effects meta-analysis was used [16, 17]."
Reasoning: The authors used appropriate statistical methods to combine study findings and assessed heterogeneity.
[Yes]

No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing publication bias.

Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See structured abstract on page 1.
Reasoning: The article provides a structured abstract with background, methods, results, and conclusions sections.
[Yes] 

P3
Quote: "The undescended testes (cryptorchidism) is one of the most common disorders of childhood, affecting 0.8–1.8% of infants at 1 year of age, 3% of full-term newborns, and 21% of premature babies [1, 2]. Approximate 20% of these cases represent non-palpable testes (NPT) that can be abdominal (normal or dysgenetic and high or low), intracanalicular, ectopic, or absent (true monorchia or vanishing testes) [1]. Thus been established that abdominal testes may be associated with an increased risk of infertility and cancer [3, 4]."
Reasoning: The introduction provides rationale and context for the systematic review.
[Yes]

P4

No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention a protocol or registration number for the systematic review.

Reasoning: The authors describe the process for selecting studies.

P10

Reasoning: The authors describe the data extraction process.

P11
Quote: "Data regarding the following factors were considered: first author, study duration, methodology, participant features, intervention characteristics, and outcome measures."
Reasoning: The authors list the data items collected from studies.
[Yes]

P12
Quote: "Each included article was appraised by three reviewers (GJ, LZL and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently. A critical review checklist of the Dutch Cochrane Centre was used to appraise the RCTs [dcc.cochrane.org, last updated July 2010]. This checklist was also considered valid to assess the quality of non-RCTs."
Reasoning: The authors describe the methods used to assess risk of bias in individual studies.

Quote: "Weighted mean differences (WMDs) and ORs were used for the analysis of continuous and dichotomous variables, respectively."
Reasoning: The authors state the principal summary measures.
[Yes]

P14
Quote: "Statistical analyses were performed using Review Manager 4.2.10 Software (The Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK). Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 statistics. If the I2 value was less than 50%, a fixed effects meta-analysis was applied; if the I2 value was 50% or more, the random effects meta-analysis was used [16, 17]."
Reasoning: The authors describe the methods used to combine results and assess consistency.
[Yes]

P15
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence, such as publication bias or selective reporting within studies.
[No]

P16
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not describe any additional analyses such as sensitivity or subgroup analyses.
[No]

P17
Quote: "Two hundred and twenty-six studies were initially found to report the laparoscopy in the management of NPT using the keywords "laparoscopy" and "non-palpable testis". Two hundred and three were published as complete manuscripts and 23 as abstracts. After screening the titles and abstracts, 129 studies were excluded due to review article or reports in adult. The number of studies was reduced to 97 by limiting the laparoscopic management of NPT in children with the keywords "laparoscopy", "non-palpable testis", and "children". Seventy-nine articles were further excluded due to no comparison with open surgery. After independent review, 18 publications dealing with comparison of LO and OO for the treatment of pediatric NPT were considered to be eligible for inclusion in the analysis."
Reasoning: The authors provide a flow diagram (Fig. 1) and describe the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: See Table 1 for study characteristics.
Reasoning: The authors present the characteristics of included studies in a table.
[Yes]

P19
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not present data on the risk of bias of each study.
[No]

P20
Quote: See forest plots in Figs. 2-3.
Reasoning: The authors provide forest plots showing the effect estimates and confidence intervals for each study and outcome.
[Yes]

P21
Quote: See forest plots in Figs. 2-3.
Reasoning: The authors provide forest plots showing the meta-analysis results with confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P22
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not present any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[No]

P23
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not report any additional analyses.
[No]

P24
Quote: "In this meta-analysis, we demonstrate that the operative time, time to resume feeding and full activity is similar between LO and OO. Although the hospital stay of LO was slightly shorter than that of OO, this benefit may be less significant due to the one day basis of both procedures in most centers. In addition, the recurrence, success rate and testicular atrophy were found to be comparable between LO and LO, suggesting that laparoscopy does not provide significant advantage over open surgery for treating NPT."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings and their relevance to key stakeholders.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Another study indicated the longer operative and anesthesia time in laparoscopic cases, due to the tendency that peeping testis is considered as located in the inguinal canal during open procedure and as intra-abdominal under a laparoscope [3]. The overall rate of abdominal testes in 3 large open surgery series is approximately 40%, and there is a higher percent of absent testes in the laparoscopic series [25–27]. However, Ferro et al. [3] reported that the percentage of abdominal testes is same in laparoscopic and open surgical approaches, with a slight difference in the incidence of inguinal and absent testes."
Reasoning: The authors discuss some limitations of the evidence at the study level.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "In this meta-analysis, we found no significant differences in regard to operative time for laparoscopic versus open surgical treatment of NPT. We also noted a significant learning curve with the LO, resulting in a markedly shorter operation time than in the initial cases [13]. Abolyosr et al. [9] reported that due to a transperitoneal approach gaining a midline subumbilical incision, the mean time to return to normal activity after open primary and second stage Fowler–Stephens orchiopexy procedures was longer than LO. However, our meta-analysis did not reveal any difference in time to resume feeding or full activity between LO and OO, while the hospital stay of OO was slightly longer than LO. Since the testicular surgery is performed on one day basis in most centers, caution should be paid to interpret the difference in hospital stay between LO and OO."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not describe sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

The overall rate of abdominal testes in 3 large open surgery series is approximately 40%, and there is a higher percent of absent testes in the laparoscopic series [25–27]. However, Ferro et al. [3] reported that the percentage of abdominal testes is same in laparoscopic and open surgical approaches, with a slight difference in the incidence of inguinal and absent testes."
Reasoning: The authors discuss some limitations of the evidence at the study level.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "In this meta-analysis, we found no significant differences in regard to operative time for laparoscopic versus open surgical treatment of NPT. We also noted a significant learning curve with the LO, resulting in a markedly shorter operation time than in the initial cases [13]. Abolyosr et al. [9] reported that due to a transperitoneal approach gaining a midline subumbilical incision, the mean time to return to normal activity after open primary and second stage Fowler–Stephens orchiopexy procedures was longer than LO. However, our meta-analysis did not reveal any difference in time to resume feeding or full activity between LO and OO, while the hospital stay of OO was slightly longer than LO. Since the testicular surgery is performed on one day basis in most centers, caution should be paid to interpret the difference in hospital stay between LO and OO."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors do not describe sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "We systematically reviewed the pediatric literature."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Incidences of recurrent appendicitis, complications after IA, and carcinoid tumor were estimated accounting for interstudy heterogeneity. Cost and length of stay of IA were analyzed."
"Data relating to length of stay after IA were reported in an inconsistent fashion among individual studies and are therefore presented in descriptive form only."
Reasoning: Data extraction was performed independently by 2 reviewers, but no information is provided on the selection process.
[No]

A3
Quotes: "A Medline search was performed using the keywords appendix mass, interval appendicectomy, and children from January 1964 to July 2009 to identify reports of successful nonoperative treatment of AM in children (<16 years). Furthermore, the index of all issues of the Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery was searched for relevant articles. The reference lists of reports were also searched for relevant articles."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases and supplementary sources were searched. Search terms are provided but the full search strategy is not available.
[Yes]

A4
Reasoning: The inclusion of grey literature or unpublished studies is not mentioned.
[No]

A5
Reasoning: A list of included studies is not provided, and excluded studies are not mentioned.
[No]

A6
Quote: "Three studies (127 cases) reporting routine nonsurgical treatment were identified; all were retrospective. There was marked interstudy heterogeneity and variable follow-up. After successful nonoperative treatment of AM, the risk of recurrent appendicitis is 20.5% (95% confidence interval [CI], 14.3%-28.4%). The incidence of complications after IA (23 studies, n = 1247) is 3.4% (95% CI, 2.2-5.1), and the incidence of carcinoid tumor found at IA (15 studies, n = 955) is 0.9% (95% CI, 0.5-1.8). No reports compared costs."
Reasoning: Characteristics of the included studies such as number of cases, study design, follow-up duration, and outcomes are provided in aggregate form.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "Because of the limited literature on this topic, we subsequently broadened our inclusion criteria to include reports of nonoperative expectant management after successful nonoperative treatment of an AM in children and, separately, reports of outcome after IA in children."
Reasoning: The inclusion criteria were broadened due to limited literature, but no a priori methods for assessing study quality are mentioned.
[No]

A8
Reasoning: Not applicable as the scientific quality of included studies was not assessed (A7).
[NA]

A9
Reasoning: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis.
[NA]

A10
Reasoning: Not applicable as this is a systematic review without a meta-analysis.
[NA]

A11
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are reported, but sources of support for the included studies are not mentioned.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Is interval appendicectomy justified after successful nonoperative treatment of an appendix mass in children? A systematic review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See the structured abstract on the first page.
Reasoning: A structured abstract with labeled sections for background, methods, results, and conclusions is provided.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Inflammation in acute appendicitis may be enclosed by the omentum and adjacent loops of bowel, resulting in the formation of an inflammatory mass known as an appendix mass (AM). A recent meta-analysis estimated that approximately 9% of all children with acute appendicitis have an inflammatory mass at presentation [1]."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known about appendix mass in children.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "The purpose of this systematic review was to evaluate the evidence for IA in children after successful nonoperative treatment of an AM based on the current available literature."
Reasoning: The review question mentions the population (children), intervention (interval appendectomy), and outcome (after successful nonoperative treatment of appendix mass), but does not explicitly state the comparator or study designs.
[No]

P5
Reasoning: The existence of a review protocol is not mentioned.
[No]

P6
Quote: "Because of the limited literature on this topic, we subsequently broadened our inclusion criteria to include reports of nonoperative expectant management after successful nonoperative treatment of an AM in children and, separately, reports of outcome after IA in children."
Reasoning: The inclusion criteria were broadened but the rationale is explained. However, the full eligibility criteria are not clearly specified.
[No]

P7
Quote: "A Medline search was performed using the keywords appendix mass, interval appendicectomy, and children from January 1964 to July 2009 to identify reports of successful nonoperative treatment of AM in children (<16 years). Furthermore, the index of all issues of the Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery was searched for relevant articles. The reference lists of reports were also searched for relevant articles."
Reasoning: The information sources (Medline and journal indexes) and date ranges are described, but it is not clear if additional sources like contacting study authors were used.
[Yes]

P8
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented for any of the databases.
[No]

P9
Quote: "Because of the limited literature on this topic, we subsequently broadened our inclusion criteria to include reports of nonoperative expectant management after successful nonoperative treatment of an AM in children and, separately, reports of outcome after IA in children."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described in terms of broadening the inclusion criteria, but the full process of screening and eligibility assessment is not detailed.
[No]

P10
Reasoning: The data extraction process is not described.
[No]

P11
Quote: "Data relating to length of stay after IA were reported in an inconsistent fashion among individual studies and are therefore presented in descriptive form only."
Reasoning: Variables for which data were sought are mentioned (e.g. length of stay) but are not listed and defined systematically.
[No]

P12
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies are not described.
[No]

P13
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are not explicitly stated.
[No]

P14
Reasoning: Not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P15
Reasoning: Assessment of risk of bias across studies, such as publication bias, is not mentioned.
[No]

P16
Reasoning: Additional analyses are not mentioned.
[No]

P17
Reasoning: A flow diagram of study selection is not provided, and reasons for exclusion at each stage are not given.
[No]

P18
Reasoning: Characteristics of individual studies are not presented with citations. Some aggregate characteristics are provided but not systematically for each study.
[No]

P19
Reasoning: Risk of bias assessments for individual studies are not reported.
[No]

P20
Reasoning: Simple summary data for each group and effect estimates with confidence intervals are not systematically reported for each study, although some individual study data is mentioned in the text.
[No]

P21
Reasoning: Not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22
Reasoning: Not applicable as assessment of risk of bias across studies was not mentioned (P15).
[NA]

P23
Reasoning: Not applicable as additional analyses were not mentioned (P16).
[NA]

P24
Quote: "The most significant finding of this review is that, despite the relative frequency of the condition, we have been unable to identify any data comparing routine IA with a "watchful waiting" approach nor any prospective data relating to the risk of recurrent appendicitis in children."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized but the strength of evidence for each outcome is not provided.
[No]

P25
Quote: "Although the retrospective nature of the included studies may limit the strength of this review, we justify its completion because it is our opinion that there is currently inadequate information on which to base a treatment decision."
Reasoning: Limitations of the retrospective nature of included studies are discussed, but limitations at the outcome level and review level are not fully addressed.
[No]

P26
Quote: "This review suggests that the risk of recurrent appendicitis is approximately 20%. Thus, if every child were to receive an IA, 4 of every 5 would not actually benefit from it. Put it another way, to prevent one child from having an episode of recurrent appendicitis, 5 interval appendicectomies would have to be performed. Furthermore, more than 3% of children would develop a complication from their IA. Although these data suggest that hospital stay in the region of 3 days would be required, we acknowledge that, with current surgical practice of laparoscopic IA, this may be an overestimate [10,12]. The alternative watchful waiting approach carries a 1 in 5 risk of developing recurrent appendicitis and a very small risk (<1%) of missing a carcinoid tumor."
Reasoning: The results are interpreted in the context of clinical decision making and implications for practice. Implications for future research are not explicitly stated.
[No]

P27
Quote: "© 2011 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described, and the role of funders is not mentioned.
[No]
